They have chicken and waffles on the menu... but it's not your standard breasted/wing with waffles and syrup; it's a huge breaded breaded smothered in mushroom gravy... with a totally separate waffle on the side. I can't say I prefer this gravy-laden style, but it was still darn good and refreshing to see on the menu.

I've also had the bacon-infused waffle. That's right-- a waffle with strips of bacon inside! On top of the waffle is cheese, red pepper and eggs, sunny-side up. This dish deserves a high-five.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I'd give the banana chocolate chip pancakes 5 fat stars by itself, because they are just delicious darlings. Pancakes are fluffy, and toppings are generous. Everything else are just mere-alright. Coffee is $3+ each, a little higher than other typical breakfast joints', so with their generosity, drink the hell of it. My friend ordered the Waffle Bacon, which I thought is on the dry side. The pancakes are way better. 

We caught a funny incident while patiently waiting for our table. The host/server who's calling names off the wall wouldn't bother to raise his voice to call out to the people sitting on the bench that's about 10 meter away. They ended up having to check the wall, and got furious when their names got erased. Then, a couple of girls ran off to buy something from another shop while waiting to be called, and when their names got called, they weren't yet present. But when they came back 5 minutes later and asked for a table, they got seated right away. I think that is a fair and unfair situation for both sides. Fair for their side, but unfair for our side because we got to wait for another table. We were supposed to be next!!! So we got a communal bar while those girls got a nice big table that fits four.
author: Rika P.

description: Good tasting food, but terrible service.  I hate it when other tables are served their food before us when we arrived and ordered before them.  Even worse when three other tables are served before us and we came before all three.  Not sure what was going on, but the wait staff did not apologize for the long wait before or after I called them on it.  Weak sauce!
author: Benny A.

description:
Honest good home food, charming and sweet are the first things I think of when I think of Eats. 
My favorite would have to be the Waffle Bacon, although from samples I can sufficiently say that I doubt you'll be disappointed. Be prepared for a wait though, and a bursting belly.
author: Bea R.

description: This place got everything right on my breakfast!!! The egg leek and cheese omelette was delicious, just the right consistency.  The blackberry jam was copious delicious and chunky the way I like it.  Best of all an option for salad instead of potatoes!  And the days was great.  Kettle bits of pepper that all mixed so well with the eggs.  Also my waitress was incredibly sweet and worked around a long phone call I was on while outside ( yes I was that customer... But aren't we all sometime). I wish they were closer to my house, this would be my ushe.
author: Eric N.

description:
My new go to brunch spot!

Delicious brunch options and the service is definitely up to par. The pancakes with bananas were so yummy and they also serve 4505 sausages!!! Yum all the way. The servers were so nice and attentive, makes me want to come back.
author: C M.

description: This place is going to be my new go to breakfast spot! The strawberries with goat cheese is delicious!!!
author: Natalie T.

description:
Eats is my favorite go-to brunch spot in the inner richmond.  I always bring people here, and everyone loves it. You can't go wrong.  

I love the homey, eclectic vibe of this place, as well as the friendly staff.  Their coffee is strong and delicious, which is a staple of any brunch spot.  Moreover, their food is amazing! I dream about the fancy toast, and always have a hard time on deciding which entree to order.  The Build your own Mimosas also makes for a most enjoyable experience.  I will be loyal to Eats for all of time!
author: Bridget B.

description: Worth the wait to get in. The potatoes are off the hook!  I had their Arnold Palmer soju cocktail- lovely. Service was excellent on a super busy Saturday. Had the pulled pork scramble and friend has the spicy sausage polenta. Delish!
author: Malorie S.

description: After hearing great things, I decided to try Eats for myself, and unfortunately I was disappointed. I didn't get adventurous, ordering the waffle, two scrambled eggs and bacon, and I think that worked against me. The bacon was okay, the eggs were pretty gross and the waffle was burnt. Service was also mediocre, although understanding that I went on a Sunday, I can't really blame them for their inattentiveness. I would probably come back and try something else, maybe one of their more specialty breakfasts, but for now they get 3 stars.
author: Gabriela A.

description:
How have I not know of this place before??? I've aimlessly (and negligently!) passed by this lovable culinary resto for years on my way to hair appointments, chinese/thai dinners, and meaningless perusing and shopping at Kamei. Finally came upon this place after yelp search for post-work breakfast joints. 

Had the ham and bacon benedict which was delicious and the potatoes were OMG. I usually pass on potatoes to reduce bland carb intake, but these looked too delicious and I was pleasantly satisfied. So well seasoned!! My neighbor's waffles with berries looked off the charts good, I had to stop myself from doing the unthinkable and swipe a bite. 

Mugs are cute, bought one for $10 =).
author: Christine Y.

description: This is not a review for chicken and waffles.  I think that dish has been sufficiently analyzed.  I do want to say that this place is charming and cozy, our server today was great (very friendly, timed everything well, offered to refill coffee without our having to ask) and the food was delicious!  I had the B.A.T. scramble (bacon, avocado, tomato) with a side salad and it was perfect.  The veggies were so fresh, with a just-right amount of a very tasty vinaigrette, and the coffee (in those cute mugs) is really good too.  Loved it.  Can't wait to come back!
author: Samantha G.

description: We make a point of coming here every time we are in the city. We love, love, love it! Great food, great service!
author: Joel S.

description:
For a Sunday brunch, expect the wait to be half an hour or so, but the boyfriend and I were lucky, the weather was beautiful outside, so the wait went by quickly.

It was our first time at Eats and the bf was pretty much set on the ham and eggs benedict, while I kept debating over a scramble or the chicken & waffles. Our waitress was ever so patient as I first went with scramble, then quickly changed my mind, and then I went on right ahead to ask her for a recommendation. She suggested the chicken & waffle EVER SO NICELY and I docilely complied.

When the gigantic plate of fried chicken topped with gravy and mushroom & two thick slices of waffles came out, I knew it was going to last me for the day. It was extremely delicious, I especially loved the mushroom and gravy, it was a delightful twist to the traditional fried chicken. The benedict wasn't all too impressive, but the garlic house potatoes (with actual cloves of garlic) took my boyfriend's breath away.

Overall, Eats was a good dining experience, the waitress was super nice and helpful, definitely a must try breakfast/ brunch joint.
author: Ada C.

description:
I grew up around this area, but I have never ever tried this place! I dont know whY!!! My dad wanted to eat at a breakfast place near his doc because he had to starve for 24 hours for a check up. and so we came here. He really liked it! 

He had their waffle with fresh fruit on top. and he finished every bit of it n looked happy. lol 

I had their spinach and mushroom eggs benedict. VERY good. I had it with the potatoes.

Interesting how they put roasted garlic (unpeeled) with the potatoes. 

Wish they cut the fruit thicker, its a good palette cleanser. 

Service is great
author: Erica L.

description:
I used to come here often many years ago.
I was always with my 2 boys for weekend brunch.
This place was always popular for weekends.
I remember that the place used to have a special "thin" pancake, it was between regular pancake and crepe, or, I could say, amateur crepe.
I liked it.

I remember there was an Asian lady, I think she and her husband owned the place. She was middle age, short hair bitch-lasbo type.
Reason why I just wrote "bitch" only because I had never seen her smile.
I think she didn't like the job, serving food to other people, or she had a huge ego, but showing her face, you can tell right away when you see her face, like nothing satisfies her life kind.
Maybe she disliked her husband.

I think she disliked me too.
That happen often.
I didn't care, as long as I get served.

Well, last week, my son phoned me to get together for brunch and he picked the place because the owner changed.
So, we got here for Sunday morning.

i had Waffle Bacon.
It was 2 eggs over a "2 bacon" cooked in a waffle.
The 2 eggs were a perfect sunny-side-up, because when you break the egg, won't run over like water, it was like gelatin.

I hate egg yolk run over like water sunny-side-up.
Even over-easy. i always have over-medium to see egg yolk stay and hold in side.
But, the 2 eggs was looked just like a sunny-side-up.
I was like "Oh Hell, here we go, this egg yolk run down the river !"
But, the egg yolk was like gelatin.
The bacon was good too.

You can choose potato or greens.
I got potato.
The potato was with roast garlic!

We were 5 of us.
My son's gf had Chicken Waffle, she gave me a bite, it was very good.

The service was good too.

I think the "New Eats" became our "regular" Brunch place again.

But, I kind of missed the bitch waitress, tell you the truth.
author: Nobu K.

description: soo yummy . one of the best egg benefits i have tried . good and fast service . i  really recommended
author: Nestor G.

description:
I really love this place. My favorites are the waffles with fruit (so fluffy and the fruit is always fresh) and the scrambles (they have many vegetarian options made with fresh seasonal veggies) I've never had an issue here before, but I do make sure to only get food to go, or dine-in during an off-peak time, because no food is worth waiting on the street for 30 minutes for, in my opinion, when there are times when there are no lines.

Last week, I had a friend and her son visiting from out of town and we went here on a Friday around 2pm for a very late breakfast. There were 2 large tables open when we arrived, so no waiting.  I had already eaten, so I ordered a half-order of fancy toast, thinking it sounded like a good treat. And I LOVED it. A toasted baguette topped with moist goats cheese, fresh strawberries & drizzled with honey. They have other choices of toppings as well like banana, pomegranate, nutella, or whipped cream.

My friend ordered the eggs, potatoes &toast. Minus potatoes, and with just 1 egg and a side of bacon. They suggested she just order side dishes in order to save a little money. The only issue was that she ordered 1 scrambled egg, and unless they serve ostrich eggs, it was obviously two. And she was charged for 2. I see the menu shows 2 eggs as the only side option, so it's understandable, but it would have been nice if the waiter had explained that to her.

Her son had the tuna melt and inhaled it, so I think it met his approval. Overall very nice experience.
author: Venus S.

description:
Eats is a great little place for breakfast any weekend. I love the veggie scramble and the ricotta cheese pancakes paired with a nice hot cup of coffee.

The service is also very excellent. Since the place isn't too big, you won't be ignored. They have no trouble keeping the coffee cup full!
author: Nathan E.

description:
Owned by Asian Americans, cooked by Asian Americans, eaten by whomever orders the food. Well who cares..

I had the Portebello Mushroom Benedict for brunch with my friend who came to visit me from Korea. This place is bomb! She wanted American food, and she got it when I brought her here. Now, she's hooked on the Bacon Waffles.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
I love coming here on the weekends!  I always say you vote with your dollar everyday and this is a place I come to frequently.  Everything I've ever had or that my friend's have had has always been amazing!  There's been a time here and there where I've gotten a somewhat over cooked poached egg but that happens.  Get the potatoes!  They come with roasted whole clove and shelled garlic = happy me!

Somethings to note:
- try to get there before 10:30 or it gets busy
- they have community tables which I think is awesome, I like the feeling of togetherness for meals
- it's really homey on the inside
- the service is really good
- local and seasonal ingredients :)
- lots of veggie options and they have a mean bacon waffle!
author: Christina C.

description:
I am giving Eats five stars because the food is delicious!   I have tried several dishes here and today had the vegetarian egg breakfast sandwich.  It was utterly scrumptious.  The kind of delicious that when you take your first bite, you can't wait to tell the person you are eating with how good it is.  And then need to slow yourself down to make sure you have the chance to savor every bite and prevent yourself from getting overly stuffed too quickly.  The breakfast potatoes are the best in the city.  Don't be afraid of the roasted garlic bulbs mixed in, they are mild and a perfect asset to the potatoes.     

All the other Yelp reviewers are correct, the wait can be very long and the service is spotty but it's worth it for the food.   I have waited just as long outside other breakfast establishments for food that doesn't hold a candle to that of Eats.  If you go with a party of two you are less likely to wait for an uncomfortably long time and if you aren't happy with the service, just be proactive and flag someone down.  The place is small so its hard to ignore the patrons.
author: Holly L.

description: Eh, I wasn't really a fan. I came here with my boyfriend and our dog and expected the food to be amazing, but my waffle bacon just ended up being mediocre.
author: Erika W.

description:
Small, homey feel. Friendly and attentive staff people. No waitin' on a weekday around 9! Too early? The coffee here will wake you right up. Zing!

Waffle Bacon ($11.50): The kind of breakfast that induces heart palpitations, but one may as well die happy with a full belly. The bacon is ironed into the waffle (awesome), smothered in cheddar cheese, sprinkled in peppers (slightly pickled), and has a sunny side up egg on top. Savory, sweet, sour deliciousness in every bite--IF you plan it that way. 

I have also heard good things about the Spinach and Roasted Mushroom Eggs Benny ($10.95). 

I say go big or go home and order the MYOM: comes with a whole bottle of sparkling wine & fresh squeezed juice. You do the rest.

Chorizo Polenta & Poached Eggs ($12.95): the combination of spicy chorizo, tomatoes, onions, corn polenta, queso fresco, and cilantro all just sound a lot better than they taste. Don't be surprised when it doesn't quite tickle your taste buds the way you had hoped.
author: Briana F.

description:
Hm... I'm not quite sure how I feel about this place anymore since they've changed it.  With the previous owners, the line used to be out the door, but nowadays, i don't see that too much.  After seeing interesting pictures from my friends about this place, I decided to give it a try.  

The decor of this place has definitely upgraded.  However, I cannot say the same about the food.  After looking at the menu, I have to say that there was almost nothing that I wanted to order from the menu.  It took me a really long time to decide, but I finally decided on something and it took a really long time to come.  The complimentary scones came in time because i was going to go crazy from starving.  Haha.  The cooks looked crazy busy behind the counters, but it felt like a really long time before the food came. =\.

When the food came, my egg tasted a little salty.  The salad was good though.  

I'm not sure if I'll come here again...
author: Tina L.

description: Very disappointing after seeing the constant lines. On a warm morning after just a few minutes wait (10 am Saturday) the hostess pointed us to the only two open seats, at the back counter, without asking if we wanted to wait for something less overheated. That would have been fine if the service and food were better. Different servers made the same mistake: bringing part of the meal w missing crucial ingredient (steamed milk for coffee, toast for eggs). And neither of our orders (spring scramble and BAT scramble) was all that. Next time I'm looking for brunch in my neighborhood I'm going back to Q. Eats is just popular because it's popular.
author: Robin W.

description:
I love their chicken and waffles.  It's ying and yang on a plate -- salty and sweet, crunchy and soft -- supreme happiness on a plate.  What more can you ask for.

Service is good.

Prices are fair.

Be prepared to wait if you come on a Saturday.

I have noticed that their portions have shrunk a bit -- not by a lot. I still can't finish the entire dish and always end up with a to-go box.
author: Tina C.

description: The service is HORRIBLE. You have to ask 3 different servers for a drink refill, because the first 2 will forget. They are over-worked, and inexperienced. Food is decent, but nothing special. Farmer's Scramble, Huevos Rancheros, and sandwiches are good. Skip the home fries. Go to Q Restaurant instead where the wait is shorter, the food better and service professional.
author: Monica B.

description: Good food, good service but a rude and arrogant owner/manager who most likely has a napoleonic complex ruins the mood its also way too expensive for the venue.
author: Sean B.

description:
So if you're reading this review, then you should you already have your name on the waiting list.  Get here early and you'll hopefully get a table.  Breakfast is great here, but the service is lacking a bit.  That being said expect good food, but frazzled service.
  We arrived early and you know its early when the ketchup is still a virgin.

What I ate:
Zoe's breakfast sandwich with the side of potatoes.
(Fantastic, expect to either eat it with a fork and knife or its going to be a little messy.  The potatoes were nice and crispy and seasoned just right.)

Decor: 3
Food:4
Service: 3 (They try)

Would I go back? You bet your pastrami! I would if the wait was short
author: Kelson H.

description: Only thing I don't like about this place is the wait during primetime.  But such is life.
author: Floyd B.

description:
One of my favorite neighborhood brunch spots! Eats manages to the combine everything you would want in a good, hearty breakfast and executes it in several different ways. There are scrambles, there are pancakes and waffles, there are traditional egg, bacon/sausage plates, and there are lunch (salad, sandwiches) options too. 

Everything I've tried here has been fantastic. I especially liked the spinach eggs benedict w/ parmesan sauce, the egg sandwich and the B.A.T. scramble (bacon + avocado). The other day I decided to try to something new and ordered the succotash polenta and it was soo good. It came with asparagus, corn, cherry tomatoes, basil and parmesan cheese sprinkled throughout topped off with 2 poached eggs. Definitely recommend trying this if you like polenta.

Oh and most importantly, make sure at least one person at your table gets a dish with their POTATOES. They make some of the best. Just don't mistake the big ass clove of garlic that it comes with as a potato or else yeah....gum mouthwash and toothpaste will maybe take some of the pain away...

Eats staff is super friendly and quick. There's usually a guaranteed line on weekends between 1030-1pm so plan accordingly. There is both bar seating and tables...I personally love sitting at the bar :)
author: Yee-Shing W.

description: Very delicious brunch place on Clement!  I love coming here because they give you latte's in huge bowls :)  Some of my favorite dishes are: Chicken and Waffles, hot cakes, spicy mango sausages, and the pancakes.  This place gets pretty packed so make sure you come here early.  The waiter's are always very friendly! Highly recommended.
author: Alister L.

description:
I like the food very much, the waffles is not soft and fluffy, they are more crispy. The flavors were really good, the sausage is a bit spicy but also really good. The portion fits me nicely, as you can order half size. My only concern is that the glass of water is dirty as well as the small jar of orange juice is definitely not clean... 
Other than that the food is really good, the service is really nice too, they are very friendly.
author: Kristin W.

description: I would brave the cold winds of the inner Richmond and the long line for the polenta succotash.  This is one of my favorite spots for brunch.  The polenta succotash is outstanding and so fresh - just perfect - and I also really like the oatmeal.  For a super busy diner, the service is pretty good.
author: Louise V.

description:
I've been going to Eats for the past few years. I'm glad that it doesn't have a 5 star rating. That means picky people on yelp will pass it by. Please do! But if you happen to come across this review, take away one thing. Eats is the best. 

We are talkin about Waffle "Bacon." bacon in a waffle, with eggs on top. delicious eatin savory or sweet with syrup drizzled over.
Spinach Mushroom Benedict - damn good benedict
scrambles are fresh greens and yummy things

Never took anyone here who didn't just love it.

It is rather small but they pack it in. Sometimes the service is not the best, but they are REALLY friendly people most of the time. If you have a problem with this place, get over yourself. It's good food at a good price, and will make most people smile.

Wait times are never over half an hour unless it's ridiculous. 

Coffee is strong and powerful (Beware ho much you drink, remember that coffee is indeed a strong purgative

No place is better for breakfast around the neighborhood that I know of. 
However, BSTAR is soooooooooooooo good. Secretly I like it better nowadays.
author: Matt K.

description: This place is cute and good. The decorations are very artsy. I order the banana chocolate chip pancakes and spinach feta Benedict, both  are delicious, tasty and satisfied my hungry tummy. I sat at   At the "bar" tops and saw the whole magic in the kitchen. One of the cooks used his dirty towel to bring the cooked sausage to the plate. It was unsanitary. I was disappointed since then.
author: Regina Rose S.

description: I was very happy with my experience here! We went today (a Thursday morning) so yay no wait! We were seated immediately. I ended up getting Zoe's egg & bacon sandwich which was super yummy! It came on ciabatta bread, but it was supper runny in terms of the egg on it. (which I like but i know a lot of people don't). The potatoes that come with are yummy, but a bit flavorless without ketchup. I mean, I love garlic as much as the next person and it seriously could have used a little more. I also got the grapefruit mimosa in the big vase thing. It was 16$ and the grapefruit was a nice change in comparison to a traditional mimosa. The waiter said that it would be about 4 normal mimosas if you get the bigger thing so I did but realistically it was about 3 so meh. Nonetheless, I was happy about my choice! The food came from the kitchen super fast (probably because there was literally like 4 other people here) and everything was overall great. Our waiter was super nice and humorous in helping us decide what to get. My friend that was with me got a half of a portion of a berries and cream waffle and a side of sausage and loved it! But said that the waffle was very small for the money! The only issue that I had was the fact that they sent us the check about a half an hour before I was even halfway done with my sandwich. It's not like they had a line so I"m not sure why they were trying to get us out so fast. Anyway, it was an overall good experience and I will be back! I just love brunch and they do it well!
author: Madi N.

description:
Eats is my neighborhood go-to joint for weekend brunch. Don't let the 15-20 minute wait deter you from coming here-- besides, if there's a wait, that means it's good, right?

I've tried a ton of things on their menu, but I can whole-heartedly say that the cheesy potatoes and eggs are the best thing on the menu. The name is pretty self-explanatory, but it also comes with pico de gallo salsa (I generally abstain from pico de gallo because it usually lacks spice, but the fresh tomatoes, lime, and cilantro really give the meal that extra kick). The fried egg sandwich is just as delicious, as are the bacon waffles. 

Be sure to grab a Detox juice, too. You can never go wrong with a juice that has beets and carrots!
author: Jerome C.

description: The food here was really good- amazing Benedict with spinach and mushrooms and the hollandaise sauce isn't too heavy- but it doesn't matter if the food is good when the service is bad. I would suggest making sure you sit at a table not the counter because we watched people who were seated wayyyy after us get served their coffee before we did. We finally went and poured our coffee for ourselves and when I informed them they didn't really seem to care. Too bad cause otherwise I'd recommend this place for sure.
author: Kaitlin M.

description: Awesome.  Despite being full from my order of waffles, I ordered another serving.  The french toast was great too.  We did not have to wait too long but it would have been worth it to wait 30 min or so.
author: Jackie K.

description: The food here is consistently delicious. I recommend the spicy sausage polenta - a wonderful stew of flavors with a creamy polenta base and delicious split sausage. The coffee is excellent and I've never had to wait more than 20 minutes to get a table, even on the weekends. Sometimes gets a bit noisy, but that's just because it's full for breakfast and brunch. In my opinion the savory dishes are preferable to the sweet ones.
author: Rita C.

description:
Good EATS!

Oh SF brunch places, how I secretly hate you all.  Why?  Because you make me get up at 9am or earlier just so I can make my way in without having to wait for 2 hours for eggs!

With that being said, I won't wait forever... BUT I will definitely pop back in around 9:30am on a Sunday again to do brunch at Eats.

As soon as they put my name on the list, a table opened and our little party of three got a table.  Coffee came quick (milk was a little slower to follow), but I have literally never gotten my food so quickly at a breakfast joint!  They are ready to turn your table!  :)

Even so, the food was DELICIOUS!  I was lured by the chicken sausage, poached egg and polenta dish and was not disappointed!  It was rich and savory and a lot spicier than I expected.  TASTY!!!!!  My hubby's bacon and fried egg sandwich was MASSIVE.  The juices were tasty.  Overall, this place was great!

DEFINITELY CHECK IT OUT IF YOU COME EARLY AND AVOID THE CRAZY WAIT!
author: Christine K.

description:
This cute little neighborhood nook really knows how to dish out yummy, fresh, large portioned breakfasts. 
But the true reason for five stars is.... the orange juice. Seriously. 
As a kid, we had an orange tree and mom would make fresh OJ for breakfast. In ten years or so, I have endlessly sought OJ that would satiate my youthful nostalgia. Lo and behold it has been found at Eats. Needless to say, best mimosas ever.
author: Cassie C.

description: Food is dang good, but wait is often ridiculous.  Get here early (8:30am or before) or be prepared to wait for 30-45 minutes.  Breakfast/brunch is one meal I can't stand waiting for.
author: Scott L.

description:
So I'm on a Clement kick (probably because I live a block away) and I can't get enough of Eats.

5 Stars for being awesome and fresh; make your own mamosas; and my meat eater friends say the breakfast sandwich is literally the best sandwich they've ever had.

-1 Star for only having 2 Vegan options on the menu (yes, I know 2 is alot for most places but I encourage you to explore your other possible options Eats!)

I usually get the Tofu Scramble or the Open-Face Veggie Pita.  Both are fresh and amazing.  

Be prepared to wait.  Its a GREAT brunch spot but everyone one knows that and there's usually a line outside.

If you don't want to wait, B*Star is on the next block and has the same owners.  The food is a little different (ex. - tofu scramble is the same but it also features lots of typically asian veggies).  B*Star is equally delicious but like I said slightly different.  They have more seating and an out door patio area so there's usually less of an issue with waiting.

I totally recommend trying both!
author: Christopher R.

description:
I love Eats and at this point i have been there probably two-dozen times. I live only a half-block away so it's very convenient. The food is fantastic, overall. The BAT scramble and huevos rancheros are especially tasty. MYOM is fun and a good value for a group of friends. Their bacon is just the right combination of thick cut and crispy.

However, I do have one complaint, and it's regarding the waffles. They taste awesome, don't get me wrong. They're fluffy and crispy at the same time and the syrup and butter soak in a bit and i put an overeasy egg on top and gobble that shit down. The problem is the size/cost of the waffles. They are roughly 3 or 4 inches on a side. This isn't a full diner waffle. This is a quarter of one. And the breakfast "suite" only includes ONE of them. And each additional waffle costs $3.75. Yes, $3.75 for a waffle 3 and a half inches on a side. It's pretty outrageous, but they're so good I can't help but order them. They should give you two waffles for that price, at the VERY LEAST.

otherwise from that it's a great place to eat a nice brunch.
author: Will G.

description:
My mom comes here all the time and always brings home her second half of her brunch, which I get to eat!  Even though I eat it hours later, it's still SO good.  She always orders an omelet with avocados and spinach with their house potatoes.

I came here with the dude for brunch on a sunny Saturday and I wanted to sit outside to soak in the rays.  He ordered a Cobb salad and I ordered a small order of waffles with berries and we both had coffee.  Coffee was good, strong and not very acidic, just the way I like.  My waffle with berries were delicious-cripsy on the outside, tender on the inside with just the right amount of berries and whipped cream sitting on top.  

We didn't have to wait very long to be seated and didn't have to wait very long for someone to take our order.  Good food, good service.  Now I know why my mom comes here all the time!
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
No one gets their own table. Feels very unorganized.

I got an omelette. Was a little bland. Side potatoes looked good but over cooked. Felt like I was biting into a rock for some pieces.
author: Elton H.

description: Absolutely awful service. Waited 1 hour to be seated with plenty of tables available, took 15 min for anyone to take our order. We waited 45 minutes just to find out our order was never placed. Currently very hungry and unhappy. Food is good but not worth the horrible service. Do not come here unless you are prepared to wait a VERY long time. Possibly forever.
author: Megan H.

description: Buttermilk pancakes were on point -- disappointing that they didn't have a significant accompaniment option. Could so easily be improved!
author: Milly B.

description: Cute place, on the small side. It's very crowded for Sunday brunch, so be prepared for a wait. Service was efficient and pleasant. Food was fine--really pretty standard breakfast fare. Has a nice neighborhood vibe.
author: Joanna S.

description: Did not have to wait too long. Coffee was nice and strong. Had a scramble and added ham extra $3.95 (expensive). So scrabble, coffee, and xtra ham costed me over $20. I think that's kinda expensive for breakfast. Yikes! I'm a fan but i better get something simpler next time.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Good food, healthy choices, very friendly servers and a pretty cool overall vibe for a breakfast place.

Only complaint was that it is a bit cramped at times and it can be a bit pricey depending on what you order.
author: Zack E.

description:
OK, totally better experience this time. Came today after getting disappointed that Q was closed! For what, Good Friday? Seriously? People need to eat on Good Friday too!

Went in around 11, seated right away, drinks ordered and brought right away. Our waitress was super friendly, totally accommodating to our numerous requests and substitutions, love that  "Yes we can!" attitude! 

We started out with the salmon platter with toastettes, mmmmm, best salmon ever.

I ordered the poached eggs italia... poached eggs with a spicy tomatoe sauce, crispy prosciutto, broccolini, red papers, so tasty!

The bf had fried chicken sandwich, wow, the fries that came with his meal, were soooooo goood! Now for the sandwich, was pretty good, however, if they combined the fried chicken with their mushroom gravy into a sandwich, now THAT would be a total winner!

All in all though, much better this time around.
author: Pauline T.

description:
The new owner (same peeps that runs Burma Superstar) has turned this place around.  Top 5 breakfast/brunch spot in San Francisco.

Must Order:
Spicy Tomato Skillet
author: Tina N.

description: Always wanted to try EATS. It is walking distance from my place. I was doing some grocery shopping @ the new farmers market held every Sunday in the Richmond district between 2nd and 5th Avenue. I was walking through it and decided to have brunch at Eats. There was about a 25-minute wait. The weather was gorgeous so I opted to sit outside and get some sun. I had a hard time contemplating on what to order. Logged onto yelp and looked at the pictures. Ordered the Chicken & Waffles for the gf and i got the  and the Spicy Tomato Skillet The waffle was nice and crispy. I would definitely come back to try the other items on the menu.
author: Christopher L.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised with my trip to Eats.  I've walked past this place many times, but it really looks like a dive from the outside.  I went here because with my parents because it was the only place open at the crack of dawn which is when they 
like to eat.

I had the chicken and waffles and that was delicious.  My dad had a waffle with fruit that looked really good. 

A neighbor table had some banana chocolate chip pancakes and i'm totally ordering them next time.  I also noticed that they
have the make your own Mimosa thing.  I think you choose the juice you want to go with your bubbly and mix it yourself.  

Overall i would say that Eats is small dining San Francisco style.  It really has great food at a good price.
author: Mike Y.

description:
Hate to do it, and honestly, probably an unfair one star, as the food didn't make anyone ill and the employees seemed well meaning in general.
But please, train your staff.  
Late breakfast on a weekday, which means cooks outnumbered customers.  Ordered, sat, watched another couple come in, order, eat, put money on table.  I finally asked "Soon?"  Yes, they are putting it together now.  My food came out, in 3 minutes my companions food came out.  I said "Is there something we ordered wrong, was the waffle iron turned off?"  "No, we are just training a new cook."  

My "waffle suite" had more plate showing than an entree from any upscale restaurant in the city.  The waffle was one square of what is normally considered a waffle, included one small sausage, and two eggs.  All tasted fine, but damn.  

When I paid I said I don't normally complain, but I wouldn't be averse to you picking up one of these breakfasts.  We waited way too long.  

"Well, we are training a cook, and pancakes can take 7-8 minutes."

"Yes, but we waited 30-40 minutes for our food."  And that was that. 

So, again, train your cooks on your time, not mine.  When you do make someone wait for an extraordinary time, don't serve food to one person and let the other diner stare hungrily at the food while it cools on the plate.  And awknowledge the screw up in some way...I personally would probably have comped the meal, but in this case if they'd bought one breakfast I'd have been happy.  That way we still would have subsidized their training program, but not at full price.  Seems fair enough, right?
author: Kean S.

description:
We were visiting friends who live within walking distance to Eats. Our friend who lived in the hood never had been and said she wanted to try based on the Yelp reviews. We decided to take a walk and have a nice breakfast before we had to drive to Los Angeles.  We had 7 of us and were told it would take about 15-20 minutes.  After a 50 minute wait we were finally seated!

The place is small but the staff was very nice.  We ordered and after 10 minutes we finally got our drinks because we asked where they were.  Our food came and it was pretty good but not great.  We had to ask several times for refills, condiments etc.  The service was abysmal!

We got pancakes for our 3 kids and they only brought about a tablespoon of syrup.  We needed more and asked for a bit more which they brought after several minutes.  When I looked at my bill they charged us $2.25 for the extra syrup!  I have never been at a restaurant in my life where they charge for syrup.  If you are going to charge at least inform the customer and let them decide. 

Also, we had 7 people which 4 were kids and they assessed the 18% gratuity on our tab which is customary if they are adults not kids.

The place is a rip off!  Our bill was $124.56 for breakfast!
author: Laura T.

description:
I came here for a birthday breakfast with my friend.

I ordered the Chicken and Waffles. The chicken was breaded in Panko and the inside was moist and not dry. It was not oily. It came with syrup for the waffles and and gravy. This may not be the authentic Chicken and Waffles but they have a good twist on a classic.  

The atmosphere is casual. 

There maybe a wait depending on when you go.

I would recommend you try this dish because you will come out of Eats satisfied and happy.
author: Irene L.

description:
This is a great place for breakfast or brunch. The servers are really friendly and the whole atmosphere is very cozy. 

I recommend the huevos rancheros, but it seems that basically everything on the menu is good, in its own right. 

The only reason this place is four stars instead of five is that the mimosas struck me as being a little pricey, considering the size served. Maybe its a price-point thing and they need to be that expensive to pull a profit? I'm not too savvy on how expensive blood oranges are.
author: Taylor S.

description:
Pretty good basic food.  Pretty normal SF thing of better ingredients and add some spices to diner fare.
Prices were slightly high for what you get (even for sf).  Prices were the same as what I would consider a high-end breakfast such as the nearby Ellas vs. the diner category where I would put Eats.
The other negative is much of my grading for breakfast places is how they refill your coffee and here it was very sub par.  Cup sat empty for most of the meal.  The one refill was only half a cup.  It appeared to be on purpose and the waiter couldn't seemed to hear me when I asked for a full cup.
author: Ric S.

description:
So I have now eaten at the "New Eats" four times. By far, the best thing I've had is the chicken and waffles. It is definitely more brunchy, than breakfasty, but savory can be good and the crunchy fried chicken with the mushroom sauce is a good start to any weekend day.

My biggest issue is this - you change the owners, you change the menu, you change the staff, you change the decor, YOU KEEP THE NAME????? That just seems like a bait and switch to me. And after everything, I could accept all of that if the ricotta pancakes were still on the menu, but they are not. So now Eats is just another overpriced breakfast place like all the others on Clement and not the Eats I came to know and love when I first moved to the city. It used to be a place where out of town guests would make sure we visited and old roommates would make a cross town trek just for brunch. But now its just another brunch place, nothing special, nothing worth going out of your way for. 

Don't get me wrong, I will still eat there, but only because its less than a block from my house. Eats is no longer a destination restaurant, and that makes me sad.
author: Brenda K.

description: My coworkers and I grabbed Eats the other day. I chose the fried chicken sandwich. Yes, it was my first time. Absolutely, I want more. Really enjoyed the portions and how tasty this was. I got the sandwich, a side, and a freshly squeezed OJ for under $20.
author: Richard K.

description:
I love this place because it is so close to my house. I usually come here with some friends who also live close for mimosas and breakfast. I love the eggs florentine with spinach and mushrooms. The spicy tomato skillet is also amazing. It has kale, potatoes, and veggies in a yummy spicy tomato sauce with fried eggs on top. I'm drooling thinking about it right now. They have plenty of fresh juices available, my personal favorite is the detox one. 

Overall, the only downside of this place is the wait. Typically there is about a 30 min to hour wait. So as long as it is sunny outside, I don't mind waiting.
author: Talia M.

description: Eats is one of the best breakfast cafe's ever... My bestfriend and I go here often and order the dance thing everytime. Eggs Benedict. And because they are dog friendly, my dog comes with us everytime. This is a greatvplace to go and chat with friend and eat amazing food:)
author: Lauren H.

description:
Haven't had a 5 star experience in some time, so I'm very excited I had one today!!

Always been scared of the wait at Eats, apparently the rush is before 11:30 on the weekends, so we scored our cozy table after a short 15-20 minute wait. My only real complaint came during the waiting period, I was hoping for a cup of Joe to sip while I waited for my much anticipated breakfast-I was disappointment when the explanation was that the coffee machine could not accommodate in house guests and outside waits. All was good when we got our table as my coffee was literally waiting for me before I sat down :)

The thing I liked most about this place was the waffles-light, airy, crispy/crunchy crust on the outside and melt in your mouth on the inside. Just totally perfect-especially with whipped cream and berries. I'm so so sad I didn't get more than one! My counterparts both got the same dish-the Caprese salad which included: arugula, fresh mozzarella, eggplant and pesto sauce. I had a bite, delicious!! Also, the dudes in the kitchen know how to make over-medium eggs at Eats, you'd be surprised how many cooks don't know how to cook eggs in this city.

One of the best parts of this place are the portions. At a nearby restaurant, which I wont name but starts with the letter Q, one receives massive portions without real quality. Eats is the opposite, they serve up fresh ingredients they dont weigh you down the rest of the day because they don't serve you 3 lbs of greasy/salty food on your plate-they also freshly squeezed juices like the 'detox (beets, carrot, ginger, orange). YUM!

Expect a wait most of the time-but you can put your name down, walk down to the Blue Danube for an amazing latte and come back to a yummy breakfast. Very recommended and they can easily accommodate larger groups (6-8)  in a small space!
author: nina B.

description: Their waffle bacon and egg sandwich are SO good! And they have this toast w jam and goat cheese that I highly recommend as well. As for waiting, it takes awhile to get a table especially w more than 3 people bc its a small place but worth the wait
author: Erika P.

description:
The best american breakfast place in clement! (be ready for a long line, and crampped eating space. but hey, if you live in SF you're probably used to that).

Hands down the best banana chocolate chip pancakes I've tasted in a loooong time! just heavenly.
author: Libby K.

description:
Food pricing is decent. Although the 75 cent difference between half a slice more ($5 half...$5.75 full) for the fancy toast seems awkward to me. Food taste was good. 

Waitstaff: went on a sunday morning, place was full. Looked like the wait staff was consistently running around trying to help people out. Party of 6 waited, took approximately 50 minutes to get our food (we saw two parties come and go before we got ours) so our party naturally was upset. When the time for the bill came by, one of our members wanted compensation for the meal due to the long wait time. After a short discussion with the manager we ended up getting a small compensation 

I thought the manager and the waitress handled the situation appropriately and despite the stressful surroundings of a full restaurant and their computer system malfunctioning. Both the waitress were professional and courteous when they took the time to explain the situation.

TL;DR: Staff professional, food's good, food pricing weird. Go on a weekday
author: Matthew W.

description:
Best breakfast food in town! 

I was annoyed at first when the couple who use to own eats put a sign in their window that read, "be back in a month"...only they never were back and someone else purchased the joint. BUT to my surprise the new owners made it a thousand times better! The menu reminds me of NYC food and it's just really good. I wish they would add to it a bit, going there so much the menu tends to shrink in size. 

When they first opened they must have had a different chef or maybe testing out the place, but their menu was different and they had this great smoked salmon omelet with bri and dill. It was simple and just great. Well, since that first menu they amped up the salmon omelet and added creamed instead of bri, they put in capers and tomatoes. It's still great, but i miss the bri! 

It's a tiny place so it can be awkward if your not in the mood to wait for an hour for a table and rub elbows with your neighbor. The interior design is great, I love the beach wood and the tables/bar throughout. Very modern and chic. I was glad to see they took out the mushy carpet the old owners use to have...Whatever happened to that couple?
author: danielle w.

description: This place is an excellent choice for a Breakfast Spot in the Inner Richmond District! I highly recommend the Chorizo Scrabble, it is Delicious!
author: Avery J.

description:
More of a 3.5 than 3, but the service was a deciding factor in giving it 3 stars. Came here with a group of 5 and had to wait about 40-55 mins, which isn't TOO bad considering it was sunday around 11:30ish and we didn't really have a small group. We got the eggs benedict, bacon & egg sandwich, and chicken and waffles and I got the polenta with chorizo. Everything was REALLY good except for my polenta and chorizo... I should have known because it wasn't a "typical" breakfast meal and polenta was lukewarm and sort of coagulated which wasn't that great. Also, the onions with the chorizo weren't cooked as much as I liked. Also, the chicken and waffles was good but its not your "typical" fried chicken and I think I prefer House of fried chicken and roscoe's fried chicken more.

Also, service was not great. They seemed super overwhelmed with the customers and we didn't get our water until AFTER we got our meal. It also took about 10-15 mins to get our order in.

All in all, solid brunch place.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Lovely ambiance, nice employees and delicious food!  It's a nice neighborhood place to eat!
author: JL B.

description:
Eats is amazing because...

It specializes in breakfast, MY FAVORITE MEAL OF THE DAY, and it can be really difficult to find a good breakfast spot in the city, ESPECIALLY in the Richmond.

Furthermore, all of the breakfast favorites are executed perfectly; pancakes, waffles, french toast, omelets, strong coffee, various flavors of Mimosas, a fabulous sandwich....everything!!!! 

God I love this place.  Just avoid the Sunday chaos for a better experience.
author: Bret O.

description:
Eats had me at 'bacon waffle.' Excuse me? Did I read correctly? You have BACON in a waffle?

Yes and yes. The universe's two most perfect foods, together at last in one savory piece of dough.

I really don't think I need to say anything else.
author: Genevieve W.

description: I had the spinach and portobello Benedict. It was bomb diggity, gotta eat it up. The flavors were way on point! The portobello was so succulent, the sauce complimented the flavors very well. So groood! I had a side salad and it was so light and delicious! I really truly enjoyed my meal. It was too pricey for me but a dollar or two less would've been just right. Goldie locks style. Mmmm... I still have the memories.
author: Jakob R.

description: The food was good, and the service was excellent, that's not what gives eats 5 stars. If you treat my dog right, i'll give you five stars. The gentlemen serving us was so nice to my dog, and brought out a water bowl. I'd go back.
author: Ben Z.

description:
Came here during the week (yay, no wait!) and had me some awesome breakfast. I'm a sweet and savory gal when it comes to breakfast...so I had to go with chicken and waffles! 

Be forewarned, It's different from your typical C&W, it was breaded chicken breast as opposed to the wings or thighs. All in all, still good, but I guess can be disappointing for someone who likes dark meat. 

Their waffles are mmm mm good! I like Belgian type waffles with the big squares, none of that small stuff you can make at home. They were crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside. Their berries and waffles were just as good, very sweet strawberries!

Had to get a side of potatoes too, coz I heart garlic. They didn't disapoint in flavor-- though some of the tots were too roasted. It was dry, hard and unappealing to eat. 

They only came to refill our coffee once...booo. I need my caffeine.

Overall, very accomodating and their portions are pretty decent, esp the eggs. They have a few items you can mix and match, or get half orders of, for those that want to try a bit of everything. 

So much more I want to try on the menu...def need to come back :)
author: Ly T.

description:
What an awesome way to end my first official running event! I finished the Kaiser 5K in Golden Gate Park and came here with friends (M, T, and C) for post-race grub! 

Quaint and clean dining area, and efficient and friendly service. 
You order by # here, and I had the #11 (egg scramble with ham, mushrooms, which came with country potatoes and toast.) Country potatoes  were perfectly seasoned, and toast was my fav, sourdough (appeared to be a sliced mini baguette with an end pieces --yay!). Scramble was great and tasty, with perfect amounts of ham and mushrooms. It was relatively healthy since I requested egg whites! Coffee was strong, and refills kept on coming.
I inhaled my meal, and maybe left a few potatoes on the plate! I had to carb up after running, right?!

In the middle of our brunch, our friends told us that they just got engaged. M and I shrieked and squealed with glee, which startled the other patrons (sorry about that). I couldn't be happier for C and T!! I was one of the first to know, and what an honor!

Anyway, this is a great spot for brunch and where locals like to hang. Wish I would've discovered this place sooner when I lived in the 'hood'!
author: Gill C.

description: This place is always busy on the weekend so my gf and I decided to give it a try. I must say, we were a little disappointed. The service was lacking friendliness and the food was good but certainly nothing great. Considering this is one of the only breakfast places in the area I might give them a second try, but my hopes arent set too hight
author: Tyler L.

description:
Scratch the Spanish Scramble.......I didn't care for it the last time I ordered it. And Eats changed the menu, so the potatoes aren't mixed in anymore.

BUT.......I have a new fave, which even boosted the star rating! 

The B.A.T. (bacon, avocado, tomato)  Scrambled Eggs - egg whites of course - is ridiculous! I was so full but wanted to keep eating because it is SO.DANG.GOOOOD!!!! A definite must.....
author: Gina G.

description: So the lady friend and I kept hearing we need to go to Mama's, but each time we called it was a 90-120 minute wait.  Nope, don't care how good it is.  So we jumped on yelp (your welcome for the free plug yelp!) and looked for a breakfast place.  Eats?  Why not?  The waiting for the table, or 'putting your name in' was an interesting process, you simply write your name on a board.  Ok.  So after not too long a wait we get in and order a make your own mimosa!  How did they know we were coming?  We love mimosas.  So they give you a bottle of champagne and what ever juice you want.  Yay!  It's 10 am and I'm drunk.  Thanks Eats!  Oh and your food was good too!
author: Pedro L.

description:
Didn't have to wait too long on a Sunday Morning.  Wonderful seats at the bar, good view of the action packed Kitchen.  Delightful decor, and well rounded menu; standards and some new school twists like the Waffle bacon which was decadently delicious. 

Perfect for what I was interested in - I will return for a visit during the week as I live in this 'hood.

Thanks Eats!
author: Artnok A.

description:
My weird friend Ryan. Sometimes I wonder about how his mind works.

"It's the weekend. You wanna get a table early? Might be crowded."

"No, Saturdays are usually OK, but Sunday's are bad. Besides, there's a high turnover."

Hmm. Not sure about the logic behind that one.

He got there 10 minutes before I did, and we still ended up waiting over half an hour.

But was it worth it?

At $16 a head, it was alright. I got the spicy winter tomato skillet. On the plate it looked delicious. The first few bites were also awesome. But towards the end, it did leave my palate with an out-of-the-can kinda taste. I also ordered a side of pepper chicken sausage. No complaints there.

So, a luke warm review. The menu did look pretty awesome, especially some of the sweet brunch dishes, so I'm more than willing to give Eats another chance at winning my heart.

And when I say heart, I really mean stomach.
author: Tony L.

description:
checking and taking this place off my list. was excited to finally try but did not deliver. cute spot, nice staff/good service but the food leaves a lot to be desired. 

got the waffles and bacon with sunny side up eggs. one fatty slab of bacon baked into the waffle. waffle was smothered in too much cheese with tart roasted red peppers on it - definitely threw off the flavor. the eggs were super runny with some of the egg white still clear; a food no, no. 

husband had pulled port hash with the same eggs. fortunately he asked for his over medium so they were cooked nicely. flavors good in the dish but a bit too soupy for a hash. 

almost $40 with tip for this disappointing meal. if you decide to give it a shot then pick your dish carefully. sorry, eats, but we really had high hopes for a great brunch spot in the hood.
author: Cara G.

description:
Summary: A great place for a simple and filling breakfast with quality
ingredients and a friendly staff, if you have the time.

Eats is not fancy; no fine china, white table cloths or suit-wearing
servers and you should leave your pearls at home.  The charm is in its
ability to deliver an amazing breakfast experience without the extras.
 At Eats you will get quality ingredients, a flexible menu and leave
with a full stomach...what else can you ask for?

First timers should try one the various "scrambles", a signature dish
if I had to choose.  Opt for the breakfast potatoes instead of
switching to fruit or salad, the fresh roasted garlic that accompanies
them are worth the extra calories.  If you get toast, make sure you
try the jam, another Eats highlight.  Finish the meal with a side of a
single waffle square or pancake, it just feels right.

The one downside to Eats is the meaningful wait on the weekend.
Parties of two can usually get seated in 30 minutes or less, but
groups of 3+ can expect 30-60 minutes.  While no wait is fun, Eats
helps keep you warm and awake by offering coffee to the guests waiting
outside...a nice little extra.

Give it a try...and let me know how it goes!
author: Ryan F.

description:
i'm so sad to be writing this right now. eats was one of the first places that i discovered in SF to have great breakfast, and i LOVE my breakfast. back then it was run by a middle-aged Chinese couple and it was just wonderful. food was always hot, service was fast and orders always accurate (i never saw the waitress hold a pad or pen once), just the best really. and now i hate to report that since the change in ownership, i'm always a little disappointed. yes, the food is still good but some times the breakfast potatoes taste like they were cooked a few hours ago and one time the poached eggs were WAY overcooked. 

secondly, the service as of late hasn't really been up to my standards. yes, maybe i'm biased, working in the industry myself, but really my standards are pretty reasonable. and while none of my visits have ever really been royally fucked by the service, i just was never impressed.

anyway, the point is, i'll probably still go there every once in a while because i do still enjoy the food and it's cute and comfortable and "trendy" or whatever, but deep down in my heart, i miss the old eats.
author: Georgia W.

description:
Enjoyed a bowl of delicious granola, yogurt, and fruit yesterday morning with a hot cup of coiffee outside in the sunshine. (That reminds me...not to be a princess but, while it is nice to sit outside in the warm sun, it does start to be a pain in the ass when you can't look at the person you are eating with because it's so bright. Ah well...white people problems.) It was also fairly easy to get a table after we realized we needed to write our names on the board outside, haha!
I really enjoyed my breakfast. I've never had granola and yogurt at a place that adds sliced dates and shredded coconut, oh my! So good. It was pricey (~$7) but damn good. 
We will be back (to steal coffee mugs). I mean, to try the bacon waffles.
author: Leigh W.

description:
Great for having breakfast in small groups. Delicious food, friendly staff. Put your name on the waiting list and be ready to wait about 30 minutes on a sunday or holiday. 

Bigger groups wait longer and they're not really equipped for parties of more than 4 people.
author: Tim S.

description:
I really want to like this place since it replaced my absolute favorite breakfast/brunch spot in the Richmond, the former and original Eats... but I just can't like it that much. Three stars (though still borderline two stars) for its fresh-tasting ingredients, fresh juices, and the Farmer's scrambled eggs.. Minus two just because the concept of all the dishes on the menu sound delicious in theory, yet somehow it feels like each dish is missing something that binds the dish or it has a flavor that overpowers the rest. I really don't know how to explain it.  For examples, Chicken and Waffles with a little of an asian twist in this case sounds delicious... but that rich gravy flavor is in lack, chicken not as moist or crispy as desired, and waffles are whatever. I've also had the smoked salmon salad which is decent... but the dressing has too much dill? or not enough salt? or something. Idk each dish I try leaves me disappointed.

I only come here because it is one of the few American breakfast/brunch spots in the Richmond and my whole family lives here so it's one of the meet-up places. Yet, each time I'm still not convinced this place is THAT great. I'm not saying this place is terrible, I know a lot of people like it and that explains the usual wait. I would just say: go in expecting a decent breakfast/brunch for prices on the steeper side of the mountain but nothing that will change your world. If you're not in the neighborhood and you are looking for an awesome new breakfast/brunch place, don't trouble coming over here. I'd rather leave the Rich to find better place... and i LOVE the Rich.

P.S. I was (and still am) heartbroken when the original Eats was taken over by the new owners a couple/few years ago. The original Eats had with the biggest yummiest omelettes and the BEST ricotta pancakes, waaaaaay better than Plow and Park Chow. If anyone knows where the previous owners went or if they have a new restaurant, please let me know. Shoot, even if you know where they live so I can knock on the door and beg for a batch of ricotta pancakes.
author: Rachelle F.

description: Definitely wouldn't come as often as I do if I didn't live directly across the street. The food is good but extremely overpriced.  I never wait and only come during weekday off hours for a late lunch. The staff is slow to take my order and slow to bring me my check. That is all.
author: Rachel E.

description: The menu sounds better than the food tastes. This place has a lot of potential and the ingredients sound amazing, but the food just doesn't deliver. Good ambience though...
author: Neil S.

description: Tri-tip burrito is a winner! I'll be back for it for sure. Also love the beer of the day.
author: John B.

description: Try the chicken and waffles. Really good! The service was friendly and welcoming. The only thing that bothered me was that the place is TOO small for my liking and we were seated after someone who came in after us.
author: Yvette Z.

description: Great food, great service. Went two days in a row it was so good... The only problem is the wait.. It is worth the wait..
author: William M.

description:
I use to frequent Eats before it was taken over by the Burma Superstar family. I loved the old menu. The new menu is just okay. It sounds delicious but the dishes I have tried were not mouth-watering by any means. They were just okay. The interior is definitely better designed than before, but I would take the shabby old decor with the old menu anyday.

The Spicy Tomato Skillet sounded amazing, but it was too saucy. I think it should have been reduced and sprinkled with a handful of cheese. I actually took half of it home. Later, I reheated it with cheese and ate it with tortilla chips - way better. It made the sauce thicker while balancing out the jalapeno's in it and giving it an extra texture from the crunch of the chips. The grilled bread was awesome though. Maybe using the grilled bread, spread over some whole grain dijon mustard, topped with thinly sliced avocado, lettuce, and topped with a medium over egg

The Spanish Omelette sounded amazing also. However, it was pretty bland. It probably would taste more thrilling with some red onions, way more garlic, perhaps some curry powder and/or chili powder, and some cherry tomato and/or avocado added.

Entering the place, the staff was very efficient in seating and serving water. However not so great in checking up on more water or refills for coffee or lemonade.
author: nightlife i.

description:
Growing up in SF, Eats has been around for as long as I can remember! It truly is a cozy, comfy, and dependable breakfast and lunch place! Unlike Lucky Penny, everything at Eats has a "homemade" flavor to it, which accounts for their limited but tasty menu. 
The atmosphere here is relaxing and the crowd is pretty friendly with lots of regulars who frequent the place.

The sandwiches are always fresh and they deliver solid egg dishes with crispy and flavorful home fries. Here you can find pancakes that taste like they were made from scratch and tuna melts the way Mom used to make. Eats seems to stick with what they do best and does not try to overextend their menu. The service is pleasant and we have never felt "rushed" here. Quite simply put, Eats is a chill place to get a good honest meal at affordable prices!
author: Richard T.

description: French toast and egg sandwich are off the chain! Cozy space. Loved it.
author: Nina K.

description: Eats is a great little neighborhood breakfast spot! It's not mind blowing, but it's consistently very good and I've never left disappointed. I love the spicy sausage over polenta... mmm! The one thing you absolutely have to get here though is the detox juice. Man oh man is it good, and so good for you!
author: Lauren B.

description:
Dined here today for the first time! I had the fried bacon and egg sandwich. It was pretty good, but unfortunately was slathered in a very spicy sauce that totally overpowered it. I had seen the spicy sauce in the description, but I didn't realize that it would be absolutely DRENCHED in it! They should do one side of the bread in a thin layer of spicy sauce, and the other side in mayo to cool it down. That would have been better.

My companions ordered the huevos rancheros. It looked absolutely delicious! I'm definitely gonna go for that next time. And I will also be sure to get their mimosa deal. $20 for a bottle of champagne and a pitcher of juice! Can't beat it.

Although this was a 3 star experience for me, I can't wait to go back and order the 'right' things. Then I think it could easily be a four or fiver.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Enjoyable place for breakfast, brunch, or lunch.  The specialties are chicken and waffles and waffle bacon and magnificent freshly squeezed orange juice.  Interesting menu with many options for breakfasts, omelets, sandwiches, and salads.  About a third of the menu is devoted to vegetarian items.

While the food is excellent, the restaurant isn't very comfortable.  Seating is cramped and service is somewhat shaky and slow.   Servers are friendly but they tend to be way more friendly to their regulars and somewhat forgetful about the rest of us.  The staff treated the regulars so well that I felt like an intruder to the place.  If Eats wants me to become a regular, they need to treat me well in a timely fashion, also.   The service aspect of Eats is the one thing keeping it from achieving the five star rating.  While there are more items on the menu that I would like to try, I don't feel obliged to put up with the ambience or the attitude.
author: Re-pley Z.

description:
Honest, well prepared, and presented food.

I only come during the weekdays usually round 1 so lines are not a problem for this guy.  Love the house squeezed juices-the detox is great!

Will keep returning to this place.
author: frizzle-fry e.

description: Good fancy toast. Long wait and tight quarters.
author: Chelsea F.

description:
I had heard briefly about this place a couple months ago but it somehow  slipped into the back of my mind, and it stayed there until my friend suggested to grab lunch here, at Eats. I must say, what a superb place to grab breakfast/brunch/lunch! It was such a delight, partly because the sun was shining with a slight cool California breeze. The staff is super nice and although they were busy, they still managed to check up on me and offered me coffee for the wait. After reading over their menu for what seemed like an hour, i finally made a decision and got the (i hope i'm saying the right title!!) Farmer's Scrambled Eggs (vegan). It had so many delicious veggies in it that i just had to try it. The goat cheese on top made it that much more better!!! 

I can't wait to come back and try the breakfast plates and their amazingly sounding pancakes.
author: Suzan L.

description:
It's hard to eat here without making comparisons to the old Eats.  The old Eats had kitschy charm and a very unique menu.  You felt like you were in a neighbor's home eating American breakfast food with an Asian twist (the teriyaki beef sirloin omlette comes to mind).  You ignored the fact that there was a 20 minute wait and that the decor had probably been the same since they opened because the food was that good and very affordable.

The new Eats still has a line, but no charm and a predictable, less-affordable menu.  I'm afraid Laurel Heights is continuing to bleed onto Clement Street coming from the east.  I had the chicken and waffles.  The waffles were too crispy, and the gravy had very little flavor.  You could tell that the gravy was homemade, but it was as if there was no seasoning in it.  I'll take Roscoe's over that any day.  The bacon waffles were good, but COLD.  My boyfriend said they were just as cold the first time he ordered them.  I don't know what that was about, but I hope it was just a fluke.  

The service at the old Eats was slow but courteous.  The service at the new Eats resembles a hip eatery in LA that I only go to because someone is dragging me:  quick, disinterested, and too cool.   

Sorry new Eats.  You're just not as good.
author: Daniel F.

description:
Just had to get out today.
My 401k is now a 201k and I'm hungry for eggs.

It's situated on a corner with windows galore.
Just 3 were people here at 8:30am and I snatch a window seat.
Order the eggs sunny up!, italian sausage,home fries and choice of bread. I asked for rye bread. 

Coffee was better than average: dark,smoky, slightly bitter, altogether Yummy !!

In a wee ten minutes, I had my buckfast. 
The home fries look red, and that's because they season them with paprika ( a little funky but just so you know) they tasted ok. 

The eggs were cooked as requested sunny side up and were warm too. 

The  two italian sweet sausages were cooked just right: not dry but succulent. The rye bread was toasted just right too.

Customer service: fine.
Decor: straight ahead americana.

I'll def. return for those ricotta pancakes.
author: Bert K.

description:
11.22.10

Sister restaurant to Burma Superstar and B Star.  New American concept brunch food, focusing on seasonal veggies (maybe even locally grown).  Open for brunch EVERY DAY until 3:00 p.m.  Because I always find myself strolling in there at 2:00.

Big, heaping cup of joe, refills every 15.  Quick and friendly service, and they don't kick you out even past closing hour (I so, so appreciate that).

Stick with their omelets; they have a fresh, funky twist to traditional ones you would see at normal diners.

Can't wait to return next time, 2:00 p.m. of course.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I am shocked, SHOCKED, that the rating isn't higher.  We've been here at least 6 times, we drive 45 mins from the east bay just to go here.

It's a small place, only about 8 tables.  They can't handle large groups very well, party of 2 or 4 is best.  We usually try to get there before 9am so the wait isn't too long.  We've never had a problem with the service, it's always been good.

The food is very good, they put a little bit of a twist on things, it's not just your standard pancake and eggs kind of place.  The food is always very fresh and well made.  I don't even like telling people about this place, I want it all to myself.
author: Tim S.

description: Fantastic place for brunch! Amazing juices!
author: Sp S.

description: Worst breakfast experience EVER!  First I ended up having to sit directly outside the restroom...but that was the good part.  My bacon was terribly undercooked, even though I ordered it very, very, very well done.  So I asked kindly if they could please continue to cook it for me (as it was limp).  After closer inspection, the remaining food on my plate was cold...not warm...cold.  When the bacon came back, under the bacon was a black hair.  The only thing nice about the place was the wait staff.
author: Tess C.

description: Perfect place for an early breakfast with your young children on the weekend. My little guy loves the junior pancake.
author: Sean C.

description: Spent the weekend in SF for a friends birthday and am eating breakfast here for the 2nd day in a row. Enough said.
author: Chris H.

description:
When I sat down to order here yesterday morning, it seemed to me that the place should not be calling itself EATS; it should be calling itself EGGS. Here's what the subject headings on the breakfast side of the menu consisted of:

* Two-egg breakfasts
* Three-egg scrambles
* Three-egg omelets
* A la carte

I'm not a huge egg person, but I'm definitely more eggy than pancakey. So when my friend who had been to Eats before asked if I wanted to share a scramble and the ricotta pancakes (an "a la carte" item), I agreed, but  figured I'd only have at most a couple bites of the latter.

Then our food came.
Then I had that first "couple" of bites.

And that's when the moment of clarity arrived. The place should not be called Eats. It should not be called Eggs.

Without a doubt, it should be known as simply, "Ricotta Pancakes."

Like I said, I don't even like pancakes. But these aren't really pancakes. Like, you don't even need butter or syrup. They're more like a perfect little piece of heaven in my mouth. Like a soft, moist, delicious ORGASM in my mouth.

I think this is the 2nd place in SF I've reviewed based only on one experience. Maybe I'll discover more hidden treasures among the scanty menu on subsequent visits... 

But until then, the ONLY thing that'll keep me coming every morning, is Ricotta Pancakes ;)
author: Kate V.

description: Great service today! Food was perfect portions and sooooo tasty. Great atmosphere and loved my bowl of latte!  Can't wait to go back!
author: Shannon D.

description:
Try the Hummus dish and the chicken and waffles and wash everything down with a Refresher drink.
I would of totally gave this place 5 stars, but the server tossed all my table left overs in the trash and we had so much food....The server knew she made a mistake and kindly told us she would take care us next time we come in.
author: Ernson C.

description: Pretty good diner food in SF. Nice waitstaff and a weird table system but not bad. I had the fried chicken which is a hard food to complain about and my gf had  eggs. We split one of the special toasts and all were par, nothing crazy but no complaints. Would come back if in the area for lunch/ brunch.
author: Max S.

description:
How can I even begin to explain how in love I am with this restaurant? You approach the restaurant, are presented by a dry erase board where you write your name, number of people, and seating preference. You wait a little while and they call your name and seat you. Awesome service there by the way!

Inside, they play amazing music. Indie, Alternative, New Wave, 80s... All of that good stuff! Everything, and I mean everything, looks amazing on the menu. But, after much debate, I ended up picking the B.A.T. Scrambled Eggs which comes with delicious toast and Roasted Home Potatoes. Those potatoes are, by far, the best potatoes I have ever had in my life. They put whole scallions inside your mix of potatoes which just kicks everything up another notch.

I had an amazing experience here. And, whereas it seems like you would be waiting hours to get a seat because the place is cute, adorable, and small, it's really not that long of a wait. It's best for 2-4 people. However, I wouldn't mind waiting an hour just to eat here. If there's one brunch restaurant you're going to try in San Francisco, make it a goal to go to Eats.
author: Ray L.

description:
Great fried chicken sandwich. Everything else is pretty good but expensive. 

It's filled with young parents with their children in the morning and hungover hipsters toward noon on Sundays. Go early to avoid a long wait. Closes at 2pm.
author: Anonymous C.

description:
Eats = delightful and hearty All-American dishes that will waken your palate, particularly during breakfast hour. 

Excited and thrilled to try a new place, my friend brought me to Eats to grub. Talk about heartiness and large portions of everything! Our server was nice enough to explain the menu and when I asked about the size of a mocha, she said it was really good and in a LARGE cup (believe me, it's HUGE. The size of 2 tall coffees). 

My delicious entree was a Spinach Omlette, served with Breakfast Potatoes and toasted bread. Savory and simple. The addition of the mocha made my meal perfect.  

I want to go back!

PRICE: $10 range. Not bad. 
OTHER NOTES:  Be prepared to wait in line to get in!
author: Melinda L.

description: This was my first time eating at Eats and I can say without hesitation that I will definitely be back soon. My group of five was seated approximately 10 minutes after signing up on the whiteboard post outside and we were treated to free coffee (not sure if it was free considering I didn't pay the bill but no one asked for it). Although it was incredibly messy, the Vegetarian Egg Sandwich was top notch. Can't wait to come back and try the Bacon Waffle!
author: Jack A.

description:
This place rules! First time I've dined for breakfast in the Inner Richmond and I have to say the place has personality.  Was totally packed but didn't have to wait too long (5 minutes).  If you're not paying attention, there's a pen and red board to jot your name down outside...
Service was a bit slow, but only because they were getting hammered and our waiter was attentive enough.  Try an egg white omelette here...I swear they must grill the mushrooms or something because it had a smoky taste that was surprisingly palaterrific...I had the fried egg sandwich smushed nicely between ciabatta, bacon and very nicely spiced aioli.  And the potatoes!?  Damn...They fry em, roast em, and then season them again before they hit your plate.  I wanted to do the Balki Bartakamos dance after I ate them..
author: Darren B.

description: A friend and I met for brunch on a Sunday around 1pm. We were really lucky and got in right away to sit at the counter. I was disappointed to hear that the lemon poppyseed pancakes were sold out...next time! I ordered the Waffle with fruit, it was delicious. The prices were quite reasonable. Our waitress was patient and we split the bill on two cards. I will certainly be back!
author: Dani L.

description:
really cute place for breakfast/brunch.

i got the B.T.A (bacon, tomato, avacado) scramble - basically eggs scrambled with those ingredients. it comes with either a side of potato or salad and toast. the egg was a bit too fried for scramble but it was still good overall. it was $10.95. for a dollar more you can get the smoked salmon omelet which was really good.

the waffle is pricey - $3.50 for 1 tiny waffle. but according to my friend, it's yummy.
author: Christine C.

description:
Great brunch mimosa (mmm...and comes in blood orange too!). Great savory egg dishes. 

But there are only a few dishes for those with a sweet tooth which makes it hard for me to come here with my boyfriend. 

Also, a breakfast spot like this should have a weekly special to keep its novelty since there are many great spots in the city. That being said, when I want a mimosa and a scramble, Eats is where I come.
author: Ashley A.

description:
My friend & I went here one morning when it wasn't soo crowded! Cute spot but a little small for me. Ordered the Huevos Rancheros & was surprised to have 2 hard tortilla shells with the eggs etc...on it placed in front of me! I've had better @ other places & the presentation much different.
