Went there again a second time when it was very busy & some guy put his name down to be seated knowing that its a rush with limited spacing for such a small place & walked off with others waiting. His name was called numerous of times but no answer. The hostess of course called the next name(s). Keep in mind I was a name behind. This guy returns arguing with the hostess that why wasn't his name called? Hostess told him sir we called your name many times but you weren't here so we went on to call the others that were waiting. This went on back & fourth for a couple mins. She finally ended up sitting him down with his guest. Word of advice don't put your name down & walk away stay & wait like everyone else has to who are very hungry!

After finally being seated, I ordered the Chicken & Waffles & boy was I satisfied!!! I highly recommend this meal w/ a mimosa of course
author: Anthony S.

description: My daughter and I were staying at an AirBnB around the corner and decided to stop in. The food was great and the price was right.  I know others complained about the wait, but we went mid-week and had no problems getting in.
author: Eric R.

description:
I hadn't been to Eatz in many years. It was always the "high class" place around the corner from me when I was younger and more broke in San Francisco. My girlfriend and I were in the area early on morning and we decided to check it out. Its been remolded to look friendly and cool. The staff was super kind too. The only issue was the cream had gone bad and I didn't find this out till it was already in my coffee. OK, no big deal. They apologized and replaced it quick enough. The breakfast was so delicious in fact that a few days later we decided to go back. And thats where things went wrong.
There was a group of people waiting for tables. There was the usual list on the door to put your name on. I went inside and asked if I could get a cup of coffee while I waiters. The waitress had to ask the manager who told her no. The waitress then came back to me and gave me some mumbled explanation that they don't do this here. So let me get this straight. A customer waiting outside requesting coffee can't have a cup of coffee from the restaurant? Yes. It seems like a way to turn business away instead of make your customers feeling valued but that is their policy there. When we did finally get a table and a cup of coffee the cream rose to the surface of my coffee in small hard chunks...again. When I asked for it to be handled the waitress this time seemed angered that I had pointed it out rather than helpful. Sorry Eatz, your lack of basic refrigeration knowledge and off putting customer service policies about coffee have chased me away.
author: joe k.

description:
Really good Brunch place! Service is good and you won't have the long waits for tables like you do at brunch places in the Marina and Pac Heights. 

I had the two eggs any style with bacon. It was quick and very good.
author: Bernard D.

description:
Brunch here was amazing.  I had their Chicken & Waffles dish for breakfast and it filled me up.  The waffles stayed crunchy even though the honey had been sitting on top of it and did not get soggy.  It was great!

But my friend ordered the Bacon Waffles dish and I think they only put 1 strip worth of bacon in his meal.  So...just a heads up on that!
author: Wendy T.

description: Decent food, HORRIBLE service. I had to ask multiple times for refills on my water and coffee, along with my guest's drinks. The server never came by to ask how our food was. THEN on top of it all, she thought it was a good time to sit down and eat at a table next to us while we waited for the items,  that are already included with our meal, to arrive. I was very disappointed. I've been working in the service industry for 8 years and I would have been fired on the spot if I ate in front of the customers who I should be taking care of. Our server was rude and treated us as if we were a nuisance. Another server brought our check and when I tried to tell her which items to put on which card, she THREW her pen at me an told me to write it down. If you are looking for a good place to get great food and service, avoid Eats.
author: Alan T.

description:
I approve!! The servers were personable, funny and accommodating, and the eats were beyond edible and reasonably-priced.

I had the vegetarian fried egg sandwich.  It was pretty tasty, and very filling.  It is served with a side of country potatoes, which were cooked with whole, unpeeled garlic cloves, which are fun to chew on... Mmmm. While the egg sandwich was good, I feel that it could have used a little extra spark... Maybe I needed to have the bacon one.

It is a tiny, quaint lil' restaurant, so I'd recommend going elsewhere for breakfast if you have a big, loud, hungover group of friends with you.  But I'm definitely going back.
author: Dubby D.

description:
Came here with a friend on a Saturday morning at 10am. I've heard this place was popular but I didn't expect it to be crowded with a wait list. We got in fairly quickly. 

The waitress was nice and helpful. I asked her for her favorites and ended up on one of the last items that she listed. It was a new item just from last week. Chorizo with polenta and poached eggs. 

The chorizo was delicious, with a nice kick to start off my morning. I love anytime there's a little spice in my food. Normally, I'm not a fan of polenta but this was really smooth, buttery, and tasty. The poached eggs were unevenly cooked. One was nice and runny, the other was not. My only complaint. 

I tried out a drink from their juice bar, it was the Power C drink that is orange and grapefruit. Pretty refreshing. A litte sour though.

I always wanted to come by this place to try to chicken and waffles so I guess I'll be back.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
I recently returned to this place, which had been a regular weekend brunch haunt of mine when I lived nearby from 2003-2009. Since I was last there, Eats has had a change of ownership -- and, based on this latest experience, I won't be back.

They've added a counter along the windows facing Clement, making the already-crowded dining room ridiculously cramped. And on a moderately warm (68 degrees) and sunny day, this area was just unbearable as the white muslin curtains that theoretically provided protection from the sun in fact created a near-perfect greenhouse effect, making sitting at the counter rather like roasting in a 350 degree oven.

The menu has changed. The beloved ricotta pancakes -- the reason I went there -- are gone. Instead I had a smoked salmon omelette which was okay but nothing spectacular, and came accompanied by one pathetic piece of toast (and I wasn't even asked what variety of toast I wanted).

In general, the prices seem somewhat higher as well. All in all, what had been a beloved neighborhood diner has attempted to move a notch upscale and not done it very well. This onetime regular will have brunch elsewhere when I'm in the neighborhood again.
author: Bruce M.

description:
The Old Eats: traditional brunch menu with some bangin' pancakes...tho generally speaking what you would expect from a Greasy Spoon.

The NEW Eats...
I know I said I was sad that Burma was taking over my little neighborhood spot... I TAKE IT BACK. This local eatery has been transformed into a place with great meals spun off of traditional SF brunch finds...

my Huevos Ranceheros... had pinto beans instead of black, which helped to kick up the flavors a bit and add a creaminess to the dish's sauce. Also, it was nice to see giant chunks of fresh avocado and tomato on my plate... but the best part was that the corn tortilla was flash fried and crispy. It gave the meal that little extra somethin' somethin'.

The stand out for my meal was the Detox Juice. The Beets and Ginger really complimented the Carrot base and being that it was freshly juiced for me, the flavor was very refreshing! 
They also serve a traditional fresh squeezed OJ there as well.

I agree with other reviewers that this brunch spot likely isn't too great for groups larger than 4 people...but my brunch buddy and I agreed that pretty much any seat in this place wouldn't be considered "the bad spot".
Lots of couples here...and the turn around isn't too bad. We waited for about 5/10 minutes...which is much better than some spots with the same caliber of food. Also... the meal pricing was pretty good for the type of food and the portion size. However...my juice was $4.25 for 10 oz. which seemed a bit high. 

Over all, I will FOR SURE come back!
It's pretty silly that my experience at B-Star for breakfast kept me from coming to the new Eats for so long. But...now that I've proved myself wrong...I'm really glad I did. 
I think I've finally found my go-to neighborhood brunch spot! WINNING!
author: Katy A.

description:
The morning after my Tahoe snowboarding trip I figured would be the best day to start my Chicken and Challenge.  I called my best friend David to have breakfast with me before we worked a 1 pm that day.  I told him that we'd share the massive concoction because I knew if I were to finish it alone, work would be filled with me in food coma.

We enter the building on the corner of 1st ave and Clement with the red awning that said EATS. I had been there once before on a first date and of course David and I sit in the exact same place.  I also so that this Eats also has a Waffle Bacon, where the waffle is made with slices of bacon in it.  Of course I thought it would be a genius Idea to order the Chicken and waffles with a bacon waffle substitition and 20 mintues later and our food wasn't out she comes out with the bad news.  Either I wait till they fix the waffle maker to get the bacon in it or I get a regular waffle and eat now.  Of course I eat now.

-I feel that it was fate telling me to NOT mess with the menu and just order as is.

In my research to find the best Chicken and Waffles joint in the Bay Area I compiled a list of all the places and what the menu description was.
LINK: http://www.teepzcorpuz.com/teepz/Contact_files/Chickenandwaffles2011.pdf

EATS

50 Clement Street St

Tue-Sun 8am-3pm

"All Natural Chicken & Homemade Buttermilk Waffle panko crusted fried chicken breast topped with a mushroom medley gravy served with homemade buttermilk waffles topped with honey butter 11.95"

REVIEW:

Besides that fact that the order came super hot and burned the roof of my mouth, the panko crusted fried chicken topped with the mushroom medley gravy was super delicious.  It topped off the ultimate sweet and savory aspect.  People eat their chicken and waffles separately, but I eat it on top of each other.   As I cut through the tender fried chicken on top of the fluffy yet crispy belgium waffle two friendly women talked to me about my dish. As I raved about the concept of Chicken and waffles, she talked about her experience in LA with Roscoes a long time ago.  I explained how I only like belgium waffle  and no skinny waffles and insisted for her to order Chicken and Waffles herself.

The best part of dish was the mushroom gravy, I never thought to add another piece to this crazy dish but it worked great.  When I ran out of gravy and waffle and all I had was fried chicken, I had to order another waffle.  So I used their house maple and shared the rest with David.  Over-all I was very impressed with EATS on Clement.  The service and atmosphere was great and the Chicken and Waffles were something else.

I wonder: will every place I go to, will I run out of waffle and have a ton of fried chicken left over?

till next time-enjoy theses pictures

follow me on @teepzchallenge

and like me on Facebook
author: Tipay C.

description:
So here's the thing...a lot of people might consider four stars to be a stretch...however....it really isnt, as long as you order the right stuff.  I have eaten here a handful of times so I feel like I have a good grasp of the menu. 

NEVER EVER EVER order the tuna sandwich. Seriously it is nasty bad. So bad that I actually sent it back which i virtually never do. 

Dont bother with the salads. They are okay, but, just okay. I dont very much like the creamy dill dressing on the chop chop salad. Obviously, if the tuna salad uses the tuna stuff from the sandwich avoid it at all possible costs. Just say no to funky tuna. 

Do eat....
The huevos rancheros are freaking delicious and amazing beyond belief. They serve them on two fried tortillas instead of over chips which is so amazing. Fresh avo on top...yuuuummmmmyyy

Waffles are also SUPER duper tasty. Great whipped cream tastiness. 

Other great things about Eats is that the coffee is good, the tea is super tasty and high quality, the mimosa deal is great too. They also make green juice fresh which is a huge plus. 
Service is great. When I had to send back the tuna sandwich the waitress was really super nice about it. 

Overall....I recommend it.
author: Yuliya R.

description: Was here last Saturday for Breakfast. Was pretty lucky and only had to wait 5 min to get a table. I got the eggs, bacon, and potatoes, and a regular coffee. The eggs had chives on top, garlic and seasoning on the potatoes and the bacon was crispy just ow I like it, was a fabulous breakfast! Would definitely go back here again!
author: T L.

description:
Excellent brunch place off the beaten track.  

The wait on a blustery sunny Sunday was about 20 minutes for 3 people. 2 person parties were being seated within 5-10 minutes. The staff moves cheerily and quickly. For 20 minutes, it's great to stroll down Clement, and check out some shops. The toy shop down the street kept us plenty occupied.

Chicken and Waffles - Large fried breast of chicken, in panko crusted batter. Chicken was moist and flavorful. The waffles light and hearty. The gravy was a flavorful mushroom, and not goopy and fatty like traditional gravy. I'd highly recommend it.

Home fries - many dishes come with home fries. I'd recommend it. It's well-seasoned with roasted garlic. It's firm and with a crunchy (sometimes a bit too crunchy) exterior. 

Bacon Waffle - Yes, you didn't mis-read. It's a waffle with a bacon in it. It's covered in cheese, hungarian peppers, and 2 eggs over-easy. If you are watching your cholesterol, it may be a good idea to avoid it. If you aren't, you could ask for them to put the mushroom gravy on it. (you only live once... and after eating this, maybe not too long)

They also make fresh juices. I'd recommend the detox, which was refreshing. 

They have mimosas (and ones you make yourself), etc. but didn't try. Eggs benedict also looks like something to try on my next visit.
author: Boris C.

description: Traditional home style American breakfast foods done right, mimosas too!... set in an up beat, relaxed atmosphere.
author: Greg K.

description:
This place is exceptional. I could eat breakfast and lunch here every day. HIghlights are the Salads, Egg Dishes and Fried chicken. The staff is really well trained and attentive too.

There's always a line here for a reason.
author: DEREK S.

description: Eats has the most heavenly french fries. Their pancakes aren't bad either! The service has always been friendly and you can really taste the quality of their food. Eats is a great local restaurant in the Richmond.
author: Victoria F.

description:
I came in asking about the menu and several substitutions, the waitress was more than happy to say no problem we can do that for each of my requests. 

I ordered the fried egg sandwich with chicken and a side salad. Everything tasted great and good came out fast.

I know this place has the potential to be really greasy but you can sub and get a healthy meal.
author: Dennis K.

description: Try the tofu tacos! And get a sweet tote bag while you're there
author: Sandy C.

description: I came here for my birthday breakfast and was disappointed. The service was adequate, but the food was mediocre at best. My boyfriend seemed to enjoy his breakfast, but mine was rather limp in both taste and presentation. I also ordered a mimosa which was petite for its price. The place is ok, but nothing notable.
author: Kristen M.

description:
Came here with a friend who lives right down the street. I didn't imagine how busy this place was at 10AM on a Saturday morning.  Good thing our wait wasn't that long cuz it was freezing out. 

Our server was very friendly and attentive. She pointed us all the popular dishes which is pretty much half the menu. My friend ordered the Chorizo with polenta and poached eggs and I got the cheesy potatoes with poached eggs. My dish was overloaded with potatoes which is what I should have expected. The dish itself was too dry for my taste. I had to add a lot of hot sauce to it. My friend's dish was pretty delish as it was definitely tasteful.
author: Christina Z.

description:
Under the new ownership & management (Eats is now owned by Burma Superstar) , I have to say that I like what they have done.  The new ownership took over...I think in Feb 2010. The menu is less traditional then the "old" Eats, so the food is significantly better- more creative menu & fresher ingredients. Yes, Eats still has its cozy "mom & pop" sort of charm.

The steel cut oatmeal is super good: brown sugar on top of the hot oatmeal with contrasting tart & sweet fruit: strawberries, blueberries & peaches.  My wife had the portobello sandwich. Just amazing--several thin slices of grilled portobello, with grilled yellow bell pepper, mushrooms, goat cheese and a pesto spread.  Also, try their grape juice mimosa, it's outstanding. 

Service is very good and the staff is attentive. 

This is a very small restaurant, so you will have to wait if you come at peak times. We were here twice in 2 days--once for breakfast and once for a late lunch. No wait.
author: Al G.

description:
Yes the wait to eat at Eats (had to to that) can be really long but I lived here over the summer so it was nice to be able to go put our names on the board and hang out for a bit before being seated. I've never had to wait more than 45 min and it's worth it. 
Eats is owned by the same folks who run Burma Superstar and B-Star so it's not a surprise that their food and service is of the same quality. I remember seeing the same waiter we had at Burma Superstar be our waiter at Eats the next morning. 

Highlights:
-Large portions
-fresh local ingredients
-food is always presented nicely and full of flavor
-there's this waffle with bacon inside that is a heart attack waiting to happen but sooo delicious
-i'm an eggs benedict girl and theirs does not disappoint


lowlights (but not really low):
-the wait can be long 
-parking on clement can be tough at times
-the price for the food isn't super cheap but like i said, the portions are large

Can't wait to come back!
author: An-Nhien L.

description:
I feel bad giving Eats a three-star rating, but after two visits, it is all I can do.  First, the good things.  The service tries to be good. The servers are very friendly and do their best.  In addition, the restaurant's mainstream American food (which is what most people there seem to order) is done well and has good flavor.  Eggs, waffles, etc. are all done with interesting twists that add flavor.  The restaurant puts a gourmet touch on some dishes and definitely makes much of the food special.  So, service is friendly, and the core menu is good.  So why not a higher rating?

Several things prevent Eats from getting  a higher rating from me.  First and foremost, the physical space really sucks; it is simply too small.   There is a long wait during peak hours and people have to wait outside until a table or counter space opens up.  Second, even when you get in, the eating space is super tight.  Eats has to turn a profit off of only a breakfast and brunch crowd (no dinner), which means packing people in and turning customers around quickly.  No matter where you sit, it is hard to shake the feeling that you are just crammed in.  There are people at counters and every possible seating area is jammed packed.  The last time I went, I got lucky and got a table -- right next to the bathroom, which was constantly in use while I was trying to eat.  Realistically, you feel like you just want to gulp down the food and get out into the fresh air again.  The tight eating space makes it hard to feel relaxed.

The crowdedness also affects the service.  While the servers are friendly, they are busy.  You are not likely to get asked if you want more coffee mid-meal unless there is a lull in business. As noted, however, the place is so busy, this rarely happens.  So, you tend to get friendly, attentive service up until you place your order, then the service drops off until the bill comes.  For the money Eats charges, customers deserve better.  

While the food is generally tasty, not everything is right.  The Mexican food (e.g. huevos rancheros) is awful, at least if one likes  some authenticity.  Sadly, it seems the Latino cooks have been ordered to create fake Mexican food to appeal to mainstream tastes.  It does not have to be this way, as there are several upscale places that do a better job with ethnic food.  A gourmet bent should not be an excuse to ruin ethnic dishes.   

So, who won't like Eats.  Old people like me who like personal space and service, like slow meals and conversation, and authentic ethnic food.  Who will like it?  I suspect mostly young people who moved here after growing up in middle America with limited ethnic exposure, who want to try new places for familiar, but fancier, American fare, and who, if they are honest, do not really care about service and space too much.  Visit and judge for yourself.  But if you go, get there early to get a table away from the bathroom.  i am done for a while with Eats.
author: Miles N.

description:
I went to Eats not because its got great reviews on Yelp, but because its near where I live and whenever I walk past it, it always looked so inviting and cute. 

I went on Friday morning to have breakfast with my friend.  We knew that under the old management their ricotta pancake was quite popular, however, it is no longer on the menu. 

The two of us had:

Coffee
One pancake
Ham & Tomato Egg's Benedict
Fried Egg Sandwich 

The atmosphere of Eats is very welcoming and inviting.  It seemed homey yet at the same time clean and contemporary.  

We sat at the counter and could watch the cooks prepare our food.

The waiters were also very attentive, as the minute we sat down the coffee waiter came with the coffee.  However, the coffee from Eats were very watery and run down.  I am not a big coffee drinker and even I thought it tasted really bland.

Next came our breakfast.  The eggs Benedict was okay.  Granted, i really liked it when I had it, but the next day we went to Mel's Drive In and I ordered eggs Benedict again, and I'd say the two were comparable.  Mel's eggs Benedict was just your normal eggs Benedict, but Eats added the twist of tomato.  So the tomato actually made the egg Benedict less heavy and more refreshing.  However, the hollandaise sauce that Eats used with it, which is a bit spicy, completely negated the taste/effect of the tomato.  So at the end, its just comparable to a normal Mel's eggs Benedict. 

The pancake, oh the pancake.  Firstly, it was HUGE.  Second, it was THICK.  Third, it was surprisingly GOOD.  

I am always hesitant to order pancakes.  I can honestly say I've never had a good tasting pancake my whole life, yet I continue to be tempted in ordering pancakes whenever i see it on the menu.  Pancake, the concept to me is so attractive.  To me, it should be a cake, that is flat, with the right amount of buttery sweetness, moist, light and fluffy texture as one would want in a cake.  Whether it be a gourmet restaurant, popular brunch spot, IHOP or pancake mix, I've never had a pancake where i go "Yes, this is how a pancake should taste" in my head. So "pancake" was always a very vague and elusive food item to me.  

Eats' pancake, is now what I would call a pancake.  It was served w/ powder sugar and butter.  I was really skeptical, after being disappointed many many times.  Then I ate it.  

The powdered sugar gave the right amount of sweetness, just when you think its an ordinary-sweet-and-too-sweet pancake, the butter kicks in and u get a hint of the salty butter.  Then as you are eating the pancake, you wait for that ultimate let down - when the pancake gets soggy and breaks apart in your mouth, and instead of a pancake its now simply batter that is sticking to the roof of your mouth or your teeth.  To me its felt like mixing the pancake batter in my mouth... not a texture I enjoyed.   (was this too descriptive?)  That didn't happen with Eats.  You can sorta chew on it, savor the taste and texture before swallowing.  

While I was so-so with my eggs Benedict but loving the pancake, my friend would not shut up about how good his fried egg sandwich was (which worked to my advantage cause then I get to eat more of the pancake that we were suppose to share). The fried egg sandwich was a mess to eat alright, since the egg yolk ran all over the place.  But boy did that guy LOVED Eats' fried egg sandwich.  If guys can 'gush' I'd say he was gushing!  He took pictures of the sandwich untouched, then took pictures of the sandwich in his hand, then took pictures of the sandwich with egg yolk running.  He just LOVED that sandwich.  

All in all, I'd say Eats surpassed my expectation and definitely did a number on my friend.
author: Jessica C.

description: Eats is without doubt the best breakfast in the neighborhood. The bacon waffle, the chicken and waffle, and the breakfast sandwich are so damn good, there's no way to describe them. It gets crowded on the weekends but it is always worth the wait. Sometimes the service is slow or something gets forgotten but no matter, it is worth it. Love Eats!
author: Sophie K.

description: Eats deserves at least an average yelp score of 4 stars, or maybe even 4.5. This is arguably the best breakfast in the city, certainly the best in the neighborhood. Menu is quite large for this small of a restaurant, and everything I have ever ordered has been delicious. Coffee is great, service always efficient. The only downside is that unless you come early, you will have to wait because its so small.
author: Michael B.

description: BEST EGG BENNY EVER!! We are from SLC  and this was a great find.  Great neighborhood feel, small, and friendly service.  For was seriously awesome!  My son had the tri-tip, daughter oatmeal... Both amazing.  Oh!  Get a Bloody Mary :). Perfectly made.  Will come back next time in the area.
author: Staci C.

description: I had one of the best breakfasts EVA this morning at Eats. You gotta try the fried eggs with sausage and polenta. It will knock the socks you just put on your feet cause you had to rush outa bed to grab this culinary delight.
author: Rob H.

description: Fun little breakfast spot with great food that always highlights whatever is season. Remember to write you name down on he board outside. Place is small but the turnover is pretty quick so don't be scared away.
author: Matt F.

description: Food here is great.  Had one of the scrambles, and the rest of our party had waffles and pancakes.  Everything was fresh and tasty, but the portions are really small.  So, being a little pricey, maybe a little more on the plate would be good.
author: Marie S.

description: This place is awesome. Very local, humble feel. And the food is well made, well presented and with some great options. The fiesta scramble was killer.
author: Nathan A.

description:
My usual "go to" brunch place in my neighborhood was always Q's, mainly since it's where all my friends like to go. Well luckily I was walking around the neighborhood and passed this quaint (and totally packed) little restaurant. I quickly looked at the name and reminded myself to look it up later when I got home. 

A few weeks later three friends and I decided to head over there for some brunch. I had called ahead and knew there was going to be about a 30 minute wait (on a Sunday morning that's to be expected) so wasn't bothered when the hostess told us how long it would be. It was so packed inside (the space is tiny!) that there was no way we were going to try to wait inside. Luckily it was a rare warm, sunny San Francisco day so we waited outside. We walked down a block to get some coffee and stood outside for about 25 more minutes before being seated. One complaint- there aren't many seats outside to sit on while waiting. 

Once seated (I'll admit it was really crammed) the waitress came over to take our drink order, tell us the specials et cetera. I had been looking over at everyone's plates when we walked in and the vibrant green salad looked so freaking good! But I was on a breakfast mission and in desperate need of potatoes. The waitress happily gave us her opinions about what dishes to choose and based on that I has the prosciutto eggs benedict. My friends had the caprese omlette which looked amazing and my other friend had a sandwich with the side salad- which I kept eating. 

Everything was delicious, the price was reasonable and the service was great. I can't wait to go back and try more of the menu. One star off really because of the size of the place and the wait.
author: Suzanne D.

description:
My husband ordered the chicken and waffles, and I was immediately jealous. The chicken is more breaded than fried, and covered in mushroom gravy. I love this Southern dish showing up in San Francisco.

I ordered the most amazing French toast with raisins and walnuts, with sort of stewed apples on top and a cream cheese drizzle. The place is tiny, but our wait wasn't bad at all, even close to noon on a Sunday.
author: Kat M.

description: Quaint and welcoming with natural wood benches and an adorable, friendly decor. We were seated immediately, offered tea and coffee, and we're brought menus to browse. After a few minutes of reviewing their selection we were ready. I have the vegan tofu scramble with potatoes and sourdough toast and my friend had the chicken and waffles. Both came promptly and were cooked to perfection. Full of mouth wateringly good morsels of whole garlic and topped with green onions, the potatoes were to die for. And they definitely didn't skimp on proportions. My tofu scramble was piled sky high and I ate every last bite. My friend also ate as much as he possibly could of his chicken with mushroom gravy and dilectible waffle ensemble. To top it all off, the price was right, and we both left feeling satisfied and with the intention of returning in the near future. Thanks Eats for hooking it up proper!
author: Sadie K.

description:
Some things are just not meant to be.  

The first time we tried to go to Eats, we found parking, only to find it closed with no explanation.  The second time there was no parking and a large crowd outside so we went to Park Chow instead.  Today, we were determined to give this place a try only to be sorely disappointed.

Here are the reasons why Eats lost 3 stars:
Coffee: not great, required lots of sugar, and table was out of cream when we got there

Menu: I love brunch, but nothing really stuck out to be as an "omg, I want to try!" 
- No french toast on menu
- Garden scramble: there was an herb in this dish that I didn't like
- Breakfast suite: hardly a "suite" (small portions and the presentation was not at all appetizing)

Service: One of my pet peeves is when you sit down/order before another table and get served after...After waiting in line for a long time, it rubbed me the wrong way to see a table that got seated after us get their food first.  To add insult to injury the food took a REALLY long time.
- Menu said you get a choice of toast and the waitress was about to walk away without giving me a choice!  When I asked, the only three options were: mutli-grain, rye, or sourdough. (Limited much?)  
- There are 3 types of hot sauce on the table (awesome!) but NO JAM.  One of the best things about brunch is having amazing jam with your toast.  

Decor/set up: this place was remodeled?!  Seriously?  The place still seemed old-style.  Okay, I get it if you're going for the homey feel...but the use of space is not efficient and not comfortable.  

Alas, better that I know now than later.  Some things are not meant to be and I will not be returning.
author: Alvina W.

description:
Came for breakfast fare at this spot after a friend said she always sees it packed on the weekends for brunch. Came on a weekday to avoid the crazy lines and walked right in to a seat at a table.

Checked out the menu and guess what?!? Chicken and waffles?!? SOLD! The waffles were nice and crisp on the outside and fluffy on the inside. Just the way I like them. Seasoning and crust on the chicken is really nice, it's just too bad the chicken is a dry chicken breast. The mushroom sauce on it doesn't really add to the fried chicken experience either.

Regardless of that, I devoured it anyways. Why you might ask? Cause it's chicken and waffles. DUH!
author: Eric L.

description:
This is a small, quaint little neighborhood breakfast eatery that is well-known to the patrons in the area. I never tried Eats under the old management, so this review is based on my first and only visit to Eats, which is under new management (as I've read from Yelpers). 

The restaurant itself is very small. Maybe 10 (less, maybe?) tables and some bar space, so be prepared to bump elbows with your neighbors! We had to wait about twenty minutes for a table on a Sunday morning around 10 am. Those waiting for a table are welcome to enjoy a cup of joe outside, so just ask. 

Once seated, service was great. We sat at the bar facing the window and were promptly served hot cups of coffee. It got really hot since the place is so small and gets a lot of morning sun. And theres a lot of bustling going on...of course having hot coffee doesn't help! The menu is very small but offers some variety. 

Shortly thereafter our server came to take our order and before we knew it, the food was already in front of us, piping hot. I had the modern twist on chicken and waffles...the chicken was panko fried and came with a Belgian style waffle and mushroom gravy on the side. My bf had the ham and tomato eggs benedict, and my sis had the bacon and fried egg sandwich with arugula. All of our dishes were good, with fresh ingredients. I will say that my waffle didn't blow me out of the water...it was crisp on the outside but it was dry and cakey on the inside. On a good note, all of the plates reminded me of Barefoot Contessa recipes. Simple and classic dishes with a contemporary spin. Appearance goes a long way here. Prices are more than your average coffeeshop but worth paying for the fresh ingredients.

If you're willing to wait and don't mind being seated in cozy quarters, Eats is worth trying for a fresh take on breakfast.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Solid 4 Stars.

For those not yet in the know, this place recently reopened under the new ownership of those fantastic restauranteurs responsible for Burma Superstar and B-Star. 

While I was a fan of the previous Eats, I never found much reason to review it besides their sourdough french toast - which was delicious. Everything else on the menu was pretty ho-hum. Now, however, it's a veritable smorgasbord of seasonal, farmer's market inspired dishes.

And creative! Bacon Waffle? Yeah, you heard me right. It's a WAFFLE with BACON it! How could it get any better? I'll tell you! Those crevices in your waffle that are usually filled with syrup - or in the case of certain unsavory individuals, butter and powdered sugar - are filled with CHEESE! But the gastro goodness doesn't stop there! They take it OVER THE LINE and top it off with FRIED EGG! 

It's like breakfast incarnate! 

Do yourself a favor and check this place out. The food is comparable to Zazie, and a few bucks cheaper.

Oh! And kudos to them somehow breathing life into the original Eats logo. I want one of their coffee mugs!
author: Dan W.

description:
I always drive by and see a whole bunch of people waiting in line outside Eats. Having an early day off on Friday, husband and I wanted to have an adventure to try Eats which we have heard a few years ago to be very good. Weekend brunch is the selling point.

Right we sat down and took a look of the menu, I have a feeling that I want to leave but DH would like to give it a try. Basically, Eats is a place to serve breakfasts all day. It does not make it stand out. Many places we know offer that.

We both ordered 2 eggs with chicken sausage. I took the salad and DH chose the potatoes. Interesting that the portion of my scrambled eggs seemed to be double of my DH's sunny side up eggs. The salad was fresh but the portion was too little for the price. The salad dressing was tasty. The chicken sausage tasted like the one sold in Costco and it was quite salty. So far, the ambiance was relaxing as it was a late lunch. No waiting to be seated was needed for us but we had waited for 25 minutes for our plates.Turn out we needed to eat fast because we only put 1 hour worth of quarters into the parking meter and the car was parked a few blocks away.

Overall, the food is overpriced. The restaurant is small and the tables are placed so close and everyone next to your table can overhear what you have said to your companion. Parking is kind of suck. We had spent at least 20 minutes to find parking and finally parked a few blocks away.
author: Roserrele W.

description: One of those places that it depends what you get I guess I have gotten the fiesta scramble most of the times and that seems rather good, the time that I got the other scrambles didn't seem so good the waffle bacon thing that I got once seemed pretty good but I think I'll stick to the fiesta scramble
author: Rachel N.

description:
I am not sure why this place isn't ranked higher. It's delicious, fun, and cute! I have only been for breakfast on a couple occasions. The eggs are fantastic, the huevos rancheros actually have ranchero sauce! Not salsa or the somewhat typical eggs with beans that we're calling huevos rancheros.

The thing that blew me away most was the oatmeal - I was trying to be healthy and it turned out to be a treat :) Love this place!
author: Katie K.

description:
Egg omelet with sausage and side of roasted potatoes and wheat bread. Perfect combo for breakfast. They use seasonal vegetables which makes everything nice and fresh.

Love the ambiance. Has a relaxing cafe feel and with some cool wine racks hanging on the wall.

Service is great. Attentive waiters and helpful.

It was surprisingly busy on a Thursday morning so I bet it's packed on Sundays. If so, it's definitely worth the wait.

4 stars.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Great lunch place. I really like their sandwiches- I've had the crispy chicken and tuna. Both times it was delicious, with one caveat- Bread is always incredibly oily! Next time I'm going to ask them to tone down. Regardless, they were delicious and incredibly large portions. Their fresh juice options are also great and the salad with the sandwiches is great. 

I also like that they serve breakfast all day although I haven't tried it..also like how they give you a piece of fruit with every plate =). My husband l o v e s their caesar salad too!
author: Dana S.

description: Nice staff, it was a lovely breakfast. Portions were smaller than expected but they were the exact size I needed, just enough for me to be content. But I'm 4'11" at a 105 lbs, so you may want to order a bit more. The place is a bit cozy, so if you don't want to be a foot away from another person, you may want to ask for a table with a bit more space, they also have tables outside, but in SF weather that could be a hit or miss. I would eat here again.
author: Kimberly S.

description: Quaint little place with superb breakfast menu! Loved the eggs Benedict!
author: Ana marie d.

description:
OK, so we finally ended up going here, and the old Eats, it ain't.
First off, we were really looking forward to eating outside until we realized that their outside tables & chairs are made of METAL. South-facing buildings on Clement get sun almost all day long, so you can imagine how freakin hot the table top was when we got there at 1pm. The host, who was a cheery, farm-boy looking young fellow offered us to sit inside or out. When we decided to eat inside because we didn't want to get second degree burns on our elbows & asses, we were sort of forced to sit at a tiny table in the front.
My husband is a vegetarian, and I wanted to check out the famous "chicken & waffles", so I did just that, and he ordered the spinach eggs Benedict with a salad. I should mention that we did NOT receive any of these famous "free scones" everyone is raving about.
 When his food arrived, there were potatoes as the side dish, and no salad. That turned out to be a happy accident, because the spuds were quite nice. Turns out he made the better choice. I waited another 10 minutes for my dish to arrive. The waffles were cold. And my "fried chicken" was not the Lousiana style of my youth (my stepdad is from Baton Rouge), but some sort of Asian-inspired melange of favors smothered to death in a mushroom sauce. It was ok, but I ended up eating half of my husbands dish because it was WAY BETTER. 
With tip, the tab came to $40. All we had was the Benedict, the chicken & waffles, and 2 cups of coffee (which was good). At the old Eats, our enormous meals were so cheap that we would leave extra big tips because we felt bad! Easily $13 before tip for the two of us.
There were a few weirdnesses: At the table next to us, a woman had ordered a salad with a hard boiled egg, but it came sort of soft boiled. She asked that it be hardboiled, and they took her salad away. While her friends munched away on their meals, she waited patiently for about 5 minutes, then asked for her salad. They brought it without the egg so that she could start eating. 10 minutes later the waitress came over to tell her they were "Still working" on her (boiled) egg, and that it would take another 5 minutes!! I have no idea if she ever got her egg or not, but how freakin long does it take to boil an egg?
Also, they make a HUGE deal about charging you a fee for Healthy San Francisco. As past recipients of HSF, we know that  ALL San Francisco businesses that do not offer their employees health benefits HAVE to pay into HSF. Why does this place charge you extra? Why do they feel the need to tell you about it? Most places just lump the cost or add the fee to the food cost. Oh, that;s right! this place is so expensive already that they probably are afraid they will lose business if they do that. Pretty crooked for a business that already owns half of Clement St...I am sure they can afford it, don't you?
author: roz A.

description:
One of my favorite old Breakfast places has been sold to a new owner... basically the only thing left untouched is the name.

Don't get me wrong- for the most part- the changes are for the positive. The place looks GREAT.  The renovations are really very nice. The service is *way* faster. The menu is fancier and more refined. The food is presented better- nicer, tidier. Meals are $2-4 more each... They give you free delicious little scones with your order. Awesome, right?

.................. I guess so?

My biggest gripe here is that they've COMPLETELY changed the menu. I understand new ownership and wanting to refine things a bit, widdle down a huge menu.. quality menu choices, over quantity. I get that, I do. But what I don't get is why you wouldn't do a little research and keep a few KEY items. 

If you are going to KEEP the name of the place the same... you should find out what made this place famous... Find out what the customers were coming back for week after week..  and keep those few things.. Namely- the RICOTTA PANCAKES. How could they get rid of the Ricotta Pancakes!?

*sigh* I dunno... This place is nice.. But it's *not* EATS, anymore. It might still have the same name... but until the Ricotta Pancakes are brought back, it might as well have any other name. It bums me out, to be honest.

Oh- and the Breakfast Potatoes have WAY too much effing rosemary. Yeeeech! I love fried potatoes as much as the next guy.. but I *could not* eat my potatoes. Rosemary mania. Ick.
author: Tamara B.

description: I would like to say that everything is good, but there are a few things that I cannot stay away from, so I only know two things that are good. Coffee is good, OJ is fresh squeezed, and the farmer's scramble and fried chix sandwich are really great. I cannot stay away from the farmers scramble, that cheese and the combo of those vegetables is to die for. Everyone likes it. I love sitting outside with my bf and my doggie, it is much better than the tiny crowded restaurant, but of course we will do that on cold days.
author: Erin L.

description:
Greasy diner food, but with plenty of flavor.  I love this place, even though the place is tiny, and always a line.  

I love their vegetarian omelette with their home fries, and a large glass of OJ.   They also have a selection of lunch items--sandwiches and salads.  Hearty portions.

The owners and servers are always so nice and friendly, even they are packed and busy!  

Oh, they're cheap!

There is always a wait though on the weekends...so get there early!
author: Fannie S.

description:
I like the staff as they're very polite.  But the wait is just painful.  On a busy Sunday morning, they only have one chef cooking.  They serve each table one dish at a time.  Our wait outside was 20 minutes.  it's the wait inside that was unexpected.  From the time we ordered, we waited another 25 minutes before we got my plate.  Then his plate...

Basic greasy food which is what you expect.  But the wait is just unbearable.  And they constantly have infomercials on their TV.  I'd rather have it off than being distracted by weeping women having their lives saved by hair transplants.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
I was visiting a friend this past weekend and after partying too much the night before. So, we needed food. STAT! or coffee in my case. so we walked down to this place, EATS. wrote our name on their board outside and just waited 5min to get seated. Funny thing is they were super crowded but offered community seating. Which works, if you want to be seated fast. Thus, the only 5min wait. They had so many yummy food, i didn't know what to choose. Then i saw the ultimate hangover plate!! Chilaquiles. These were soo good! Scrambled eggs, green chile sauce, beans and tortillas. Delish! 
I'd definitely come to EATS on my next visit, the wait staff was friendly, food didn't take to long and good food. Check them out, next time you're up North.
author: Clara M.

description:
I don't know how I'd prided myself on being a Richmond girl all these years without ever having eaten here...oh yeah, there's usually a huge gang of folks outside and I'm usually hungry RIGHT NOW!

Until yesterday that is, and all I can say is: good golly, Miss Molly.  It was absolutely delicious.  Sunday breakfasts/brunches are usually at one of two spots--Squat & Gobble or Joe's--usually dependent on the level of potential hangover slash laziness.  This place combines the convenience of Joe's with way better food than the Squat.

Let me back up momentarily.  There was NO wait when I arrived.  That's right--none.  Despite years of the disappointed drive-by--the "we'll just drive by and see if there's a wait"--there was one lonely table in need of company.  We obliged.

The bf ordered this waffle/berry/whipped cream goodness that looked absolutely sinful.  (Stephanie would have been proud.)  If I had to picture manna--this would be it.  There were super-fresh looking blueberries, blackberries and pomegranate seeds, powdered sugar and a beautiful helping of whipped cream topping this bad boy.  The waffle itself was beautifully crafted--perfectly golden brown, and looked like it had that perfect crispy outside/doughy inside thing going for it.

It turns out, I wasn't meant to know.  Usually, I'm a taster.  Generally speaking, the bf and I have an understanding.  He consistently orders delicious-looking food and I must therefore consistently taste it.  For purely safety purposes, of course.  Yeah--my food was so delicious, and I filled up so quickly on it that I never made it to my tasting course.

Firsty, allow me to say that any breakfast place that puts whole cloves of roasted garlic in their potatoes has me at hello.  I thought the first one was a fluke.  A beautiful and serendipitous accident.  Five more in and I knew I was in love.  Let me also establish, that, like that cute little girl in Knocked Up--I too LOVE breakfast.  I have eaten me a-many-a breakfast potato and these were hands down the best I've had since my dad's.  With these, I had the BTA scramble--as in bacon, tomato and avocado, son.  Dee-licious.  Note the capital "D."  It was so good that I did the unthinkable--I took what I couldn't finish to go.  That's right, eggs to go.  Before you judge, allow me to say that they were equally wonderful the next day.

Also, kudos for a clean and well-stocked bathroom as well as the jam-packed chalkboard of in-season fruits and veggies.  I love a place that satisfies AND educates.
author: Jasmine L.

description:
Great brunch place. 

I ordered the fried chicken and waffle. SO. GOOD. Probably the best I've had in a lonnng while. You know that good clean feeling of food that goes down light, hugs the inside of your stomach, and leaves you smiling? A good satisfaction that leaves you longing for an afternoon nap, even though you just woke up an hour ago? Yeah, it's that "gotta roll out of your chair into your bed" kinda good. But, not that omigodwhathaveidone kinda food coma, but the letshangoutinahammock kinda food coma.

Since my taste buds were being massaged, I can't remember the name of the other dishes my friend and I ordered.

Although, I do remember that every extra bite I took just tasted better and better! I couldn't detect MSG though... what the?

And people, come on! The portions are just right (you really shouldn't be eating portions enough for 3 people--just 2), the service is great, and they have red velvet cupcakes!

One last VERY IMPORTANT THING: they have the best jam, from Jam (the brand--where can I find it to buy it?!)
author: jolie L.

description:
Only been here once but really enjoyed the food. I ordered the bacon waffle which is a waffle with bacon pressed in the middle topped with red peppers and covered in cheese (fontina?). Oh yeah and if that wasn't enough two sunny side up eggs on top. It was truly delicious. I especially liked the waffle itself - it was one of those  "cake-y" ones not all thin and crispy but soft and moist. I liked you could get it w home fries or salad because i needed the salad to balance it out. There were a few other things that really looked good on the menu like the fancy toast with goat cheese, strawberries and honey and the quadruple grilled cheese so I'll have to go back. 

No complaints really - though 3$ is a little steep for a cup of joe.

Friendly staff. Reasonable food prices.
author: Miya F.

description:
Refreshed eats.

New management. New paint. New aesthetic. They did a nice job. Still a diner feel but with a more modern vibe. Wait looked daunting but 20m on a Sunday wasn't bad at all.

Now for the eats.

Best part was the generous fruit with both the waffle and the house granola parfait. If there was such a thing as too much this would be it. Fortunately you can never have enough fruit.

Strawberries, blueberries and bananas aside, not bad. Waffle was good. Liked they offered half portions, though the waffle itself was about half the size of a normal waffle. Had we not shared a parfait I would have needed the full order.

Prices are a bit high, especially the coffee. $2.75 for drip is steep.

Friendly service made up for the sticker shock.
author: Jason B.

description: Delicious breakfast food.  I had a half order of the berries and cream waffle.  Yum, yum yum.  It is a smaller portion- which is better honestly even though I wanted to eat it forever.  I also order a side of  bacon.  My husband had the mushroom & spinach eggs benedict with potatoes.  It was also delicious.  We will be back.
author: Christy L.

description:
went there during lunch time. the restaurant was half full and got a nice greeting from a server. sat down along the window side where it was nice and sunny..first time wearing sunglasses while eating inside a restaurant. the orange juice i ordered was freshly squeezed and oh-so-sweeeet. kinda pricey but worth it. me and my girlfriend both ordered the chicken and waffles. this was like a up-scale version from your normal take on chicken and waffles. the chicken looked like it came from the breast, all white meat and no fat. it was breaded and topped off with gravy and different varieties of mushrooms, along side with 2 waffles. i think the mushrooms were the best part of this dish. the chicken was too lean for me and the waffles were good but the syrup was so watered down....weird. it was an ok lunch. maybe i will try something different from here next time.

*not written by me!*
author: kim w.

description:
- freshly baked warm mini scones: check
- fast and friendly service: check
- best prosciutto eggs benedit ever: check
- having b-fast after a wild night out  w/ your besties: priceless

My first time eating here was after a long night of debauchery with the ladies and having my glass of water constantly refilled was a dream come true. This cozy diner was exactly what I need for "the morning after." Minus one star for the price to porportion ratio. Although the food was impressive/excellent, and SF is expensive to begin with, it would still be nice to get a bigger portion when you're putting out $13 for a b-fast plate.
author: Crystal D.

description:
I just got back from trying the new Eats 20 minutes ago.  I was a fan of the old Eats even though I stunk like grease every time i left. 

so, the new Eats is cute and has the brunchy feel.  the menu is new and improved with more than just eggs and bacon.  so, we ordered the following:

1) cran-orange scones- $4.50.  (more comments on this in a bit.) 
2) fresh squeezed orange juice- $3.75
3) coffee- $2.00
4) chicken and waffles- $12.00 (?)
5) cracked pepper chicken sausage scramble with rosemary potatoes- $(i can't recall).

the coffee was bold and bottomless, the fresh squeezed OJ tasted fresh squeezed but considering it says "juice bar coming soon" on their drink menu, i question whether my OJ today was really fresh squeezed or it came out of a bottle.  we asked for water for the table and didn't get that until 1/3 way into the meal (fine, i guess they were busy).  

the chicken and waffles dish was tasty.  it's a thin piece of chicken breaded with panko, fried, and covered with a mushroom gravy- YUM.  the waffles were...like waffles.  it wasn't an eggo waffle so that's a plus.  the cracked pepper chicken scramble was flavorful except mine was almost room temperature since they probably waited for the chicken and waffles to be done so both plates could be brought out together.  i'm sure my scramble sat on the counter a bit.  it's alright i guess since it was tasty.  the rosemary potatoes had pieces of rosemary all over them, so kudos for that!  overall, we enjoyed our main dishes.

ok, now onto the scones.  promptly after we placed our orders (see above list), a plate with 3 tiny little scones and jam arrived at our table.  my boyfriend and i looked at it and thought, "damn, 3 tiny scones for $4.50?"  we ate them anyway and truly loved how they tasted; we just wished they were bigger.  :/ we thought the price was to justify that they were homemade?  but thank you to the previous yelpers, i found out those tiny scones were meant to be free!!!!  SO WE PAID $4.50 FOR SCONES WE NEVER GOT!!! fml.

i do live a block away, but am i going to walk all the way back just for $4.50+tax?  no.  but we shouldn't have gotten screwed.  they forgot our water bc they were busy- fine.  but i sort of have a problem with paying for something i didn't get.  and since those scones were yummy, i'm even more bummed i didn't get what i paid for (maybe they were bigger?).

so Eats reborn, i know you just opened a couple of days ago and there are kinks you need to iron out so let me make a few suggestions:

- make sure your customers get what they paid for.
- make sure their food isn't dried out and at room temperature.
-bring out waters within a reasonable amount of time.
-fix the front door so there isn't a draft coming in for those sitting by the door.

look guys, i have faith in you.  brunch is one of my favorite things in the world and considering you are so close to home, i would hate to have to write you off.  now how about those scones???
author: Sally T.

description:
This is one of my favorite breakfast/brunch places. They offer some pretty unique dishes and all of them are good. Today I tried the Spicy Tomato Winter Skillet - very satisfying. It was fully of fresh vegetables, was topped with 2 eggs cooked sunny side up and Parmesan cheese, and had just the right amount of kick. 

They also have really good coffee (I'm relatively picky about my coffee) and selections of juices. The downside of this place - it's small. So if you head over there on a Saturday or Sunday morning after 9:00 a.m., expect to wait. Also, if you are in a group of 2, you may very well have to sit at a counter as opposed to a table.
author: David S.

description:
This is currently my favorite breakfast/brunch location. So long Stacks.

I've had the pleasure to try this place a few times. I've only been dining here at or before 11am so the line don't seem that bad and I can get a table quickly. The ingredients are freash and seasonal and their specials menu on the chalk board changes every so often. 

All early meals start off with a freshly baked bite sized complimentary scone with blackberry jam on the side. Nice touch!

My favorite dish is no doubt the chicken and waffles but it is a little pricey at about $12. It slightly different in that the chicken is more like a fried chicken filet. It is topped with a gravy consisting of different mushrooms including the black Chinese ones. The square waffles are nice and fluffy, and are sprinkled with powdered sugar. 

I've also had a couple of their scrambles as well which come with toast and potatoes or salad. Most recently, I had the pepper chicken sausage scramble. There are some peppers mixed in that provide a nice sourness that goes well with the scramble, perhaps they were marinated in something. 

And I always get a glass of granny smith apple and carrot juice to go with my meal. It is freshly blended and delicious. My wife always gets it to go afterwards as well!

I definitely would recommend this place for breakfast/brunch. They do offer sandwiches for lunch but I have yet to try. The only thing I would complain is that it is small and not a great place for larger parties.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I live right down the street and have been coming here on a regular basis for years, but the service has taken a serious nose dive recently.  The food is pretty good, however, I've had problems 3 times in a row now, and it's always the same problem.  They run out of something and I don't find out until they bring out my boyfriend's food, which is always fine, and I have to sit and watch him eat while they scramble to make up for the fact that an idiot is managing the kitchen and screwed up my order.  

The kitchen staff seems to be incapable of foreseeing when they will run out of things.  Nobody seems to be paying attention as levels get low.  Instead, they wait until they are completely out of something, then act surprised, as if nobody could have possibly noticed that they were running low ahead of time.  

Today, however, the idiot server actually brought out my eggs benedict without sauce, placed it in front of me, and said, "we ran out of hollandaise sauce.  I can get you some aoli or another sauce if you want..."  I had to explain that it's not eggs benedict without the freaking sauce.  It's like bringing out the burger somebody ordered without a bun because you ran out.  You just don't do that.  What a freaking moron.  It's bad enough that the kitchen staff is oblivious and doesn't have the presence of mind to alert the servers when they are almost out of something.  The real kicker was that I was expected to eat something minus a key component, which isn't what I ordered, and that I received no compensation whatsoever for this mess.  I should have contested the bill, but I didn't because I'm a sucker.  It's the last time, though, because I am done going here.  The staff needs to get their act together.
author: Katie B.

description:
I can't believe its owned by new people now. What a disaster! I used to like going here for their awesome brunches even though parking wasn't the best. It was worth the wait because their omelets were delicious. However, I came back here a few months ago and found that it was owned by new people. They kept the name but disappointingly did not live up to the great food I once knew. 

It is too pricey for their small portions and it took forever for our food to arrive. Our waitress was nice but I think she was annoyed of me since I kept waving her our way with questions. I couldn't help it though because I had to ask for water, straws, napkins, the check, EVERYTHING. And it wasn't even that busy. If everything came at a timely manner, I wouldn't have to keep flagging her down.

When our food finally did arrive it wasn't warm enough. They even messed up the waffles by overcooking them. How could they mess up the waffles?! Anyways, I don't even know what else to complain about. Maybe it was just the cook they had that day, or maybe they were tired, or maybe I'm just making up excuses for them. Skip this place and make brunch at home. They totally killed the Eats I once knew. If you're going to keep a restaurant's name, you should do your homework and find out what they were famous for. The lines used to be out the door compared to now. Sigh, oh well.
author: Chau H.

description: Great little establishment-neighborhood eatery. Tastey-healthy breakfast treats. I'd go again and again. My husband worked for the original owner in the '80's-he was really impressed with the food, service and prices. Bravo!
author: Nancy M.

description: Food was mediocre, my bacon and egg sandwich was drowning in yolk and not very flavorful.  The hostess made us stand in the rain while our 4th member was parking, normally I understand waiting until the entire party was there but it was pouring and instead of showing compassion, she decided to make a rude joke.  Long lines are normally justified by food quality or lack of space, this was neither.  Our table was ready and the food was not great. Given the depth of quality in the neighborhood, I felt this was a 2 star experience.
author: Jake S.

description:
Burma Superstar folks are now running Eat's breakfast.  The menu and the space look nothing like the old Eat's.

Small place with very limited seating, but a quick turn around as the food is fast and everyone eats, pays, and bolts. We got in at noon yesterday (sat) and ordered while standing up... had seats 15 minutes later and I enjoyed what was possibly the greatest chicken, waffles, and home fries I've ever had in my life. I paid $17 including tip for my meal and a fresh OJ and coffee... 

SuperStars, we loved the ricota pancake from the old Eat's menu, bring it back???
author: F B.

description:
Alas! From what I've heard, Eats used to be the bomb-diggity until they were bought out by Burma- but unfortunately I do not have the pleasure of this experience.  

Pros: 
-The portions; no, you can't get stuffed.  They are not humungous like I'm used to, but they do get props for preparing the portions that you should be eating.
-The new renovation has CUTE and FARMHOUSE and GIANT MIRROR written all over it.
-Free mini-mini-scones!  Warm and delicious with a tit of jam.
-The service is all smiles.
-Their red potatoes/home fries killed me.

Cons:
-Pricey if you're expecting a huge breakfast.
-Fresh-squeezed O.J.?  Forget about it.  It was clearly NOT fresh-squeezed, it came in a tiny glass, AND IT WAS $3.75.  Rip. Off. 
-And also $3.00/ pancake. One.
-Don't sit by the door.
author: Jed E.

description:
Annnnnnnd, Brunch once again. 
As it was the day before my "Unbirthday", my Bestie set out to take a girl to brunch, and, as Clement is my Uber fave, we decided to try Eats. The wait was SO REASONABLE. The menu is brief, comprehensive, and, every single item looked amazing!! The waitress answered all my gluten questions, and I ordered the Spanish scramble with greens. Bestie got scrambled eggs, bacon, and potatoes. I also had a hot tub of hot tea, and we both left very happy and satisfied! Loved the intimate setting, brightness of space, and the menu! A plus plus!
author: A. H.

description: I live two blocks away and have frequented Eats in the past.  They make honey butter! Even with their Grade-A wait staff, I find you it's better to do carryout, as this place has unavoidable space issues.  Don't get me wrong!  Eats' breakfasts are extraordinarily palate-soothing.  Although, you should be amenable to elbowing your neighbor and wearing earplugs to protect yours ears from infant shrills.  I'm a thin person.  If you are even slightly overweight, you won't fit past the doorway.
author: Tony L.

description: Goat cheese baguette with chopped strawberries drizzled in honey. Nuff said.
author: Tony P.

description: Great breakfast, brunch, lunch place in the neighborhood.  Kids love their waffles, I like their scrambles and their french toast.  The chicken sandwich at lunch is great that the kids have been wanting me to try.  Very friendly staff.  Get there early or plan to wait for table turnover - they're mostly busy.
author: Ketan D.

description:
This place is a bit small, so if you come when it's crowded (like on the weekend) and your party is small, you might need to share a table with others. Not really a big deal, but it's something to keep in mind. 

Either way, the food is good. I got the benedict, which was delicious. However, the waffles really take the cake (or the...batter?). They are wonderfully crisp, with just enough powdered sugar on top. I only got one as a side, and it's a little pricey considering you only get one, but it's worth it to at least try. 

All in all, it's a nice place to go to for brunch in the city.
author: Michael L.

description: I used to come to Eat's before this new owner, and was a bit hesitant to give the new Eat's a try. But, I have to say that the food here is still superb. The chicken and waffles here is amazingly good, and the eggs benedict here is also quite tasty. Good sized portions, and the staff is friendly and nice. I thought the Arnold Palmer here was a bit on the sour side though. The coffee here though is great, and they also have a good sized drink menu, including juices, mimosas, and other beverages. I will definitely come back here.
author: Mars F.

description: Loved this place.  The bacon-stuffed waffle was awesome.  The country fries were hands-down THE BEST I've ever had.
author: Amelia C.

description: We walked by Eats this morning and there was no line.  We came, we tried, and will never come back.  The food was good but overpriced.  Nothing special here.  Portions seemed small.  The service was terrible.  Diners who arrived after us had their orders taken before us, had to ask for a coffee refill, and our water came at the same time as our check.  Really a terrible first impression.
author: Peter M.

description:
I love breakfast.
I love breakfast for breakfast.
I love breakfast for lunch.
I love breakfast for dinner.

I had an ok breakfast here. Eggs were cooked perfectly, over medium.  Bacon was crispy and potatoes were salty.  Nothing spectacular. So was it worth $15 including tip? I don't think so.
author: Marisa R.

description: This place is a staple of the Inner Richmond. It has a lovely barn like interior, but it also has a hefty queue running along the edge of it 6.8/7 days of the week. It's got decent proportions and the pricing is accurate considering food. I would say my biggest disappointment was that I got overpoached eggs on my benedict. Nothing like a hard-ish yolk to spoil your long loved dish. Delicious variations on the benedicts, and since it's in my area, I'll always go back for more, but I just keep hoping I can change my review, and they will delight me like so many others before and after me.
author: Brianna S.

description:
Love the food - love the service - hate the wait on weekends. 
The key: showing up early!
author: Anita B.

description:
Dunno, which restaurant Lina S (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=VWiKYqwIr5gqekj-Ka4CpA) went to, as my experience was radically different. And Lina, your review of Ti Couz was entertaining.

Too much haterade in your diet perhaps?

At any rate, never mind the haters folks, Eats is a perfectly competent breakfast joint. I'd go there again.

- Waffles

Got the full order. Two pieces, nicely browned, warm and crispy waffles, light and airy on the inside. Reminded me of waffles I ate in Belgium. 

Def bigger in size than Chiclets, as shown in photos.

However, if you want huge portions, Eats isn't your friend. Go to Stacks or elsewhere and load up.

The typical corn-syrup based pancake syrup was just fine. Nothing special, nothing evil.

- Eggs

Sunny-side up as ordered. Yolks were still nice and runny, as expected.

- Chicken cracked pepper sausage

Delicious, with a nice kick from black pepper. Skin had nice caramelized crust from the browning on the griddle.

- Coffee

Good, fresh coffee. Strong. Just the way I like it without the hint of the tired, acrid, "sitting in the pot for hours" taste you'd get in lesser breakfast places.

- Service

Servers have good attitude. Can be a bit harried when the joint is busy. Food came out in decent amount of time- No epic wait.
author: Bono B.

description: This is a good brunch place close to the Farmer's market in Inner Richmond. The wait is too long most of the time, but it is worth it.
author: BonVivantAndMore A.

description:
Eat's food is okay... 
They like to play with food's colours, tomato and eggs which is red and yellow which makes it look more attractive, however, the food itself is ok. 

SERVICE IS HORRIBLE. the asian woman with the weird 50s glasses is impolite and rude. They really need to brush their service up. None of their personnels seemed like to have any previous training and/or eagerness to servce. They're serving breakfast for godsakes and they give you an attitude. Amazing right?
author: Vickie C.

description:
LOVE this place. 

My family & I went to Eats for breakfast on a Sunday morning, and our experience couldn't have been any better. We got there around 9, so we beat the crowd, and only had to wait about 20 minutes for our party of 6 to be seated.

The ambiance and feel of the place is cute and welcoming. Comfy like a diner..but cleaner than your typical one. They have a large variety of delicious yummies on their menu - from chicken & waffles to fancy toasts. It's so hard to choose! 

I'm a yogurt & granola girl, so I ordered their yogurt parfait with homemade granola & fruit...drizzled with honey! I was in heaven :) 
I can be picky with coffee, but I really liked theirs.

Prices are a bit higher, but really, it's so worth it. Food tastes fresh & flavorful. Good customer service.

Just go see for yourself :)
author: Andrea R.

description:
Another yummy day was had by all at Eats.  This time, on a whim my wife and I walked down here one Saturday morning, after waking up early and realizing that at this time of morning could go anywhere and not have to wait!

On this particular day I devoured an amazing fried egg sandwich and my wife enjoyed the garden scramble.  As usual, the service was great and we left feeling very satisfied.  Eats, you get weekends off on the right foot!
author: Tim N.

description: Super homey brunch spot. The Vegan Tofu Scramble was delicious:)
author: Jessica C.

description:
Good food:  Shared Banana chocolate chip pancakes and Caprese Eggs
Big portions.
Ok service.
Cramped space.
author: Antonia T.

description: First off, the food here is not that special. The potatoes were unseasoned, the waffle was bland and my scrabmled eggs were wattery. It took 45 minutes to get seated (for some reason this place stays busy), when they did call us they gave our seats to someone else! When we approached the hostess, she said it was a mistake (apparently you have less than a second to appear once they call you or you go to the "no show" list). She did immediately seat us, then we waited another 30 minutes for the nasty food. Never coming here again! I would have been better off at Ihop! One star for seating us right away after they fu**ed up. Rant over.
author: Tiarra E.

description:
Well...
I LOVED the old eats, so I might be biased. 

Here is what I loved about the old place (would have gotten more stars)
-small, but incredibly efficient staff that cooks, serves and hosted in perfect unison and with seemingly little stress
-RICOTTA PANCAKES! Those were friggen amazing
-sour dough french toast (YUM)
-HUGE omelets that left no avocado lacking
-cozy, non-pretentious feel

THE NEW PLACE
-nicer looking
-SMALLER PORTIONS, beautifully presented, but NOT AS YUMMY!
- We were 2, so they wanted us to sit at the bar?? No tables for 2 tops? They gave us one after we raised an eyebrow
-NO FRIGGEN RICOTTA PANCAKES! WTF! Why buy a place, keep the name and not take the BEST RECIPE??
-Huge, stressed out staff, so many of them they seemed to be swarming at all times, but not as organized and laid back as the old staff
-Coffee is better at the new place. Score 1 point
-WAY HIGHER PRICES FOR LESS FOOD (we used to spend $21.00 for a shared omelet and ricotta pancakes (did I mention they were my fave?) and 2 coffees... today I spent $29.00 and left with a "BLAH" feeling about the experience.

In closing:
The food is prettier and the place is prettier now... but what they got in looks, they lack in taste and service. It's in my hood, so I will consider returning...if perhaps... THE FRIGGEN RICOTTA PANCAKES RETURN!
author: Andrea S.

description:
Came here with a Professor on Sunday morning and there was a line of 15-ish people at 10:30 or so. Wait was manageable - only 15min.

I had a plate of chic sausage, waffle, and two eggs. Professor had an order of BAT with toast.

Very friendly customer service and decent food, though the latter isn't anything extraordinary. Place is cramped, so that's a small negative.

Price: $30 after tax and tip for two.
author: Jack W.

description:
My eggplant sandwich was to die for.  YUM YUM YUM!

Servers were friendly, service was good, they didn't hurry us out the door even though it was pretty busy on a Sunday morning.  

Their garlic potatoes are awesome too.

I would definitely, definitely go back here.
author: Carolyn N.

description: The restaurant is a little cute place, but creates the wait for a table that comes with that.  I found the servers to be really friendly and upbeat - which definitely enhances my dining experience.  As far as food - I went here for a brunch shortly after moving to San Francisco from RI - origin of the diner - and was a bit let down.  The prices were on the high side, and they took classic meals like eggs Benedict and tried to class them up a bit... Unfortunately, I feel like the flavors got a bit muddled and it was a bit of a disappointment compared to a solid variation of the original.  I would certainly Eat here again if I were in the area at the right time, because it is still one of the better brunches I have had, but it doesn't quite stack up to the illusive ideal brunch.
author: Virginia B.

description: Love this place, despite the occasional long wait. Service is friendly, food is great. My faves are the egg sandwich and the tomato skillet. The juices and fancy toasts are also definitely worth a try.
author: Jacob M.

description: Besides having extended waits some mornings the food is ways good! Best Huevos Rancheros!
author: Kris C.

description:
Not really sure why this place is so packed. The coffee was like denny's and waffles were hard as a rock as was their house potatos.
I'm giving 3 stars since BLT and oatmeal we ordered were decent.  A bit over priced for Denny like food tho. Service was friendly and fast.
author: Sam S.

description:
Girlfriend and I had veggie omelette and belgian waffle. Yum!

PROs:
+ Great Mom & Pop feel.
+ Very delicious food.
+ Delicious latte.
+ Counter is wicked fun to sit at - watch the cooks do their thing.

CONs:
- Seating is a bit cramped.
author: Dalton C.

description:
What a gem! A tiny little place on a corner. I just walked in here on a whim! I found a parking spot at a meter on the corner that only gave me 30 min, so I had to eat at the closest restaurant and keep an eye on my meter. 

The grilled chicken avocado salad was the best!!! It maybe the  best salad I've ever had. I'm always craving salad and I can never think of a place in Oakland that has good salad. I just wish this place was closer to home! I was a little nervous about getting the lemon vinaigrette at first, thinking it would be too tangy and citrusy. It was perfect on this salad!

Hmmm...I may actually have to make a special trip to Eats in SF next time I'm having an unrelentless salad craving.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
This is one of the cuter (or only?) brunch spots in the Richmond district. I came here with a friend for brunch. We had to write our name on a long list outside. We had to sit outside since my friend brought her dog, and since there's only 3 tables outside, we had to wait a while... about 45 minutes. Otherwise the wait would have been closer to 30-35 minutes to sit inside. 

They have many brunch options to choose from, so I chose the chorizo dish which was tasty. I'm eager to go back and try more things!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Now that some new owners are on the scene this place has gotten MUCH better. The decor is great; cozy, but chic and the counter space allows you to come in solo and still feel comfortable. 

Complimentary scones and delicious food. Can't beat it.
author: Ixchel F.

description: Terrible service.  They look busy because the service is so slow.  After not eating here in over 20 years, today's experience reminded why.
author: Anton E.

description: Love the eclectic menu. Solid food. Can't wait to try the fresh smoothies next time. Friendly and fast service. Not much for decor but I think they're shooting for a quaint neighborhood brunch spot. Nice chill vibe. Nice walkability and a 5 minute walk from my place. I will definitely be returning.
author: Roy N.

description:
This review is for the new Eats, just reopened a few days ago. 

I wasn't a fan of the old Eats although I never tried the ricotta pancakes that sounds like the one thing people really liked.  It was pretty run of the mill, nothing special at all.

The new Eats is a huge improvement!  I had the eggs benedict with spinach and portabello mushrooms for $10.  I had the potatoes with it.  I thought the portions were generous and everything tasted fresh and delicious.  The hollandaise sauce was light, I liked it better than some that are too thick and heavy.
