The english muffin was large and thin and crisp, very nice.  My only complaint is the eggs were a little overcooked, they should have been a little runny.  That's the only reason I can't give it 5 stars.

I had Ghirardelli hot chocolate for $2.75 that was some of the best hot chocolate I've had, better than Blue Bottle that I just tried at the Ferry Building, and I thought that was excellent. It is served in a small soup bowl, a very large portion.

My neighbors had two different egg scrambles with salad and both said the salads were especially nice, they loved the dressing.

The service was very good too.

The only other complaint I have is the door is difficult to close and kept getting left open a crack which caused a chilly draft.  I got up 4 times to pull it shut.

The free mini-scones are also a nice touch and delicious, served warm with jam.

I'm so glad we now have a great breakfast and lunch restaurant in the Inner Richmond.  We love our Asian restaurants, but it's nice to have something else.
author: Madeline M.

description:
a somewhat decent place to get your breakfast on (comparable to Hamburger Haven, only not as cramped)...definitely get the ricotta pancakes...soft and tender, no need for syrup.  and if you're really hungry, you better get two orders of them, i did.  it's a small place but you get lots of attention, especially when it comes to getting your coffee cup refilled.

i wish they did a remodel or got better forks (mine was really worn and rusted, had to ask for another one).
author: Emy B.

description:
I am SO SAD that Eats is no longer going to be open when I need my brunch on Saturday after a long night of drinking.

I was introduced to Eats by my friends who live in Inner Richmond, and let me tell you, their food is amazing. It's like mom's cooking when you were a little kid. I always got their corned beef hash and eggs combo, with coffee and the food was to die for. Seriously. And then, they showed me their Ricotta pancakes, and it was the most delicious pancake I've ever had in my life. EVER. 

I'm so sad this place got bought out (or so I heard) by Burma. It's not like Burma doesn't already have 2 restaurants on the same block... I will surely miss you Eats.
author: Krystinne M.

description:
Usually it's hard enough for me to wake up before 12 on the weekend, or I would end up getting some sort of dim sum.  The past weekend, my roommate and I decided to drop by this brunch joint and I'm really glad I got to try it out.  

Walking over to the place, it looked like a good ol' American brunch place.  There were already people waiting outside to get seats.  The wait for us was only about 10 min, but the service was a bit slow.  We sat down, and decided to split a seafood omelet and a side of ricotta pancakes.  Waited another 15 min, and the lady (owner?) asked if we could move seats.  We didn't mind and the seat was right by the window, so it was coo...

Food arrived shortly after that.  The ricotta pancakes were surprisingly good.  I didn't know what to expect, but it was light and fluffy with a little hint of the cheese flavor.  The seafood omelet didn't taste like an omelet but it was good!  It had a very asian flavor to it and I secretly wish I didn't have to share it.  Definitely enjoyed the choices we had.

I'll probably come back after trying a few more places in the area.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Today I was craving something decidedly unasian.  Not that I don't love me some Asian food, cuz I do but sometimes I just need a goddamn sandwich and a side salad.

I had seen Eats before and it looked innocent enough.  I hemmed and hawed over what to choose as I wasn't going to get out of there without spending at least $10.  Normally this isn't a big thing but here in the Inner Richmond lunch is expected generally not to cost more than $4.58.

Also, what kind of killed me was that they charge $0.25 for mint in your iced tea.  Now I don't normally get it with my iced tea, but if I ever did, how is a place going to charge you for adding s sprig of $2 a bunch (max) mint?

Anyways, food?  Delicious.  I thoroughly enjoyed my mushroom sandwich and tasty, tasty sandwich.  I didn't feel quite as defeated after eating the food.  In fact, I'd come back here and spend more than the norm because although it wasn't mind blowing, it is the exact cure for me over doing the Asian foods.
author: Pouria Y.

description:
Food here isn't bad, but if you want to substitute something you are usually SOL.  I used to go here about 2x per week, but haven't since I wanted something changed due to dietary reasons and the cooks wouldn't do it.  There is a sign that says "no substitutions if we are busy." Fair enough, but i was the first and only person at the restaurant.  

The request was to make the eggplant sandwich into an omelet because i wasn't eating bread- "Charge me whatever you need to make it happen."  Nope, "the cook says he can't do it."  WTF!  So I ordered the sandwich without bread and a side of scrambled eggs and made it myself at the table.    

I haven't been back since.
author: Mike P.

description:
They've recently changed owners, and changed the layout of the place. It used to be a small greazy spoon that was a standby for brunches. It was always good, never great. The new menu, layout and food has definitely changed the feel of the place. Instead of a surly older Chinese woman, you get a perky young girl dressed in black asking you about your order. 

the primary complaint? I had their fried chicken  sandwich, and the oil tasted like it hadn't been changed in some time. It smelled a little off, and wasn't that edible the next day when I wanted to have it for left-overs. Otherwise the fresh juices were great, the mini-cupcakes were delish, and I'll like be returning again to try breakfast instead of lunch to see how it turns out.
author: Kira G.

description: Initially i thought this place was just meh prior to coming here since the reviews were really mixed but this place exceeded my expectations so i was happy! Came with some friends for breakfast and mimosas. I got the mini berries and creme waffle. The portion was prettyyy small but was good. I think if i got the regular order and split that with a friend i probably would have gotten more but whatevs. We got the regular carafe mimosas which was pretty good! Neither the orange or champagne taste were overpowering so i was quite satisfied. Service was quick and efficient which was what we needed since one of my friends was in a rush to go to work. So, yay! i'm a fan!
author: Jessica C.

description:
Good experience.
Crowded at brunch-time on Saturday, and the accommodations are a bit tight.  But the service was friendly, and the fare was tasty.  Serving a few mini-scones with the meal was a nice touch.
author: Ken B.

description: I really enjoyed this place, but the people I came with, not so much. Pretty delicious, but quite overpriced. I had the basic breakfast (eggs + toast + sausage) and it was delicious. Mediocre benedict, though.
author: Michael B.

description: Place is delicious!!  I live right down the street and have enjoyed it every time I've been there.  I'd recommend the fried chicken sandwich and the BAT scramble.  The chocolate chip banana pancakes are amazing as well!
author: Kyle L.

description:
So I lived on Clement street for about 10 years before moving to Ireland. Thank goodness I got to see this place completely revamped before I left. The humble greasy spoon across the street was bought up by the same people who own and operate both Burma Superstar and B Star Bar and turned into a masterpiece. What's more... the decor is fantastic and the food is delicious! The Belgian waffles will melt in your mouth... try the fried chicken and waffle dish. I also had the salmon omelet... scrumptious! And the coffee is to die for. 

You'll have loads of fun sitting at the bar along the huge windows, people watching  as Clement street shopping commences on the weekends. What a great upgrade to the little brunch spot on Clement that needed a bit of love. Hope this place is still around when I come back for a visit.  :-D  (Sniff... goodbye San Francisco, you'll always keep me guessing!)
author: Rhatia C.

description: Nice solid breakfast food--I'm a fan!!
author: C L.

description:
On a nice sunny Saturday, a visit here will reward you with bright sun, bottomless coffee a hint of people watching and... some great food.

We waited for a table, enjoyed the sun with a cup of joe.  Service was great and the free scone was a nice touch.  Unlike other reviewers, I felt the meal size was big - we left full with food on the plate.

Why not 5 stars?  My potatoes were over-salted and prices a tad high for a bfast on Clement.  All in all, great eats and we'll be back.
author: Dave E.

description:
I've been to Eats twice. The first time was for brunch, when I ordered the Farmer's Scramble. Or maybe it was called the Garden Scramble? Goat cheese, zucchini, perfectly cooked eggs...it was just right. Bit pricy, but that's SF brunch, and I'm willing to pay well when it's made well. I also like their big, ergonomic, retro coffee mugs. Coffee was OK, not memorably good or bad.

Next time I stopped in was for lunch. My boyfriend had the egg sandwich with a side salad, and I had the eggplant sandwich. Mine was fairly good and came with a cup of house-made tomato soup on the side, but the eggplant was way undercooked (more raw than cooked). I had to actually take it out of the sandwich and essentially just had a roasted pepper/pesto sandwich. Even so, it wasn't HORRIBLE, just not what it should have been. My boyfriend's egg sandwich was great, though. 

We also ordered the "fresh-pressed" juice (beet-celery-carrot-apple). I noticed the server pouring it from a pitcher removed from the fridge, though, which to me does not embody the phrase "fresh-pressed". It tasted day-old, too. It was around $6 for a small glass, I think, which is expensive for un-fresh juice.

All in all, it's a great place for breakfast, and a good place for lunch (wish they hadn't squeezed us in at the bar near the bathroom, though...awkward). My only real advice would be to cook the eggplant properly.
author: Hillary D.

description:
No Stop! Wait but keep going! Says my stomach whenever I have eaten here.  

Sunday Funday crew rocked this place out two weeks in a row.  Simply put the food is delicious.

Recommend the fired egg sandwich, eggs benedict, or my favorite the chicken sandwich. Delicious every time!

Mimosas: They do a $20 make your own mimosa, where they give you a bottle of Champagne (not cooks or Andres!!) and a bottle of juice (apple, orange, or grapefruit).  Not bottomless but still a sweet deal if you split with a friend. 

Only four stars simply because we end up waiting 45 min each time, but fill the time easily with witty banter. 

Staff is friendly but obviously busy.  We recommend you call ahead to put your name on the list, just do not be late as they will deem you a no show and drop you back down to the bottom!
author: Elle B.

description: Wowie zowie! Came here for brunch on a Thursday (so no wait, yay!). I had the eggs benedict with mushrooms--delicious! I felt the home fries were especially notable--super crispy on the outside, soft in the inside, not soggy AT ALL. They were some of the best home fries I've had in recent history, and let's just say, I eat a lot of potato products (gross, but true). I would go back just for them.
author: Nora G.

description: Love the new decor and friendly service. The free mini scone with breakfast was delicious. I miss the ricotta pancakes from the old Eats, but c'est la vie. I had the Chicken and Waffles and they were very good. Big portion! I couldn't finish it all.
author: Julia H.

description: okay, so take a regular diner, split that ish in 1/4ths and 'voila' that's THIS place!  quaint, neighborhood diner that's very chillaxed. very welcoming, clean and can get busy.  the staff is friendly and the food is good...  HUEVOS RANmofonCHEROS!!!
author: Omar N.

description:
Extremely delicious and an amazing renovation from it's former iteration.
Love the new Eats!
I don't miss the burnt Ricotta pancakes one bit.
Friendly and courteous staff, quick service. Try sitting at the counter near the kitchen so you can watch the action.
Really good fresh fruit juice, too!
author: Rachel M.

description: Great service, come closer to 1:30p for less of a wait cuz before that the line will make you pull your hair out. BLT scramble Grama says is, "jus delicious!" My chicken & waffles are great. I'd hold the gravy or put it on the side. Fruit cup was only the good stuff & the perfect size. Fresh juice gave me good pick me up. If this wasn't so far from my house I'd be a regular.
author: Malachi G.

description: My favorite brunch in San Francisco. Why? Belgium waffles with whip cream and berries, that's why.  And when my jeans weren't fitting so well, the oatmeal with all sorts of fruits and nuts and goodies was pretty dang awesome too.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
The original Eats was pretty frickin' awesome. Greasy bomb brunches, fatty omelets, blackened carcinogenic fried potatoes, excessive slices of toast precariously crowning your plate of meat and eggs. Oh, I sorta miss it....

But the new improved Eats is ALMOST just as good. I'm glad something this tasty got put in its place or I'd be fuming crazy mad.

+ fresh new look -- no more sticky seats and ammonia spilling outta the bathroom door!

+ yummy fresh fruit juices -- i had a carrot apple that was pretty darn tasty

+ emphasis on seasonal local ingredients -- gotta dig this, even though it means smaller portions (except for the gianormous fried chicken sando). 

+ cool b-star-esque spins on the classic southern brunch dishes. LOVED my Waffle Bacon. Savory waffle embedded with whole slices of bacon with peppers and cheese topped with eggs. You'll be clean plate club for sure, so add on yummy sides. 

- only minus is that I miss the Original Eats and it was a 'cheap, get the job done' kinda place.... here not so much. it's more of a 'fancy brunch.' but on the other hand, i'm sure my arteries are thankful for less grease.

- oh ps. of course there's a long wait, just like before
author: Lauren H.

description: Really pleasant space, extremely friendly staff, great breakfast spot.
author: Charles G.

description:
Stopped by Sat looking forward to some ricotta pancakes... and when I walked in I was impressed by the renovations.  However, when I sat down I was flabbergasted when i couldn't find my ricotta pancakes :( 
Still in shock, I order the cracked pepper chick sausage scramble, which was pretty good.  It had a nice little kick to it.... but... there was no ricotta pancakes :(
author: Karena L.

description: Came here on a Sunday morning, and as expected, we had a 30 min wait( which is perfectly acceptable). The hostess was kind and polite, but the dude taking our order was a bit of a jerk. He hurried us as we were ordering, and didn't seem to oblige when we asked for basic customization (how hard is it to toss in a couple of veggies on my sandwich?!?!) . Despite insisting that everyone on the table were vegetarian, the tomato basil soup arrived promptly - only that it looked white in color and was topped with bacon. Turns out we were misinformed the soup of the day was tomato basil when it actually was a clam chowder ( so much For mentioning up front that all of us are vegetarian) . In his defense, he realized his gaffe and comped us with fruit and coffee, but the overall experience and quality of food doesn't warrant a return to this place. Fwiw we ordered a grilled cheese sandwich(average), banana chocolate pancake and waffles ( both good) , yogurt with fruit and granola(sucked) and a veggie egg sandwich (below average). If you're vegetarian and/or a stickler for a personable experience, you may want to consider alternatives.
author: Abhinav A.

description:
I always wondered about the long lines outside of this eatery and today, I wanted to find out about its cuisine.  It was a very short wait for a seat and the server was attentive.  Received my chicken & waffles promptly.  Got three coffee warm ups even though the restaurant was 3/4 full.  $17.47 for chicken & waffles and coffee, gratuity not included.

The chicken was a juicy breast party breaded in a country batter that was fried crisp.  It was dressed with a mushroom gravy garnished with cilantro.  Waffles moist and accompanied well with maple syrup.

Nice friendly service with good food.  Value not on par but Eats has a certain ambience, good for bringing a morning date.
author: Sebastian W.

description:
I live in the area and will be eating here again to give it a try but I have a couple of bones to pick:

1. I ordered the special omelette of the day which was made of egg whites, goat cheese, chives etc.  The food was not bad at all...just not very much of it. It really warranted a picture to show the scale of, say the fork to the omelette. I'm not joking. I ordered coffee which was served hot (decent by the way) maybe 10 minutes before the plate was served. I finished the omelette with 5 bites and the coffee was still hot. I'm not trying to be nit picky and lame but just showing clear comparisons for what you get and what any seasoned breakfast goer would be used to. Smaller portions are fine but I wish they would scale their pricing accordingly. Again, I will eat here again out of convenience alone but am interested in reading what others have to say. 

2. Bring cash!! I was lucky to have had some on me this morning but would have felt pretty lame to have to walk out to get some (the closest BofA branch is about 5 blocks away) I think they would like to test this to see if they can get away with being a cash only establishment as the money saved on credit card transaction fees  would add up nicely over the course of a year. 

3. Not a single inquiry about how I was enjoying or if I enjoyed my meal. Maybe they had read the previous entry by another patron who was put off by intrusive inquiries of the management. Hey, that's a good thing! That means they stay on top of this and hopefully, are willing to listen to their customers and make things right. We finally have a say people!!

Again, the food wasn't necessarily bad, it was just the quantity of it and a couple of service issues. Minor things I think they can improve on.
author: ryan s.

description: The food isn't just good--it's great. And it looks like they've upped the service recently too. I came here on a Sunday around 2pm so perhaps it's more crowded earlier--but when I showed up it was reasonably full but I was able to sit right away. I had the bacon waffle with potatoes. The bacon was crispy, the eggs yummy, and the waffle refreshingly fluffy. The coffee didn't blow my mind but it's not bad. Overall--I'd recommend.
author: Mark O.

description:
The only way to get  breakfast here is on a week day. Forget about the week-end the place is overcrowded, and there's a reason: it's good!
Great service. Great waffles, eggs, fruits and juices.
Certainly the best breakfast in the neighborhood.
author: Georges L.

description: Their fried chicken sandwich was absolutely delicious. Service is mediocre. Their blood orange mimosas are a great way to cure a hangover. The house potatoes were quite good as well.
author: Darius A.

description:
Evidently EATS opened 2 weeks ago, and they were slammed at 11:30. It didnt take long (10min) to get a table for 4, however we were competing with tables for 2.   

what we had:
GRANOLA PARFAIT--- seriously insane!!! not even a huge fan of these things, but this was PERFECTION!! the granola was unworldly (where do they get it???), and the fruit combo (dates, cranberries, blueberries, strawberries, bananas) was so sinful. the dates added a certain richness.  we ordered it for my child, and all the adult gorged. we all agreed that we would oddly go back just for that.

CHICKEN & WAFFLE-- HELL YES!!! what a show stopper. the chicken and mushroom cravy would make my southern family proud. super freakin' good!!! it is what i will order next time. the waffles could have used some fruit to counter balance the savoriness of the chicken.

FARMERS MARKET SCRAMBLE (DAILY SPECIAL)- our friend really enjoyed it. personally i didnt try it due to the zucchini. it just doesnt seem like a watery veg should be in eggs.

OPEN FACED SALMON, BRIE, & FRESH DILL OMELETTE- we were disappointed. the brie just didnt go. we pondered substituting goats cheese or something else, however we took the waiters suggestion to leave it. putting brie in an omelette just seems kinda amateur. it is the kinda thing i would have done in college when i was learning about cheese. also brie does not really go with salmon & dill. the flavors did not zing. bummer.

WAFFLE WITH FRESH BERRIES & CREAM- so delightful. normally these are overly sweet and leave you feeling heavy and bloated. this was GORGEOUS and just the right size. 

the service started slow, but in all fairness they just opened, were completely slammed, and still getting organized. we will certainly go back.
author: SF U.

description: Food, service and price are all great! Had the prosciutto eggs benedict with arugala salad w/orange vinegarette dressing $10+. Went for mothers day and got a free mini scone, mimosa & homemade peanut butter cup. Yum! Going back on my next SF visit!
author: Maria H.

description:
This is a diner. A place to get a cup of joe, eggs, potatoes and toast. Nothing more or less. My fav gal likes to go there grab her typical eggs over easy and an english muffin as I scarf down an omelet and some great flapjacks (for the both of us under 20 bucks). Then we head off to explore the stores on Clement. 

It's easy, easy like Sunday morning.
author: Ben A.

description:
This is a mediocre breakfast/brunch restaurant, nothing really special about it. I feel like they would make the dishes more physically appealing but almost all the time the ingredients come mashed up together with no finesse. I usually get the Bacon, Avocado, and Tomato but it is almost always disappointing because they give like 1/8 of an avocado. Personally I could make an omelette at home of equal quality but I'm lazy. Their breads are nothing special either, they don't have RYE or any kind of unique bread, just the usual boring sourdough and wheat and white.

3 stars because its the place I go to when I'm lazy, doesn't really deserve more than 2 stars, but the service is often pretty good.
author: Andrew O.

description:
Just ate a very late brunch at Eat's.  We got there just before closing time, thereby missing the Sunday brunch rush.  I had the special omelette, which had basil, leeks, goat cheese and sausage.  I was bummed they had ran out of chicken and waffles, but after tasting the omelette, I was over it. It was delicious.  The side potatoes were just OK and the bread was average (wish it would have been toasted).

My wife had a basic beet salad with cheese croquette.  The beets were perfectly cooked and I happily ate the three or four she couldn't finish.  I will say that $9 for a small portion size was a little high.

All in all, good experience.  I'd come back, though I'm not sure I'd wait if was very busy, which it often is around brunch time.  Solidly average breakfast place.
author: Kent E.

description: Favorite brunch spot in the city and best eggs benedict I've ever had. The food is always always always amazing and the staff is super warm and friendly. That wait has never been too bad either, I don't think it's ever been more than 15 minutes. Get the eggs benedict or the stuffed french toast.
author: Caroline J.

description:
I come here for brunch at least once a week on a weekday. This isn't a fast food diner, so don't expect your food to come fast. Usually takes about 10-15 minutes on even a slow morning, but a slow eating experience will allow you to enjoy your food more. Otherwise, the servers are very nice and attentive.

I usually get the B A T (Bacon, Avocado & Tomato) Scramble with the side salad. Simply delicious. If you have the option to get side potatoes or side salad, go with the salad. They haven't fully mastered making tasty roasted home potatoes yet. If you also come in early enough, you get a complimentary scone with your order.
author: Bonnie Y.

description:
Aesthetically simple and a bang for your buck.

On a blustery Saturday Morning, I came here with mah brew..[sorry just watched Blood Diamond]. The place was packed. We were seated in the back right next to the Coca-Cola refrigerator. Table was small and cozy, perfect for conversing with my brother and playing catch up. 

I ordered the 3-Egg Omelette consisting of bacon, green peppers, and cheese; which came with country potato's, and sourdough toast. Mah brew went with the Steak and Eggs, country potato's, and wheat toast. After a healthy wait and a enough coffee fills to quench a type 2 diabetics thirst, our plates arrived; and frankly, it was worth the wait. The portions were generous. Omelette hit the spot; potato's were soiled in grease with a crunchy exterior and soft interior; and the toast meshed well. Mah brew's steak looked morning-worthy(?) and after carnivoring the piece of cow, he was content. After all was said and done, the bill came to $20 - not bad at all.

If I found "Eats" along my path to work or in the immediate area of where I lay my head, it would be a convenient, cost-efficient, breakfast location to pick up the paper, pop in, and put down some tasty grub.
author: Andrew F.

description:
looking for a breakfast place in the richmond and landed here through yelp. Ordered corned beef hash and eggs it came with house potatoes. 
The order was huge but too greasy, so oily that when i got home my jacket smelled like i was the exhaust hood over the range. 

 You will definetely get full out of this place 

They staff greetings were very mechanical, the food took a little while to come, will prob not come back again. However the servings are big
author: DOM d.

description:
walking past this place, i never gave it a second thought. i always figured it to be like any other random diner you'd come upon. but on a sunday after walking the Kaiser 5k, a couple friends and i went for brunch. surprisingly i found us waiting outside with a bunch of other people, indicating that Eats was a popular spot. 

i ordered the eggplant sandwich because more often than not eggplant sandwiches suck, so i it was my test. turns out the sandwich was super flavorful and i was very pleased with it. my friend got the fried chicken which also looked very good. i think i'll be returning for sure.
author: Regina C.

description:
Awwww, Eats disappointed me.  I've had their omelets before and those are outstanding.  Came here with Patricia P on Saturday morning (we were both in hangover HELL) and decided I wanted to try out their lunch instead of breakfast.  

After going back and forth with breakfast and lunch, I finally decided on the BLT with homefries.  Well, my poor little BLT shows up on cold, non-toasted wheat bread that was soggy. I'm sorry, but I just had to send it back.  I receive it again and they didn't even toast it.  They threw it back on the frying pan for two seconds and it came back even soggier.  So, I ate the bacon, lettuce, and tomato off the bread and dabbled into the potatoes.  I wasn't too hungry though, so left about half the meal on my plate, which almost never happens. 

The service was GREAT though and I would actually go back for another breakfast item. SOOOO, 4 stars, just for service and BREAKFAST items.
author: Jenny W.

description:
I am so glad I live near this place! 

Every meal I have ordered here has been amazing! I just came here today for the third time with two of my friends and had one of their specials, "Apple cinnamon walnut raisin brioche french toast" and it was amazing. I love coming here, because they have such good food, the place is nice and small, and the service here is great. I always have a hard time deciding what I want to order here, because everything on their menu looks delicious. 

It does get crowded here, so be prepared to wait on the weekends but I'm just going to say that it's well worth it. I love Eats! I can't wait to come back!!
author: Lisa B.

description:
My first visit to Eats since the change in management.  I had the spinach-mushroom eggs benedict with fresh fruit on the side.  

Pros:  coffee was good, eggs arrived hot and perfectly cooked, I liked the bigger English muffins, everything seemed very fresh.  

Cons:  I'm not a fan of chipotle in my hollandaise sauce unless I'm in the mood and I wasn't today.  I would have preferred the classic lemony flavor.  And while the fruit was fresh and there was a good variety, I didn't like that they had added honey.  Service was friendly but I had to flag down a server to get water and a refill on my coffee, because nobody checked on me once my food arrived.

I may go again but not sure.  With tax and tip, I paid almost $20 (with no alcohol) and that's a lot for breakfast.
author: Cindi L.

description: Chicken and Waffles were great.  Waffles were awesome.  Crisp outside, not too doughy.  Delicious with real maple syrup.  Chicken was panko crusted and very crispy and juicy.   The gravy was not stellar and wish it were plain, not drowning in mushrooms.  Potatoes were also very good - rosemary, baked and tossed in butter.
author: Carole C.

description:
Eats was a nice surprise as I went there today for brunch the very first time with a friend. 

My friend recommended the place. It is a place he has been going to for years, until it closed briefly for renovations. Apparently it is now under new management with a new chef and has been completely remodeled. 

All very clean and welcoming. Service was excellent, helpful and friendly. Food was delicious, especially the breakfast menu. 

I had the scrambled eggs with chicken and apple, spice sausage and my friend had the pouched eggs with prosciutto. 

Presentation of the food was high quality and of course the dishes we ordered were excellent. 

Doug the chef does a wonderful job and enjoys meeting with the customers when he has a moment or two. 

Emily our waitress explained that the specialties on the menu are made fresh daily and change frequently. Some of the breads and desserts are baked fresh for that day or week. 

Cafe Latte is great, served in what is like a little soup bowl. Lots of froth and foam on top. Very satisfying! 

For today I had the blueberry scones as well as a red velvet cupcake. They were good. But the cupcakes like the scones were mini and I was disappointed about that. 

While my friend and I completely enjoyed our meal, the new remodeled ambiance as well as the excellent service, we were very disappointed by the price. 

Eats is now a very upscale place. My simple scrambled eggs and sausage cost over $9.00. I think that is a bit high. The mini red velvet cup cake was over 1.00. The mini scones were over three dollars. And when I say mini I mean really small, about the width of a quarter or silver dollar. Ha! 

Yet with a fine culinary schooled and certified chef and an all original fresh daily menu, perhaps that is the way it goes these days. 

Apparently from what my friend was telling me Eats used to be a "greasy spoon" type of place that was very inexpensive. This is why he was so surprised when he opened the door. 

Now with new owners and management, Eats has gone upscale. Locals in the area, be prepared.  No cheap meals here. 

So if you want a first class gourmet type of breakfast or brunch go to Eats. 

Open six days a week. Master Card and Visa accepted. Closed on Mondays. Place is small and gets crowded for the lunch hour from 11 to 12:30. 

Street, meter parking available outside the door. Clement Street gets busy so parking is not easy to find.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
I am giving Eats 5 stars because I received better service than I have in months.  My water glass was constantly refilled, and the staff was quick, friendly and attentive.

I have had horrible service at so many Bay area restaurants that it was refreshing to dine at Eats on a Saturday afternoon.  I had a veggie panini which I would give 4 stars, but the fries were FANTASTIC!  I also liked the array of hot sauces on each table.

Although I didn't have it, I saw a bacon infused waffle with sunnyside eggs make its way past my table and will definitely be going back to check that out.

Good little spot.  Great friendly staff.
author: Ashley J.

description: The nearest brunch place to me. Get their early! Serves amazing juices!
author: Aki L.

description:
The new Eats establishment definitely LOOKS better - but the prices? Yikes... $12 for a chicken and waffle dish and everything else is around that price as well. The prices are pretty crazy for breakfast food and there were no "regular" breakfast dishes such as omelettes where you can choose what you want in them or just a simple stack of pancakes. The menu seems like they tried a little too hard and the prices evidently show it as well.

However, talking strictly about the food... it was tasty. Was it healthy? Hell to the no. Well, what should I expect when I order chicken and waffles, right? Well, the waffle already came saturated with butter and powdered sugar with extra syrup on the side (surprised they didn't put that on there for me without asking too...) The chicken was really tasty and the gravy was good as well - but I can only imagine how bad that is for you. 

Overall, the food is tasty but will probably cause your arteries to clog if you eat too much here. Your wallet will also be suffering... I would've given this place two stars but I gave it three because the food was at least good tasting. I probably won't returning for awhile...
author: Christina B.

description:
I can't tell you the number of times Sunday Funday was had at this place. Once again, after a number of cocktails the night prior, the amazing scrambles of this place were used to sop up the hangovers and headaches. So many embarrassing and hedonistic experiences were relived at these tables Sunday at around noon. 

The scrambles here are awesome. They're huge, not too expensive and the ingredients are vast. We used to come down here about ten ppl. deep and wait outside until we could practically take over the whole spot. 

Also, this location is great place to people watch. This is where I came up with rentapuppy.com. All these attractive women would walk by on their way to do whatever. None would give guys the time of day, regardless of how attractive they were. That is, until one of those guys had a dog. If a guy had a dog, girls were all over him. I saw the ugliest guy ever get like three numbers in five minutes with that little puppy power. 

So I came up with the idea of rentapuppy.com. A guy could rent a dog for a weekend and pick up girls with it. I thought it was a great idea. Unfortunately, the Humane Society had their doubts... 

But back to Eats. Eats was a great place to have Sunday Funday Brunch. So my friends and I went there every Sunday for nearly a year. At one point, my friend was so hung over that when the waitress dumped a tray of waters in his lap, he said nothing. He simply threw up. It was amazing. 

The issue was that no matter how many times we went there, no matter how outlandish the exploits within their business, the staff of Eats would never acknowledge we'd been there before. To be treated as new customers after eight straight months of patronage is crazy. We seriously stopped going because it peeved us so much. So sad, because I really loved the food. 

So the food is excellent and the view is entertaining. But because they never acknowledged us as regulars, it must be a three.
author: Joseph S.

description:
OK Eats, Im done.  I have been to you probaly 15-20 times over the last few years and while the food is almost always good, the service is almost always poor.  I am talking to you, tall slacker white guy.  Wake up.  Its a small restaurant yet you are way out of your depth.  The other servers are usually pleasant but, alas, not good.  

To be fair, I SEE other people getting what looks like good service at times, but those people are very seldom me. I expect that someone will read this review and think I am out of my mind.  So go forth, I say. Go a few times and I wager that you will start to get into the roulette game that is Eats. You may win a few times, but in the end, you will lose.
author: Rick P.

description:
Eats has a delicious homemade feel in a simple diner setting.  The meals are fresh and the service is great!

Try the ricotta pancakes and if you do not eat meat you can always replace the bacon and sausages with fresh fruit.  There is also great coffee and freshly squeezed orange juice available!
author: Saili K.

description:
I have to agree with Christina C., that Eats is the worst brunch I've been to in the Bay Area.

First of all, we apparently walked in close to closing time (3pm, and they close at 3:30pm). We asked if they were still open, and they nodded aggressively and said "yes" with smiles. So we obliged, and sat down.

We were rushed to order. My friend and I hadn't seen each other in awhile, and I was trying to stay patiently on my voice rest, writing back to her. We were just about to stop catching up and decide what we were going to order, when, heaven forbid!, we were taking too long. Within 4 minutes of sitting down, we'd had our rushed drink orders taken (coffee, for both), and were now being forced to order. We were too scared to say we needed more time. 

The food was ready super pronto, and was average at best. (Honestly, I think Crepe Vine's omelettes on Fillmore are better, and that's akin to a chain restaurant.) 

By 3:15pm, they were already tackily counting their money and closing up shop, and it was VERY clear that we were now intruders, as the check was already on our table after they lied "take your time" when delivering it. We were basically being stared down as we ate our omelettes, and thank goodness there was an elderly couple next to us. I knew we had only as long as they did, so I was watching them as my friend and I *tried* to have a leisurely brunch. 

I'm in no way pleased with Eats. If you decide to keep your door unlocked and tell us you're still open, then once we're inside, it is not in good taste to then rush us. And as everyone knows going into the restaurant business, closing times vary, as they depend on your customers. (This, coming from a former waitress - myself.) When in a customer service industry, it's the customers that dictate your final closing time. If you're not ok with that, open a different business. Not cool, Eats.
author: Sally M.

description:
This place was pretty good before the renovation, but after eating there this morning I was totally impressed!

With all the updates it definitely has a better overall look and it seems more inviting than before, which is a huge plus.

We had the side waffles, which were the perfect size and delicious!  Also, the BAT scramble and the eggs and toast were very tasty.  Everything tasted fresh and was hot as it came to the table.  

Overall, this place is a great price for the breakfast food you get!  It is open earlier than other places and is well worth a visit!

Side note:  The mini scones served to you before the meal are AMAZING and for Valentine's Day each person was given a mini peanut butter cup with the bill.  Great way to start the morning!
author: Tressa C.

description:
This is a good breakfast place. It's not ritzy or glamorous, but it gets the job done, aka filling my belly on the weekend. 

I've never really noticed this place, but apparently the Inner Richmond is lacking on the breakfasts places if you do a search on yelp.com. My friend suggested it as our meet up spot, and we were satisfied.

First off, everything is priced very reasonably. You can special request an egg-white omelet for no extra cost, the potatoes are hearty and seasoned well, and the RICOTTA PANCAKES are delciousness. They aren't fancy and don't even look too special...but the taste and texture make up for it. The mushiness is nice and delightful...and the slight sweetness. YES. 

The wait staff was friendly and patient, but a little slow with bringing out the food/I hate when one person's food comes, and then you have to ask, "hey, what happened to her order?"

I won't be rushing back any time soon, but the ricotta pancakes continue to bring a smile to my face.
author: Misha F.

description:
We came for Q the day after Christmas. It was closed. So we wandered lost and lonely down Clement Street, forlornly looking in the windows at all the closed-down restaurants. Just as I was about to fall to my knees and yell "WHY GOD WHYYYYYYYYY?" we spotted this place. 

It was kind of like a mirage, because I had actually given up hope and was prepared to go through the rest of the day without my once a week Inner Richmond brunch fix. But this place was real. It actually reminded me of diners I would see back in Florida: Stock decor dating back to the mid-80s, fake flowers in the tables, easy listening, old people, and lots of strange aromas in the air.

The service was crazy fast, and the menu was typical. I liked it because it didn't give me too many options, which can sometimes lead to mini fits of rage. 

I ordered the vegetarian omelet and it was the size of a small baby! It was a little crispy around the edges, though. My  toast was definitely a bit of a bummer, being totally blackened and gross. But beggars can't really be choosers. Not to mention the waitress was really sweet and very good about topping off my coffee cup!

This place might actually be cooler than Q or any other nearby hip brunch place. It's got a laid-back vibe, and if you think YOU look bad with your massive hangover at 1:00 PM, look at all the people around you and you'll at least know you're in good company.
author: Pamela D.

description:
20 steps from my apartment + book + sourdough french toast, bacon & a glass of milk for breakfast = Great way to start the day...

If you want a table without waiting, get there before 10am.
author: matt m.

description:
Native kids talk a lot about what the City was like back in the day, blah blah blah. And that is the main thing that annoys me about them. (Total hypocrite alert.) It's like, everyone's experience of San Francisco is utterly different, and there was no magical glory days better than any other time. Your memories are just gilded because you were young enough that everyone was spoiling you and driving your ass around. The eighties in SF was a time of recession, shabbiness, brokedown buses and peeling paint, and $45,000 houses. Don't even try to play like it wasn't. Unless you were super rich, in which case fuck you. 

But anyway. If you want to try to get a feel for what it was like here "back in the day", you can have breakfast at Eats on Clement. 

Copious amounts of un-fancy diner food in a minimally adulterated Victorian commercial space, with pink and mint green painted moldings. I'm not sure why, but pink and mint green figure prominently in my memories of the city in the eighties. On a sunny Sunday, the diner is filled with natural light streaming through the generous fenestration, and a horde of badly-dressed regular looking people and a smattering of cops. The nostalgia is palpable in framed glamour shots of Pfleuger theaters (http://sfntf.org/ , holla!) and an illuminated night shot of the Embarcadero Center. 

The proprietorship has a sweet, friendly family vibe, and two people can get more than enough butter-soaked food for $20. And considering the bathroom is unisex (ew), it's pretty sweet in there, too.
author: Megan W.

description: Last time I wrote a review for this place was approx. 2 years ago. Well, although I miss the ambiance of the original Eats, this place is OK. Their potatoes have greatly improved in that they are cooked to a crisp with yummy garlic and eggs are very good either scrambled or overeasy. They no longer serve Ricotta pancakes but their waffle is tasty. I've only had their breakfast but they also offer lunch and mimosas, which I've yet to try! Anyways, good hearty breakfast and will probably go back to try their chocolate chip pancakes. Yum.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
really cute breakfast spot near my house.  my fiancee and i stopped by for brunch one morning and sat at a small table near the window.  the seating arrangements are a little cramped, but it wasn't unbearable.

we ordered the make-your-own-mimosas, which is basically a bottle of bubbly and a carafe of whatever juice you want - we chose grapefruit.

the food was good, but nothing that really blew me away.  i did like this toast menu item we ordered as an appetizer.  it was yummy. i would like to try EATS again, and maybe sit in another area of the restaurant.
author: Carmel U.

description:
Okay. Sometimes I can be a creature of habit.

After eating approximately 5 months of hungover weekend breakfasts in a row at Q with my boyfriend, I decided I needed to break the mold and try something different. Same restaurant, same Hippie Heaven tofu scramble with unbuttered toast was starting to get to me. On my birthday, of all days, I was going to be bold. 

And go to Eats instead.

And wait FOREVER for my food.

Which was good food, but not good enough to justify waiting forever. And the menu, the atmosphere -- they couldn't keep me entertained during forever. 

And this place isn't catering to people like me, anyway -- people with oodles of dietary restrictions. This is your typical greasy spoon diner. I would rather order Hippie Heaven at Q than have to special order the hell out of something at Eats, then ponder how much better it COULD have tasted with cheese and real eggs while they take an hour to cook it.

So now it's Sunday morning, and I'm hungry. I guess I'll go order me up some scrambled tofu.
author: Lisa T.

description:
I love Eats!!! Its so yummy! Also the decor is super cute and they have outdoor seating! Food is fresh, staff is friendly, and it isnt too pricey. 

Whenever I cant think of somewhere to go, I always come to Eats!

They also have a make your own mimosa thing, you get a bottle of champagne and whatever juice you want for $20. Apple Juice Mimosas are the best =)
author: Heather B.

description:
One Star - food tasted good, but proportions were small comparitive to price.

Other star - it was clean and tidy, but new design is less geared to couples and families. Might want change 'kid friendly' to 'no'

I didn't add the other stars basically because, aspolite as the staff is they aren't very savvy to being prompt or precise. The kitchen dominates the restaurant yet on a non- busy day, our food was cold. When I changed my egg breakfast to bacon and egg, I was charged the full price of the side order, rather than the added menu price. Basically, the place is clean, food is tasty when it's warm but there are far better places in the Richmond for breakfast. If you want a small circus on your plate and you are used to expensive micro-meals then go for it. Good restaurant but not good value for the money spent. Expect to spend $40.00 for 2 people with 15% tip (entrees, coffee and side of bacon)

I'm heading to Louie's or Seal Rock next time and save some money and walk out satisfied.
author: Edward P.

description:
I was at Eats in the Inner Richmond for breakfast.  The place has an old school feel in its decor, tables and chairs.

I ordered the Ricotta pancakes, a side of bacon and coffee.  The Ricotta pancakes had a different taste and texture than buttermilk pancakes.  They would have been good if they weren't slightly overcooked.  Also the pancakes were super thin (wow?).  The side of bacon was good.  But the coffee was weak and had a slight burn taste to it.

The service wasn't the greatest, as I felt hurried and incovenienced.   But since my check was a little over $10, worse things could happen.  It was worth a shot.
author: Janet H.

description:
The ricotto pancakes, although small, are some of the best pancakes I've ever had. And I make a pretty mean pancake....

If you come early enough, there isnt a wait and you get your food quickly. But come after 9:30ish and the service slows down exponentially.

Nonetheless, the guacamole omelet on sundays is delightful (hold the onions, they put a lot in them). And if you love seafood, I recommend the seafood scramble over the seafood omelet (less greasy).

And a decent breakfast/brunch place isnt complete without freshly squeezed OJ, which they do indeed have.

So in the end, the food is what you can expect from any good family run restaurant, but the service needs to more consistent to get another star from me.
author: Justin H.

description:
Went here for brunch last weekend and was pleasantly surprised. Around noon the wait was short for a table for two. I had the French toast special, and the server suggested adding more home fried potatoes when I said I didn't want the 2 eggs. They used sourdough bread to make the French toast, and it came out really thin and a little crispy, but not in a bad or a burnt way. The sausage was good too.

My friend loved her ricotta pancakes and bacon. Other brunch places are more gourmet, but this place serves good food at a reasonable price.
author: Timothy O.

description:
I've been to Eats a couple of times now and I quite enjoy it. It IS a redeeming spot on those cloudy mornings though I've found myself there on sunny days and quite enjoying the people watching from the window.

PROS:
- Like any diner, the menu is WAY too long with too many choices. But hey! I've been adventurous and love the Denver omelet, the Farmer's omelet and of course, the Ricotta pancakes. The rest of the menu I'll try when I'm running a marathon the next day!
- If you come there often enough, the staff know you and its a great family atmosphere
- The food is not too much on the greasy side (Denny's and IHOP) and portions are generous. I liked the food overall
- Price of course, is pretty cheap and you get more hash browns for your buck
- Got a hangover? Got to eat and don't want to spend too much money? Want to go to a local place to get carbed up before your bike ride in the Headlands... head here. I do it all the time... ok... twice a month

CONS:
- There can be a wait on weekends but that's because its a popular place for the locals
- Coffee can sometimes be a bit... rough around the edges
- The service can be spotty... waited 20 minutes for an omelet. But I'm the patient kind so did not really mind it at all
 
Overall, I'm a sucker for locally and family run establishments. I love the lady who runs its and its a nice place to go to for a change.
author: Amit S.

description:
Talk about breakfast all day, whenever you wake up. I love it. If I could have it my way, I'd eat breakfast for dinner. Eats is a nice local spot that I stopped by. I decided that I've had too much Vietnamese and Chinese food lately, and wanted to scope out the breakfast food in the Richmond District.

Inside, the interior seemed very clean and it had a touch of that working class restaurant from the 60's. I thought the establishment was very clean.

The pricing isn't too bad. It's about a buck or two more than most places, but the food tasted pretty good. It's pretty hard to mess up on eggs and stuff, but I've been to places where they couldn't scramble eggs for shit. I ordered the special on the wall. "Cajun Sausage with two eggs, bread choice, and home fries". Oh, and a side order of corn beef hash of course. Yum.

The food arrives, and it's hot, fresh, and smelling damn good. The cajun sausage sort of just tasted like a Louisiana hot link in my opinion.. but I LOVED the home fries. They were chunks of potatoes fried to a cripsy charred nugget. Some people won't like it because it'll be too greasy and oily and junk, but it sure did hit the spot for me. You see, I was currently recovering from a hang over from last night, and plus it was my first meal since 4am, at about 3pm. 

The corned beef hash was pretty good as well. They seared the top layers, and it had a crunchy outside versus most places serving corned beef hash as a slop of stuff. 

I'll be coming back here to check out more stuff on the menu. Good breakfast for the win!
author: Andrew W.

description:
RICOTTA PANCAKES!!!

This is the phrase that is commonly shouted- in a Tourette's kind of way- at 6am by my fellow nurses towards the end of a long night shift. Because sometimes it is only the anticipation of those buttery, luscious rounds of goodness that pushes us through those painful wee hours of the morning. Only the best of comfort foods can quiet our minds and ease our pain- and ricotta pancakes accomplish this task quite well.

p.s. also great for hangovers.
author: Britt W.

description:
Went to check out the newly renovated Eats and I have to say I was impressed! The wait wasn't that long for 11am on a Saturday (15 mins) and once we were seated and our waitress promptly appeared as we were ready to order. 

My friend and I both had the best breakfast a BACON WAFFLE smothered in cheese and these delicious mild red peppers and topped with two eggs sunny side up! Absolutely delicious... and you can chose your side of fruit salad, home-fried potatoes, green salad or even french fries. I also had the fresh fruit juice of the day which was granny smith apple and carrot. Very tasty and refreshing and would have ordered a 2nd glass had it not been $3.75. 
We never had a problem getting our water glasses refilled and the waitress brought the bill promptly after we were finished with our meal but didn't feel rushed to leave. 

Make sure you are seated before noon as you get complementary mini scones with homemade jam when you are seated. 

I'm definitely looking forward to going back soon!
author: meg r.

description:
Very disappointed at the handling of wait list outside door. I've been a hostess and know that it's impossible to predict exact wait time, but when you see a family with a small child, I think it's worth trying to come up with an honest time estimate rather than the generic 15-20 minutes, which leads to 15-20 minutes more and so on. 

Having a friendly smile is nice, but I'd rather have someone be more realistic and smile less. Offering coffee while we wait triple the amount of time and then charging us for it (3.95 for two luke warm cups) when we tell you that we can't wait another 20 minutes seems like really poor customer service...plus a long-winded explanation of how it's impossible to predict wait time vs. a genuine, 'sorry we were so off, hey -- the coffee's on the house' would have been more appropriate.

Left a bad taste in my mouth.
author: J M.

description: Nice little breakfast and brunch spot. Had the Spanish scramble, didn't look like it would be enough given that I was extremely hungry, but it filled me up and was tasty at the same time. Had a good experience.
author: Joshua M.

description: Service was good but the food took a while to come out. It felt stuffy, cramped and oily inside (I went during peak brunch hour), but the food is pretty cheap at about $7 a dish. Nothing outstanding.
author: Jonas T.

description: I LOVE EATS.  I live half a block away from it and steered clear for months because there's always a wait to get in, but after trying it I realized it's worth the wait (especially for the chicken and waffles).  One caveat - this is NOT a good place to go in a group.  It's a tiny restaurant and there's a wait even if you're in a party of two.  Anything larger than that and you're bound to be standing on the corner of 2nd and Clement for quite some time.
author: Allison D.

description:
Ugh. I wanted to like this place so much.  But alas, I cannot... Problem #1 cramped space, too many kids - even on a weekday morning when they should have been in school.
 
Problem #2, unseasoned, bland eggs topped with something dry and green, which could not be identified due to dryness and lack of flavor - felt like twigs. Is this why there were so many condiments on the table? To encourage you to compensate for the lack of flavor?  

Problem #3, ordered Chicken Sausage as a compliment to the eggs, they sliced it in half before cooking it, and then turned it into jerky - what a disappointment - truly horrible, had to saw through it like wood, then left it anyway.  It was inedible.  What a waste of the up-charge. 

Tangential rhetorical question...why do this? Is is because restaurants are afraid to cook a sausage properly, serve it whole, and potentially have someone burned when cutting into it?  It is sacrilegious to cut a sausage in half before cooking it... However, I do not entirely blame restaurants for this...I blame lawyers, and people who whine over being burned by delicious cased meats.  People, properly cooked cased meats can be dangerous - suck it up and risk the burn - it must be cooked whole to taste good.  If you are burned, shine it on and leave the restaurant alone - or order bacon, otherwise we will all end up eating cardboard cased meats.  

Back to Eats... Problem #4, flaky service, brain seemed to be shut off, we would ask for things, get the "sure, no problem" and then the individual would commence clearing other tables, wiping up, getting checks, and standing around before having to be reminded about what we just asked for - this is with no one waiting to be seating.  This would have been understandable if there was a line, but with no line...folks, people first, cleaning second.

A positive, the whole cloves of roasted garlic in the potatoes were an interesting addition.
author: Kate M.

description:
Warning: This isn't a food review... unfortunately we never got that far.

So my friend and I decided to go exercising early Saturday morning since... well let's just say we're a little sick in the head.  Unfortunately the San Francisco weather was too cold and foggy (yeah I know shocking), so we cut our exercise short (as in we didn't even start) and decided to try out Eats.  They were supposed to open at 8am and we got there at 7:52am.

So there we were in t-shirts and shorts just chilling (hahaha) in front of their door trying VERY HARD to make eye contact with the woman setting up the place;  putting on the sorriest expression I could imagine and hoping to convey the fact that I just lost feeling in my left nut.  Sorta like I do at 2am in a club after a long night of drinking and it's last call and I realized I just spent 3 hrs and about $500 worth of alcohol just chatting with my roommate in college.  You ladies know, one of THOSE PATHETIC stares.  And of course it doesn't work at 7:52am just like it doesn't work at 2am.  She studiously avoids looking at us even though my teeth are chattering so hard people thought were were taking a jack hammer to the side walk.

Eventually an employee shows up and tries to go inside.  Of course she then RUNS over to the door to make sure we don't get in 3 minutes before they are scheduled to open and slams the door in our face as I say, "Could I just wait inside?"  She then goes about ignoring us again.  Bad bad customer service, BAD!  If I get feeling in my nuts again I might bump it up to two stars.

Needless to say we decided it wasn't worth it and left.
author: Kuan K.

description: I love this little spot.  It used to be this funny greasy spoon but someone bought it and turned it into the long awaited breakfast spot of the Richmond. I like the healthy options for when I want to go light.  Other times I just go for the bacon and waffles, seriously, everything in moderation including moderation I always say! The staff there is fantastic. I always feel welcome to sit at the little breakfast bar as long as I want.  Thanks Eats!!
author: M S.

description: I love eats! Their blueberry pancakes are to die for as well as their veggie egg sandwhich! Their waffles are rather small, but the portions are big enough to fill you up. Everything is really good quality and the people who work there are all great.
author: Hannah H.

description:
This place is a disaster.  I was was hoping to give Eats another chance on our second visit (yes, the first time was bad too) - ugh,  bad mistake.  

They took 41 minutes to get us our rather simple breakfast.  The bacon was overcooked, homefries burnt and my pork chops (the menu says grilled) was fried and as hard as a rock. And service was hurried, almost rude.   

For the price, they really don't offer a bargain.  I could pay 2 more dollars per plate and get a much better breakfast at Ella's - or even pay less at the grungier but tastier Eddy's Cafe on Divis.  

We supposedly scored a table by the window - big mistake.  There were several extraordinarily large flies (they looked like they had over-sized channel sunglasses on) on the glass window.  And some dead ones on the window sill down below.  By the time we left the feeling in my tummy matched the food - disgusting!
author: Clarice V.

description:
Breakfast and lunch are fantastic. Just the type of place you want in your neighborhood. The service can be slow but the quality of food is always consistently top notch. They do waffles like nobody else. The menu is inventive, ingredients fresh and portions large.

Bring a book or some friends though smaller parties seat faster of course. Arrive before 10:30 and the wait will be fine. Note the make-your-own mimosa, give the "waffle bacon" serious consideration or choose "Zoe's sandwich" for a spicy, in-a-league-of-its-own take on breakfast sandwiches.
author: J C.

description:
Nothing to complain about. The price is right for what you get, and the food is decent. I came here at 10:30 on a Saturday morning, parked right out in front, was seated right away, and enjoyed an early afternoon going down Clement to the Green Apple still-going-out-of-business-clearance sale.

Home fries are nothing special, just potatoes. The corn beef hash is not enough beef and too much hash. So it's either terrible corn beef hash, or very excellent hash, depending on whether your glass is half-full or half-empty.

Service is friendly.
author: Rob T.

description:
Pros: Best breakfast in the neighborhood, they do eggs well, modern menu, efficient staff.
Cons: Gets crowded and cramped on weekends. A bit pricey for breakfast places. Staff can get overwhelmed when it's super busy. But they're busy for a good reason...
 
I'd give it 4 stars because of the cramped-ness and because they took ricotta pancakes off the menu- but I'm giving them 5 because they're currently tied with "Hamburger Haven" down the block and that's plain silly. This place has much better food.
author: David F.

description: One of the best sunday funday breakfast spots to go to! No matter what you're in for, after a day of hard core drinking and in the mood for some tasty waffles, or just to enjoy a great morning with some friends over an egg skillet, you are in for a real treat! All the food on the menu is delicious, the staff is beyond friendly and it's a great neighborhood spot where you can sit outside and people watch if the weather is nice.  The mimosas are the way to go if you're feeling thirsty! I highly recommend Eats to everyone, it's never been a disappointment to me.
author: Alexa V.

description:
Eats is actually a really cool name for a diner. Admittedly, that was probably the main reason why I stopped here for breakfast.

This place is so homey, they even burn the potatoes, just like mom used to. It's basically a greasy diner, with only two waitresses if memory serves, so it takes a little while to get your food. It's best to go here on a lazy Sunday, when you've got all the time in the world and want some good, typical comfort food. 

It's cheap, it's comfortable, it's in a nice neighborhood! Go to Eats!
author: Anna H.

description:
I absolutely love this place. They have ricotta cheese pancakes that are to die for. I was eating them enough that I had to figure out how to make them before I bankrupted myself, I was addicted (and I sort of figured it out...mine aren't as good as theirs though).

This is my go-to breakfast place, especially after an exciting night when you roll out of bed at the crack of 11 and want something substantial. The home fries are excellent, the eggs I've had are good, my roommates and our friends and I eat here pretty often and I've basically never heard a complaint. Also, if you want to order takeout you can just call them and say you want to order to go. This can be nice because it tends to get pretty busy on the weekends.
author: Valerie K.

description:
Came here on a saturday with the gf and her family. We waited maybe 10 minutes, and it was about 10am. Already there were people eating inside, and the place was almost full. That's a good sign. Also, it seemed that these were people who lived in the area. That's another good sign.

So I had the cajun sausage with home fries and eggs with toast. It was a good breakfast, and I felt content with the portions served. I have yet to try the pancakes, but if I get a chance again when I'm in the neighborhood, I'll do so. Tasty and filling, but not super greasy like some other cheap breakfast cafes I've been too.
author: Clinton L.

description: I had the chicken and waffles, yesterday, and it was sooooo good.  The chicken was so tender and juicy, the gravy was delicious.  Oh the waffles were worth waiting for last, soft and crispy on the edges, delicious!  We went early and were seated in less than 10 minutes!  The staff is so friendly.  I am a new fan!  I wanted to come back after a few hours had passed!  I love EATS!  I am going to try everything on the menu...
author: Thuy N.

description: Stopped by Eats with a few friends while we were in San Francisco and we all enjoyed te experience. The food was delicious and the service was great! Will definitely return when I am back in the area.
author: Pitchfork T.

description: standard breakfast/brunch, certainly nothing special. not sure why everyone raves about the chicken and waffles, maybe they've never had real down home chicken and waffles before? i personally thought they were just ok and probably wouldn't order them again. they have the advantage of being one of the only brunch spots in the inner richmond, but charge mission brunch spot prices for pretty average food.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
East is amazing. A-MAZING.

First off, they have fresh squeezed orange juice, not that crap from concentrate.

The two best things in the menu are by far the Ricotta Pancakes and the home fries.

The pancakes are so delicious! They're a little sweet and must have a ton of ricotta in them because they just melt in your mouth. They come very brown which is how they should be. I like my food COOKED, which is what they are.

The home fries are also amazing. They are cooked all the way through and crispy, which means they are actually cooked to order, not cooked in mass quantities to be left in a heating dish to get soggy. Good home fries are hard to come by, I asked the waitress what they do and she says they season them with Jamaican seasoning. Good call, Eats.

I can never bring myself to order anything else because I love the ricotta pancakes so much, but my friend got a veggie omelet that I tasted and was delicious and LOADED with veggies.

Go here! It's the best breakfast on Clement!
author: Lindsay W.

description: Pretty good.  Food was decent.  Had the Huevos Rancheros, they were good but nothing to write home about.
author: Kris K.

description: Loving it. Another great addition to the neighborhood thanks to the Burma SS crew. Very good food and coffee, awesome ambiance and not too expensive.
author: Robynne W.

description:
Eats:  Because sometimes you just want a greasy ass breakfast.

For under six bucks, you can get a huge plate with an omelette, a side of potatoes, and toast.  The wait can be a bit slow, but the staff more than makes up for it with their excellent service.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Food is GREAT....you MUST have some homefries; they are the best thing here...crispy, cooked, not overdone...overall yummy!  Everything else is great too, service can be hit or miss, but they are water and coffee nazis!  They will refill if you like it or not!  Food is cheap, but really tasty.  During the week, prices are lower!

EDIT: Umm, So, homefries and the Sourdough French Toast are my favorite meal. mmmm carby deliciousness!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Being taken over by Burma Superstar, I had to see how they take on American breakfast/brunch.

The way they make their chicken and waffle is much different than others I have had in the past. It's almost like a chicken katsu smothered in gravy and mushrooms. It's good to have once in a while but I prefer the old fashion chicken and waffles. The waffles are pretty good though, fluffy and delicious.

Everything else on the menu is pretty much your normal breakfast/brunch shop. Omelets, Benedict, they're all pretty good.

I come here once in a while when I don't want to venture too far for some breakfast food.

Great staff, as well.

Quite enjoyable, indeed.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
What?? $2.75 for a diner-quality cup of coffee??? Who charges that in a diner/cafe?? Sneaky, Eats...very sneaky and cheap. Most of us in our excited anticipation of brunch don't look at the price of a cup of coffee - at least I expect it to be no more than $2. When we got the check I was pretty irked by this bill. 
The food was decent but also a bit on the pricey side. My fried egg sandwich was tasty but greasy. I will say the potatoes were very tasty and garlicky. Still, the coffee thing bugged me and kind of colored the rest of the experience. I won't make the effort to go back.
author: J L.

description:
The name Eats is not sufficient for this place: at the very least it should be called "Good Eats," some might argue that "Great Eats" would work as well.  

I know these reviews say to get the ricotta cheese pancakes.  Well folks, I read the reviews informing me of this fact as well but I thought, "No, I don't really like pancakes that much...and with ricotta cheese?  I'm not sure if I can hang with that."  Just let your inner critique go and do yourself a favor and order them; unless you are lactose intolerant of course, or allergic to wheat (etc. etc. in which case I would like to offer my sincere apology that you will never experience this flavor upon your taste buds).  

One note of caution: be careful when asking to substitute one thing for another in an omelet.  I think that I substituted turkey for bacon and added mushrooms and they charged me an additional $5 which was very uncool.
author: Katie O.

description:
So here's the deal. SF doesn't really have a lot of breakfast places. I can think of like 4. I'm sure there's more than 4. But Eat's was kinda in my old neighborhood. They have any kind of scramble I want and really really good french toast. Parking is decent. Waiting sucks, but I always expect it. They have diet coke. And water. Two things I love when I'm hungover. 

So... when Q's line is longer and you find a spot closer to Eats and you look really really hungover and don't feel like standing around all the 'hungover' and showered Q people, come to Eats. They have lots of egg dishes and some other stuff. They are quick once you're in there. They almost always serve food in order of who ordered it. So if you are the only starving one, order first. It'll take about 2-3 minutes for the waitress to carry the rest of the plates out to your table. 

The place is dingy inside but the bathroom is decent. Don't be scared to eat their food because they can't decorate.
author: Ali R.

description:
Nice breakfast/brunch alternative to Denny's and Mel's.  The menu consists of  your typical breakfast dishes, omelets, and sandwiches.  

I had the ham and cheese scrambled eggs which came with toast and home potato fries.  The eggs were a little oily but was still pretty good.  Good brunch for less than $10.
author: Danny P.

description:
litmus- eggs over medium, potatoes, breaking the yolks with the corners of my toast.  the eggs were beautifully cooked, not greasily bubbled or brown chewy.  the potatoes are deep, then pan fried, with whole cloves of garlic thrown in the mix, and chopped scallions to garnish.  a slice of cantaloup, and one slice of toasted sourdough.  the coffee was good.  nice selection of hot sauces, and and salt and pepper grinders! 
my husband got oatmeal with a side of fruit, and he ended up eating a lot of fruit, because the oatmeal already arrived with a huge mound of seasonal sweet melons, berries, and bananas.
the decor is really sweet and warm with lots of wood and rustic barn touches.
funny thing, its cheaper and so much better than mels a coupla blocks away. 
thanks for reading!
author: yayoi s.

description: This is the best breakfast food , in the city that I have eaten at thus far. Whenever I have visitors in town, I always take them to Eats because of it's quality , and its variety of food . It has a nice comfy/ home feeling to it, and delicious coffee that is served in the cutest mugs. I highly recommened Eats , if you are looking for a qualiity breakfast!
author: J O.

description:
My boyfriend and I got sick of the moody ladies at Joe's Cafe and were in the market for a new breakfast place. I've passed by Eats and love the name. So simple. With a simple name like that, you know it's gotta be just simple good food - what a good breakfast should be.

I was glad to find out that Eats is definitely simple good food + a hint of creativity. Here's the forumla:

To die-for RICOTTA pancakes + yummy perfectly seasoned home fries (made from sweet potatoes?) + 4 (yes, i said FOUR) pieces of bacon = (besides a heart attack) super awesome breakfastness.

My boyfriend had the corned beef has which was also awesome. So important for a breakfast place to have good corned beef hash!

And yes, the service was nice (although it took a long time to get our food) - but I think we were just unlucky cuz there was a rush right after we came in. So I will excuse it for now. But at least there were no dirty looks when my boyfriend asked for ice with his water. That's a good sign.
author: Bonnie H.

description: Went to Eats today for the first time in years. I love a good breakfast!!  I ordered the spicy polenta which came with a sausage. I have to say it was horrible. I thought I had accidentally ordered the tomato basil soup it was so runny. The sausage was small and sitting in a soup of runny polenta with some sort of sauce. Somewhere underneath this mess was an egg. There was no toast, potatoes, anything to mop up this soup. Maybe they should offer this dish with a soup spoon because that is the only way to eat it. My wife ordered chicken and waffles. The chicken came smothered in a gravy and the waffles were small. From now on I'll go to Northbeach to eat at Mama's so much better.
author: Tina P.

description: I take it back! We went a couple weekends ago, sat outside (which seems to be a must since it's so hot in there) and we ordered right and my breakfast was DELISH! We're fans of Eats now and understand the great reviews. Yum!
author: Jessica H.

description:
Just left the new Eats, and I'm stuffed. I don't know what everyone is saying about small portions, my plate was full and now my belly is too.
We showed up on a Sunday around 1:30. They were pretty slow, only a few tables were taken, so they were nice enough to substitute tomato and avocado for the spinich and mushrooms on the Eggs Benedict. When it came out I was totally surprised. It was beautiful. I've never seen an English muffin that huge! Big enough to hold 2 eggs! It was perfectly golden brown and buttery. The eggs were wonderful, too often I get runny whites, and I hate that, but not here. The holindaise sauce was light and buttery, only complaint there is I would have liked a little more of it. There was melted and browned cheese on top of the avocado and tomato, and the veggies were fresh and tasty. I have to admit, this is the BEST eggs Benedict I've EVER had. And I get eggs Benedict every where I go. It's my test to see if they're good cooks. And this one beat Zazzi by a mile. The potatoes were good. A little spicy and flavorful. My boyfriend had the biggest chicken sandwich I've ever seen. He loved it. Couldn't stop raving about it's sheer awesomeness. And the fries were damn good. Perfectly cooked and seasoned with cracked sea salt. All this and I haven't even gotten to the coffee yet! If any of you remember the coffee that the old eats served, you'll agree that it was warm brown water. More like tea than coffee. I don't know what kind they're brewing there now, but it's wonderful. Strong and flavorful. And bottomless. Our water was refilled so many times my glass never emptied. Our check was dropped off when she picked up our plates. It wasn't cheap, $28, but it was so good we left 2 $20s and didn't want change. (I hope they tip out the cooks.)
I love the new decor too. It looks great in there. Although anything is better than the old Eats. It was next to awful before. When I go out, I want food that I can't make for myself, and the old Eats made food that was worse than what I can make at home. The new Eats makes AWESOME food I definitely can't make or myself. Good job guys. We will absolutely be back. Hopefully at a non-busy time so I can get my tomato & avocado Benedict again. Yum!
author: Joy T.

description:
Been here three times in one month and ordered the same seafood omelette for $8 each time.    

They serve breakfast all day on weekends, but weekdays they have sandwiches and such.  I will try their egg salad sandwich next time.

It's the cheapest, most filling, and wholesome (albeit greasy) omelette $8 can buy.
author: Mrs F.

description: I guess I'll give this place 3 stars instead of 2.  I drove all the way here from San Mateo because i was seriously craving Ricotta Cheese pancakes as only the old Eats could provide.  When I walked in, I was disappointed not by the uber cool decor and new faces, but that these new owners didn't even keep the classic recipe in their menu. Bah humbug!  But I ordered a juice, coffee and dessert/breakfast.  The waffle was smothered in whipped cream, but I ate it and left.  It's basically another posh S.F. restaurant when I was in the mood for something old-school, familiar, classic, and delicious, vs. "The food might be good, but these prices are paying for the new decor."  Seriously bummed.  Might visit another time...but it won't be for a long time.
author: Elena F.

description:
The best huevos rancheros I've had outside of Mexico - perfectly cooked sunny-side- up eggs, flavorful beans (but not crowding the plate or overpowering), delicious smoked bacon, fresh avocado and crisp tortilla. Coffee was excellent. Probably the best breakfast choice in the Inner Richmond.

Downsides: as people have noted it's crowded and service can be slow. Note: it would not be jammed full if the food were bad.
author: Ben S.

description:
This isn't the best breakfast place you'll eat at, but with that said, it does have a few redeeming factors, and you can have a completely enjoyable dining experience--as I commonly do--if you just know a few things.

1.  The eggs, they're not great.  But they are more like poorly home-cooked eggs, than shitty Denny's eggs.  Neither are the home fries.
