2.  R I C O T T A     P A N C A K E S!!!!!!!!!!!!!     I should have written that as number one because they are absolutely the best pancakes I've had in my life.  I challenge anyone who wrote a bad review to try the RCs and see what they think.  Nuff said.

3. There aren't many other places you can sit down to have coffee and pancakes in the inner richmond on those lethargic cloudy mornings.  (Lucky Penny? Video Cafe? No thanks).

An extra star for the family-business feel, and I hope this was helpful. Please, if you live in the inner richmond, you owe it to yourself to try the ricotta cakes.
author: David B.

description:
Solid standby breakfast spot. I love how the younger waitress, who is easily 5 years my minor, calls me "sweetie," "darling" and "hon." What's wild is that, despite the fact that I'm older than her and she's (I think) of Korean descent and therefore looks nothing like Flo from Alice's Restaurant, not to mention the lack of bouffant hair and gum-snapping, this exchange feels perfectly normal and every time she does it, I feel like I'm in America's heartland where fields and roads run forever and truckers pull into all-night diners for a little moment of human contact. 

Yeah, I like the food at Eats, but what I like even more is the attitude.
author: Hannah Q.

description:
It looks like a little brunch place in a pretty neighborhood.  In reality, it's a greasy spoon in classy clothes.  
The food is good if you like it salty and greasy.  I fucking love it that way but I was annoyed at the difference between how it looked and what it is.
author: Patrick A.

description: I've been wanting to try this place out since I spotted it about a half year ago during my weekend grocery run.  Seems like its always packed for brunch, with promising smells wafting from its closed doors. Homey feeling inside.  Menu selection is relatively limited - more of an omlette/scramble type place (though my friend seemed pleased with her ricotta pancakes).  I got the three egg omlette with mushroom, spinach, and added some ham - heavenly - not too salty, plenty of unami flair with no msg side effects (I didn't feel the crazy thirst/lethargy that goes with msg peppered food).  I was happily surprised by the potatoes - I'm a hash brown girl, and tend to scoff at country/home potatoes, but these reminded me of patatas bravas (sans cheese sauce and beer), crunchy on the outside, soft inside, with no annoying frills to detract from the taste of potato.
author: Shinny L.

description:
Back in my San Francisco days (*wistful sigh*), Eats was a bi-weekly late breakfast ritual.  Parking isn't too bad that far up Clement, especially if you get there on a Sunday before the other shops open.  

The omelettes are fluffy and delicious, with good stuff in 'em.  Choose from the creative selection, or build your own.  I recommend avocado in an omelette, because hey, anything is made more Californian with avocado.  (It's like cowbell, but for food.)

I also wholeheartedly recommend their pancakes; ricotta pancakes are absolutely wonderful, as are their cornmeal pancakes.  

The coffee, while not mind-blowingly special (but certainly tasty) keeps on comin'.  That's always good.

Vegetarians and meat-cravers (hhuhh huhuhhuh) will be equally happy here.

Friendly but efficient waitstaff, plus a fairly quick table turnover make this place a great way to start a productive weekend day.   

It's worth the short wait.
author: Jill K.

description:
This may seem like a good hangover breakfast place but BEWARE - they brought out our plates AS THEY MADE THEM. I got mine first and my friends insisted I start eating because it would get cold, probably thinking theirs would be out in a minute or two. 3 minutes later, another dish comes out. 3-4 minutes later, another plate comes out. And so on. 

So, the time between when I got my food and the last of my friends got her food was about 15 minutes. That's ridiculous! Everyone was sitting there suffering, trying to fill their stomachs with the endless supply of coffee while waiting for their headache-saving omlettey goodness.

No matter how good the food is (4 star), there is no way I'm going to wait like that for breakfast.
author: Ali L.

description:
Eats sucks.

For real people, I don't understand what all the great reviews are for.

Ok, ok, so I've only been there once but it was bad enough where I don't plan on returning unless I get really lazy (since it's on the next block over).

I already hate homefries (but I LOVE hasbrowns, how come there are barely any people who serve them??) but cold, burnt homefries are worse. The eggs were like plastic. I KNOW IT'S DINER FOOD PEOPLE. I don't have a problem with grease (and this place has plenty) but this place just sucked. There are way better diners that are dirtier and better tasting, trust me.

It wasn't even cheap! And there was a wait! The ricotta pancakes could've been amazing if they weren't burnt black. The waitress was sweet but she was alone, running to all the tables. We waited a long time to even get our order taken.

Oh, and the coffee sucked :(
author: Salina Z.

description: Not good and not going back.  Poor service, cakey pancakes, mediocre coffee.  Enough said.
author: Barbara S.

description:
OK. This place is all the rage among "some" locals. I figure being in the richmond for the last 10 years and I hadn't been there I wasn't missing much. Anyway, the wife and I had to drop off the vehicle for a couple of hours on Geary so we decided to walk around a bit and get a nice breakfast. 

Got to Eats and waited about 10min to get in. No biggie. We get inside and they sit us at the smallest table known to man in the front window. First of all I'm a pretty big guy so needless to say our knees were making out. First strike.

Waiter looks and acts like he is developmentally disabled and is lost in the rush of all the goings on. Right fucking then and there I got the bad feeling. He half ass takes our order and moves on. Strike two.

Unlike many of the reviews here we surprisingly didn't have to wait that long for our food. Granted it was after 11am. I see dumb ass waiter walking around from table to table looking lost with a plate in his hand and he finally picks me to bestow the honor upon. Well low and behold his lack of attention led to my order being incorrect. At that point I just sloped it up and tried to get the fuck out of there asap. Wasn't impressed by the quality of the food either. Strike three, you're out.

On the plus side (the one star) my wife did like her omelette.

Needless to say we won't be going back any time soon, or ever for that matter.
author: Natas N.

description: Love the chicken & waffles and the tri-tip sandwich.  People are great.  NEED A BURGER ON THE MENU!
author: David k.

description: My boyfriend and I have been coming to Eat's for years. Their service and food quality stays consistent, however today's experience was extremely disappointing. They seemed to hired some new faces who tend to lack professionalism and skills. First off, we put our names on list and as I looked in there were plenty of empty tables inside, maybe 8, that were not cleaned. I asked how long the wait will be, the waitress replied, "15 mins." I said, "Why is the wait 15 minutes when you have so many empty tables?" Another waitress replied, "We trying to get them all cleaned." We didn't say anything after that. However can see they were obviously clueless how to properly arrange seating because the waitress kept asking the waitress who in charge of the seating how to seat people. After waiting for 5 mins, we were seated towards the back of the restaurant. As soon as I sat down, I noticed a used fork on the bench that had food smudge all over it (gross... ). I immediately called the wait staff over to hand and told them about the sticky fork. Embarrassed, she immediately removed it. Secondly, The tables were sticky (my coffee mug kept getting stuck on table every time I tried to lift it). We waited nearly 15 mins before they offered us water and coffee. I ordered the eggs Benedict with ham and asparagus and my boyfriend ordered the spicy tomato skilled with kale with a side of sausage. When our food arrived, they accidentally gave my boyfriend the pulled pork hash (mind you, he can't have pork for medical reasons). It was the cook from the back that served the food. Luckily my boyfriend confirmed what it was and had them take it back right away. My eggs Benedict was good, yet the ham was overly salty. I liked it but then knew I wasn't over exaggerating because my lips felt weird (too much salt). My boyfriend chicken apple sausage was  burnt and after I finished my food, I noticed a short black hair on the side of my plate. Thank god it wasn't in my food. And lastly, they never came by to refill our waters. Of course I had to express my concerns and felt bad because this used to be our favorite  brunch spot. I wasn't looking for compensation, but just a reason why the food and service off. They apologized and took 12.00 dollars off. Nice gesture but why such a drastic change? Seems they may have gone through a recent change in management and have filled their servers spots with people who lack experience.
author: Priya K.

description:
Looks like someplace you would want to drive right  by...often confused with just another Inner richmond chinese joint.

However.....

Two words--Ricotta pancakes.  

This coming from a savory breakfast eater.
author: M. t.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place for a while. Finally on a beautiful and sunny Saturday, with a blue sky looming overhead, the bf and I head over for brunch. 

This place makes me think of Home Plate in the Marina. The atmosphere is comforting, like home. I ordered an Eats scramble that had ham, mushroom and green onion. Home fries and your choice of toast (we both had wheat) on the side. The bf had a spicy sausage omelette. The portions are big and generous.
author: Helena H.

description:
I went here for Sunday brunch with two friends. My friend ordered the chicken and waffles, I ordered the B.A.T. (bacon, avocado, tomato) scramble and we split. Both dishes were delicious! Flavorful and creative without being fancy--my idea of a perfect brunch. Good selection of sides too (I had to pick from fresh fruit, a salad, country-style potatoes or fries AND I got toast!).

I'd give the food five stars, but knocked one off the overall review for two reasons:
1) The food is pricey for the size of the portions. Brunch entrees ran from $9-$12, but were about 2/3 the size of a regular brunch portion. We all left feeling still a little hungry... I'm all for smaller portions, but not when they come with big-portion prices.
2) The staff is friendly, but service lacks attention. As a former waitress, I'm willing to forgive a lot and still leave a 20% tip (which I did this time), but I also notice everything. The main complaint with this joint is that I had to ask for things multiple times. When we arrived there was a bit of a wait and I was parched, so I asked the host if I could get a glass of water. He said no problem and that he would bring it out to me, but then never did. We were seated about 10 min after that, so it didn't bug me too much, but then our waitress didn't bring water when we sat down and I had to ask for it... twice... before it came. Same thing happened with the food. When they brought mine out, with a side of toast, I asked for jam and had to ask again before they remembered it. Sure, it was Sunday brunch peak hours, but it wasn't busy enough to explain this lack of attention. 

Luckily, the service was the only part of this brunch that left a bad taste in my mouth :)
author: Lindsey S.

description:
cutie little corner breakfast spot with home cooked - like your mom made it - breakfast.

expect a wait because its a tiny little place.
author: T R.

description: This place is amazing! It's perfect for brunch and their food is really delicious. I first visited Eats with a group of people and a we each got our meals, we all starred at each others plates. The presentation of the meals are beautiful and leaves you wishing you can have everything on the menu. I can't pass any judgments on their service because we came in 10 minutes before closing and they tried to sit us by the door when it was obviously storming outside. We chose to sit somewhere else but they still waited on us patiently and served us quickly. One waiter however, with dark hair and black-rimmed glasses, was very hospitable, humorous, and made us feel welcomed. Kudos!
author: nnenna o.

description:
i had the pleasure of eating at eats (redundant much?) about a month ago with a few girlfriends. the wait ended up being about 45 minutes or so even though the waitress told us it would be only 20. whatevs, it's a small space, we got there around 12:30 on a sunday, of course it was crowded. 

the menu is small but artfully crafted - there are no pancakes, so i am sorry if you love pancakes. HOWEVER the quality of the food and preparation was really a cut above all other brunch options i have had in the area (Q, Ella's). i ordered the vegetarian benedict with swiss gruyere, spinach, and mushrooms. i don't know if they make their english muffins in house, but this was the best one i have ever had - it was huge, fluffy, and rich. the eggs were poached perfectly and the hollandaise was savory and abundant. i seriously dream about this benedict. the side salad was light with a citrusy vinaigrette - the perfect thing to offset the richness of the egg dish. i also had the apple carrot juice, which when fresh-pressed cannot be beat.

i never ate at the old establishment because i am not really a fan of your "classic greasy spoon" breakfast. i don't eat bacon and i like my eggs either scrambled softly or poached. so i have no loyalties. i will say that the new ambiance is much improved.

i highly recommend this place and will definitely be back. yum!
author: Rachael S.

description:
One of the best breakfasts I've had. 

We ate breakfast there two days in a row. The first day we stumbled on it and tried it because it was close to where we were staying, and we were absolutely amazed. The second day we went with a big group and kind of overwhelmed them (it's a small place) but again the food was top-notch. 

Standouts include the fresh fruit juices, the Caprese scramble, and the eggs Benedict. The currant scones were superlative.
author: James W.

description:
I guess you need to come here on a weekday, say Monday at 9:45am in order to get great service. We normally come in on a weekday (ahh the perks of being an indep. contractor) and the service is always speedy.  I probably wouldn't try to cram in on a weekend, but if I did, I'd probably get worse service. 

I love the greasy potatoes and the sourdough toast, especially. I also recommend the mexican scramble. Delish. 

2 people for $18 for breakfast? Not bad, imo.
author: Joanne D.

description: Excellent, esp on a weekday when there's no one there. Intimate, chill spot with food and coffee that hit the spot. Japanese fried chicken with the thickest waffles ever...heaven!
author: Sumi Y.

description:
Okay...so the first time I went to Eats, I wasn't that impressed.  Breakfast is my favorite meal of the day and my friends raved about this place so I thought I would try it.  I might have ordered the standard eggs, french toast, sausage, which, yes, in itself is not impressive.  But maybe the experience was soured by a new mom taking up lots of space by my table with her huge stroller, bumping into me periodically as she rocked her newborn, and speaking baby-ese to entertain him.

Then I met someone who had friends who worked at Eats.  I told him of my experience, and he encouraged me to give it a second chance. This time, he recommended the Ricotta pancakes.  Ricotta in pancakes?  So we go and I order.  There were no new moms or newborns in sight on this Sunday.  The ricotta pancakes ROCKED and my Eats experience renewed. 

You've just gotta try the ricotta pancakes!
author: Gail O.

description: i loooooooooooooove EATS. Simple and straight to the point food. Coffee is good to. There is usually a line, probably 15-30mins wait depending on what time you arrive.  I normally get 2 eggs over easy, side of smoked salmon with tomatoes. Oatmeal is great as well.
author: Lola D.

description:
Oh San Francisco, you always amaze me with your gourmet food and new restaurants popping up all over town.

This was formerly, a mere few mths back, a greasy spoon.  We were up early on Sunday and decided to go get a greasy brkfst the only choice on old Clement.  Noticed the renovation but had no idea it changed hands.

Now the Burma Superstar folks re-opened with the same name.  Vibe is much better, decor is subtle hipster.  This joint could be in Noe, Protrero, etc. but luckily in the less-hip Inner Richmond.

Friendly, attentive service, many choices with fresh juice, veggie juice, etc.  They give you fresh scones with home made jam while you wait for brkfst.  How has no other place figured that one out.  A lot of considerate, customer friendly touches at this place.  

My breakfast was huge, fresh, and uniquely SF.  They also have current buzz dishes like Fried Chix/Waffles.

I had Eggs Benedict with spinach (a ton fresh), portobellos shrooms, in a spiced fontina hollandaise in between super fresh english muffs with a veggie heavy delicious salad with orange vinaigrette.  Poached eggs were perf.

We will be back.  Thanks B*Star for waking up the neighborhood.
author: Lo F.

description: Excellent breakfast.  Love the mexican breakfast dishes and blood orange mimosas.  The huevos rancheros are delicious.
author: Lili L.

description: Went here yesterday for a sunday brunch with the girls. Way shorter of a wait than I expected which was nice and the food was a-fuckin-mazing! Had the chocolate chip banana pancakes, and basically went to food coma heaven. Everyone else at the table ordered something different and there was nothing but good things to be said about the food. I will definitely be visiting this place again soon for some nom noms!
author: Charlotte P.

description:
One morning, not too long ago, two girls, exhausted from days of moving, woke up on a Sunday morning in their new neighborhood and were famished.  Where, they wondered, could a good breakfast be found?  The kind of hearty breakfast you dream about after the rigors of moving (or tossing a few back)...

They wandered down an avenue and through the parting mist (or more likely, fog) saw an ungodly green sign that said "breakfast - 'EATS' - lunch".  Could it be so simple?  They crossed the street and gleaned from the menu that yes! it can be just that simple.  There at EATS they found the kind of greasy, real (and cheap!) breakfast that probably shouldn't be had too often but is just right whenever you do.

They left that morning, tummies full and ready for more un-boxing action.
author: Rashmi N.

description: I went into Eats and was greeted by the nicest young lady by the name of Teal. She was ready to assist us and took our order right away. We ordered a side chocolate chip pancake and Rancheros with bacon, which were very tasty. My husband and I were incredibly pleased with our meal and we were impressed by the staff who worked quickly to make sure we were taken care of. I would definitely go back, I even waited in the rain along with 20 other die hard Eaters.
author: P. R.

description:
There is not much to pick from in the inner richmond in the line of breakfest places, but this is a good start. The food was good, pancakes were fluffly and tasty, eggs cook well, which  I like. My friend an I both ordered a breakfest and then shared 1/2 with eachother so we could try two dishes. The other half of breakfest was an omelette, which was also tasty and really packed with cheese and veggies. 

I like this place, it was clean and the food was simple food and worth the money.
author: Bunny C.

description:
The best cure for the day after hangover/late night fun. It's a little spot that most people over look, because they're too busy looking for parking for B-star or genki or quickly. It looks like a run down spot, however its operated in the most efficient economical way possible. and that's why they are still there.

Definitely a mom and pop shop, so if mom and pop shops aren't for you...then go to stacks (which is good too. see my review on that as well). The food may not look that "appealing" but once you pop...oh man, your in for it. The decor and ambiance isn't too appealing, but it feels like you are in a big dining room, cause your pretty much sitting elbow to elbow with the parties next to you. But it adds to the experience. In addition the smell of sausage eggs and bacon and oil consumes this small little hole in the wall. 

Their omelets and ricotta pancakes are the best fix for a home made meal. and the homefries/potatoes hit the spot. I ask them to cook em just a little more than they usually do, to get that crisp and crunch. If you want to take a risk, i say you go for the "Eats special", which is pretty much scrambled eggs, veggies and some meat mixed around. I'm still alive, so it's pretty good...right?

If you do go there, i recommend you go there early, and if you drive, be sure to drop someone off, and sign in. Find parking away from the avenues (on the opposite side of arguello), maybe i shouldn't have said that, but now you know where i park. damn. If you bring a big group, expect to wait REALLY long, cause this is a place mostly for 2s and 4s. that and you'll get dirty stares from the other people waiting outside. you don't want that. we're all just trying to eat.

this is why I usually order for pickup and it takes about 10 minutes to make. they don't have menus you can take home nor do they have menus online. but they pretty much have the standards from santa fe, denver, etc. etc. either way you won't be disappointed. 

In reality, anyone could cook this on their own...but why would you? Most of us don't have time or the supplies to cook such things, or the skill to make awesome homefries. That and if you see your friends there, you know they've found a gem (and have good taste) in this area of san francisco.
author: Michael L.

description: I like the new decoration and all.  Unfortunately, the food just isn't as good as before and they've lost that "homey" touch.  The wait was too long and even the "coffee" while you wait couldn't appease us.  I'm sorry to say that Eats won't be our local hangout anymore..*sob*
author: Bessie T.

description: The service at Eats is nothing short of abysmal.  It's a case study of inefficient operations.  The owners clearly don't care because I've been twice in the 4 months and the experience has been the same -- pathetically bad.  Be prepared to have your side bacon while you're paying the bill.  It's a good thing the food is good because otherwise we wouldn't ever return and suffer the long waits. Please, Eats, hire a dedicated busboy/host so that your empty tables can get bussed in a timely manner! It pisses me off to no end standing on the curb (along with the other exasperated starving people) seeing 5 empty, dirty tables sit there for over 10 minutes while people are waiting to eat. Simply stupid!
author: Carrie M.

description: The Capresi Scramble is scrumptious and the roast potatoes have whole roast garlic cloves included. The coffee is good and the service is friendly and patient.
author: Rennie S.

description:
This started strong and has many good factors. I can't say enough about the yummy food.

The problem is simple: service.

Consistent problems with wiping down tables, table settings, pouring coffee, offering water, basic attentiveness.

Will probably be going less often now that i am seeing a concerning trend.
author: RC K.

description:
Ate there for the second time yesterday morning.  Tried to get far enough away from the madness of B2B but still have it be within dog walking distance.  Perfect option - well at least we didn't see anybody puking in front of the place - although there was one woman in a prom gown kind of sprawled the sidewalk...but, you usually see worse downtown any day of the year).  And...at least one member of the staff remembered me from the last time I ate there (nice!).  

Last time ordered the sausage omlette...was very tasty!  Right amount of flavor, but not overwhelming.  Potatoes @ toast pretty standard.  Yesterday I ordered the Bacon Waffle...YAY!  Excellent...here was some overwhelming flavor...and it was very much welcomed!  Spicy and enjoyable.  Both times my husband ordered the chicken & waffle dish...and both times it was wonderful.

The jalapeno cornbread was pretty good...especially with the honey butter.  But yesterday they were out of both the cornbread (and it wasn't even noon)...and their bisquits.  So, that was a bit disappointing.

Service can be a bit slow at times.  The first time I kept trying to get the wait-staff's attention to get a refill on the coffee...and finally got up to go get some myself.  The person behind the counter said: "You don't have to come up here to do that."  I was a bit snotty in saying: "I realize, but nobody was even looking in my direction when I was waving for their attention for the last 10 minutes."  (maybe that's why they remembered me from the last time! :-)   

But it is a small but busy place, so...I can be understanding when the service isn't completely spot-on.

Highly recommend for brunch on the weekend.
author: Jay D.

description:
Husband and I came here for Sunday brunch today. Contrary to what I've heard, there was no wait! Hubby had an omelet and I went for the seafood scramble.  We waited for quite some time to get our food- this is understandable, however, as the place was full and there are only four or five staff members. Food was good- pretty standard diner fare. 

The only downfall to this place is that a party of NINE were seated basically on top of us. I can't help but try and listen in on other people's conversations so I was like a kid with ADD. Hubby laughed and accused me of ignoring him.  Oh well, what are you gonna  do?
author: Kayla N.

description:
I had high hopes for this place. It's always packed at brunch time when I pass by.

The staff was courteous, the food came a little slow, though at brunch time you might expect that.

But I wasn't impressed by the food. It wasn't horrible. But is was just ho-hum. 

My black bean omelet was skimpy on the cheese and flavor.

Perhaps this is a pancake place.
author: M O.

description:
I'm definitely one of those people who gets very intrigued when she sees a line out of a small restaurant.  So, on a cloudy Sat morning, when my friend and i were passing by, we saw this place with a line out the door.  We didn't like having Chinese so, we decided to try the place.

It's your typical SF American diner ambience and food.  The food does take long but I mean the place is pretty small and I think I saw only 1 cook with 1 Mexican helper. So, give them a little break.
author: Food L.

description: The Huevos rancheros and the waffle berries were delicious.  I'd go back.  Service was on the slow side, so I wouldn't go here if you're in a hurry.  Ambiance was good and the staff were friendly.
author: Ela A.

description:
I've been to this place two or three times and each time I've made a mental note to not go there if I have a choice. 

Pro: Cute neighborhood joint with tempting menu items that use fresh/timely produce of the season. Staff is friendly and I like the open kitchen. 

Cons: "Tempting menu items that use fresh/timely produce of the season" have no flavor. While I appreciate the thought, I think the execution lacks... well, taste. I went last weekend and got the Farmer's Market Scramble (I think that's the name) which uses 3 or 4 types of fresh produce and comes with garlic home fries. The Scramble tastes like the chef forgot salt... and other ingredients... but the garlic home fries were too salty. My boyfriend's tuna melt was also too salty and even a bit on the dry side. We also started with the Jalapeno Corn Beard which also was bland and dry. The honey butter that it came with didn't help much. And, to add the cherry on top, the food took at least 20 minutes to come out. I mean, 20 minutes-plus might be standard for dinner, but brunch? Sorry, friend, I think not. (And, oh, that was after a 20 minute wait for the table which I didn't count upfront because I have no problems waiting that long for some good brunch.)

Sorry, Eats, I really do want to like you (mainly bc you are so close to my house), but two or three tries is all I can do.
author: Christy S.

description: Clean, good breakfast, good coffee, quick service and nice atmosphere. The blueberry scones were fabulous and breakfast was very tasty. And they were very patient with my elderly companion with Alzheimer's who kept cleaning the table. I appreciated their patience.
author: Barb B.

description: Now this place is legit. Unfortunately they know it. Great food decent prices and a creative menu. The only reason I don't think it is 5 star worthy is because it gets very crowded and its tailored toward parties of 2. If you go with friends be prepared to wait and be comfortable with being crowded this place is tiny inside, I'm usually ok with waiting but I don't like that they advertise that they will sell you coffee while you're waiting. I'm waiting 45 minutes to spend $15 on breakfast can't I have some coffee while I wait? Great food, a little pretentious.
author: Christian S.

description: So delicious!  This is one of our favorite spots for a breakfast date . . . in fact we are going today. Their bloody mary is delicious, they have great fresh fruit selections,and my husband raves about the bacon waffle dish.  Try going on a week day if possible.  We haven't gone on a Saturday or Sunday, but when we have driven by, there is usually a wait outside.
author: Lori C.

description: Food was great and huge servings. Service was a little slow and forgetful. The potatoes come with whole cloves of roasted garlic, lots of garlic. My omelet was good, spinach, flavorful mushrooms, tomatoes and cheese. They did forget butter for the toast and the DELICIOUS blood orange juice we had ordered.  My fiancé ordered the waffle bacon, he LOVED it. The food over all was really good. Be sure to get there before 10am. I also liked the little detail of the mugs for coffee on the table with spoons already in them. We will return.
author: Vera L.

description:
Gross Food! Worse brunch place I've been to in the Bay Area. 

I ordered a country-breakfast Combo.  Nothing on my plate was even eatable.  The beacons were extremely burned and chalky, eggs( supposed to be Sunny-side-up) were very hard  and rubbery on the entire bottom surface, the French toasts were also very very greasy.  My fiance ordered an Egg-Benedict and the sauce was full of large lumps and overly buttery.

If it were not for the location of this little brunch place, it would have been out of business a LONG time ago!
author: Christina C.

description:
The food was good but the wait for this place for brunch/breakfast is ridiculous...lemmings anyone?

There are two other places within a block of this place that are just as good, but maybe I shouldn't give that away.

I had some sort of Chicken Fried Chicken with eggs and it was tasty, but it took a little while.

I dunno what time a prior reviewer (Bernard D)
 went to Eats but he either west super early...or at closing because I have never seen this place without a line...and really, waiting for eggs???  C'mon people.
author: Bingo T. K.

description: We were walking down Clement and didn't really have a place in mind, so Yelped this place as we walked by.  A short wait later we were seated at the counter. Cozy place, so depending on the time there could be a wait.  The staff was friendly and helpful.  We had chicken and waffles and a portabella mushroom sammie. Both were very tasty.  The chicken breast was breaded and fried.  A mushroom gravy over the top served with waffles that came with honey butter.  Nice..  The grilled shroom sandwich is served cold, so if you are expecting it warm.....  Regardless of the fact that it is grilled and chilled, it's assembled to order.  All in all, a score for us for breakfast in the future.
author: Scott K.

description:
I have to go on a diet after my dad visits me, this is his home away from my home.

I m surprised about the complaints for this restaurant, as it is obviously family owned and so it has all the intricacies that these restaurants have. Sometimes a little slow, but that just means more family fun time!

I particularly care for the cornmeal pancakes with fresh fruit, and their scrambles have just the right amount of greas. Not a lot of choices, but what they serve is usually well prepared and enough to split with a partner.

With a focused menu, check the specials board before you order. It seems like there is an omnipresent Italian sausage special that is pretty tasty.

Coffee is always refilled with the utmost speed, but shy people beware-the bathroom is not secluded.

Avoid the window seats when they are in direct sunlight, and the seats adjacent to the door because of the foot traffic.

Noobs: please check the self sign-up list outside the door before proceeding inside and demanding a table while 10 people stand waiting outside.
author: Michael H.

description:
It's a diner....
The service sucks....
The food does NOT make it better...
The crowd CAN make it worse.....
Your wallet will make you feel stupid
author: Spanky M.

description:
Too crowded on weekends to justify the wait for okay food.
If you're in the neighborhood on a weekday you can get served fairly quickly. The veggie omelet and the potatoes that come with it are fantastic.
author: chris m.

description:
I had less than an hour before my next appointment and I wanted to have a quick bite to eat before I headed into an extended meeting that was sure to last a couple of hours. Normally when I pass by this establishment, there is a wait to get a table. But today I found this restaurant still bustling but with a couple of tables open. Perfect. 
I was seated and since I didn't have much time to kill, made my selection.  I ordered the steel-cut oatmeal and the strawberry-lemon aid. I figured the oatmeal would be, well, just oatmeal. But it was so much more! Topped with fresh fruit, a layer of cinnamon and brown sugar, and fresh milk. Even better, they remembered to omit the walnuts (which are usually standard) as I am deathly allergic to them! It was out quick and on my table in no time. Which was good because I only had 15 minutes to eat it.
The strawberry lemon aid was a great refreshing side to the brunch. Definitely going to come back and have a proper, full breakfast.
author: Chris R.

description: Good creative and traditional breakfast food. Got the carrot ginger juice and it was amazing, some good tea, and the Bacon Waffle... hmmmm as good as it sounds. Problem was the service totally sucked, had to ask and wait for everything, I eventually just had to put my empty tea pot and cup on the seat next to me when the food came, cause there was no room left on the plate, and the waitress, despit a reasonably long wait, hadn't cleared it yet. Go here if you want really good food, and a lengthy meal cause this place clearly isn't in any kinda rush
author: Eric P.

description: Here's the thing, eats is great quality food worth eating, but pretty terrible execution. I don't mind the long waits or even the prices, but the service is so sub par here that I always leave feeling a bit resentful. I've eaten here about 6 times, love the polenta and egg sando, but the spicy tomato skillet is spicy minus flavor. Anyways, I always spend at least 8-10 minutes watching lots of staff just pass by me. The wait wouldn't be so bad if someone would simply give me a cup of coffee or water, it takes about 3 seconds. My recommendation would be to get to go. Sorry Eats, I want to love you, but you need better staff!
author: Cory G.

description: Everything I have had here is really good. The service is always good as well. Out of the 6-10 times I have been here we have had only one mishap with the food, but they made repeated efforts to fix it and in the end... it's a 90% chance everything will be better than just good.
author: Jordan P.

description: I had Zoe's Bacon and Egg Sandwich and thought it was pretty good.  I didn't expect the yolk in the fried egg to be runny but it was still quite tasty.  It was a good portion and I really enjoyed the potatoes that came with it.  Service was overall good, but they were a bit slow on coffee refills. Even though they were pretty busy we seemed to get seated pretty fast.  I would definitely recommend it!
author: Anjali P.

description: I love Eats! I've had one of the best tuna sandwiches there. Proportions are very generous and it's the perfect breakfast/brunch place around my neighborhood. I only had half of my sandwich and I was already full. I tried my friend's salmon omelette and it was delicious. Great service and great atmosphere. There is metered parking on Clement but if you go in the mornings on a weekday, there should be plenty of parking. I would definitely recommend this place!!
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
I love this place!!! My whole family loves it. We live in the Ingleside district and basically drive all the way across town to have brunch here. Food taste great, not exactly the best option if you're in a diet. 
Sometimes their homefries are a little burn, but after finishing their omelettes I really can't have much more. 
On weekends there's usually a wait, just write your name on the notebook taped to the door.
The owner seems serious but she is really friendly. The  staff is friendly too,  both girls have been working there for a while now. I found this place a few years ago and my family still loves this place. My husband brings his coworkers here, and my daughter always enjoys going to "The Green" restaurant (She remembered the green color outside when she didn't know how to read)
author: karla r.

description: Been to Eats a couple of times. I'm always happy with the menu and food. And we tried the lemonade mimosas - delish. However, the service is hit and miss. My advice - don't sit outside or at the counter. They will forget about you and will NOT apologize. On our most recent visit, we had to wait 10 minutes between being seated and having someone come over for our order. No coffee (yes, during brunch). No water. When we ordered food, we asked for both coffee and water but after another 10 minutes, I actually poured my friend coffee from the wait station. They didn't notice. And when we told our server we did that, she just said they were really busy. Btw the tables that sat down after us had coffee and water served right away. And did they at least comp the coffee we had to serve ourselves? Not a chance. Not sure if it worth coming back even though the food is good. The poor service and moderate pricing leaves no desire to return.
author: Monica T.

description: I have gone for brunch a couple of times.  The food is good and is not your typical greasy spoon brunch spot.  They use fresh and seasonal ingredients.  The place is small and the tables are tight.  The wait is long for brunch, but you can get a cup of coffee while you wait.
author: lilly a.

description: Eats always hits the spot. I've been here a few times in the past couple months and LOVE it. They remember me and are really nice every time I come in, exactly the neighborhood feel that I like. I love the Zoe's Fried Egg and Bacon sandwich. YUM! The garlic potatoes are great, too. Last weekend I had their special, the Spiced Apple Cinnamon Raisin Brioche French Toast (try saying that 5 times fast!) and it was delish. 'nough said. This place is a must.
author: Darina N.

description:
I gotta give it up for Eats and the free coffee outside while you wait. I remember this place way back when it looked like a greasy diner. I always walked by on my way to Q. 
Then one day when Burma Superstar was shut down my boyfriend and I started to cry. The host at Burma said to us.." dont fret little foodies, we are serving Burma food at a place down the street called Eats. Its temporary but you can try it out." So we did and it wasnt as good as burma usually is but we made do.  
Apparently Eats is partnered with Burma. Its all in the family. 
While we were snacking on Burmese we looked at the breakfast menu and adored the beautiful new interior of the former diner. I was sold, a few weeks later whilst hungover, we went to try it out. We showed up about 1pm and didnt wait long. We were seated at the counter in front of the kitchen and got to see all the action. The spinach and mushroom eggs benedict was just right, Not too salty with fresh bug muffins and crisp veggies. The homefries are to die for. 
My boyfriend got the pepper sausage scramble and it was a hefty portion with all the right stuff. Service was excellent and despite the fact that they were sold out of fresh baked scones, I will definitely go back again.
author: M K.

description: We stumbled upon Eats a few months ago and what a find! Local and seasonal menu.  Decor vintage inspired and rustic.  Small space but well thought out.  Now our top 5 favorite places to eat in SF.  I love the caprese scramble!  Haven't had a chance to try the Grape Mimosa but it looks delish and I must have it!
author: Dana G.

description: I LOVE EATS! It makes me cringe to see anything less then a five star review... I haven't read them because they're certainly a waste of time.. But Eats is amazing. From the customer service to the actual food...  This is the first place I bring friends staying with me from out of town. My only complaint is that they close at two thirty... But I'm not actually mad.. It is a breakfast spot...I just want to eat there for every meal of the day.
author: T D.

description: On a visit to S.F.  we stopped in for some great breakfast thanks to the recommendations here on yelp.  It started our day off right!  This is our second visit and it was still as great as the last.  We've had the fried egg sandwich, was awesome, great aioli on it, just absolute great flavors coming together.  The chicken and waffles are also great, moist chicken, not greasy and perfectly cooked waffles!  This time I had the spring scramble with fresh corn, asparagus, fresh english peas....oh it was heaven, thanks to the rec. by the waitress, the side of potatoes were also perfectly crispy and not greasy and just the right compliment.  Do recommend you get there early as the line starts to grow easily.
author: michelle r.

description: Had a real good saturday brunch here.  The eggs were cooked well, and the salad was actually suprisingly good.  Everything tasted very fresh.  I would definitley come back here.
author: Phil J.

description: Ricotta Pancakes, light and they melt in your mouth.  The flavor is ridiculous.  I shouldn't have shared.
author: Arlene C.

description:
New management, updated look to the restaurant and they changed the menu for the worse.  Food was SO tasty before, and now they have modified their menu beyond recognition and you can no longer get standard breakfast fare, just complicated, overdone "brunchy" items.  And they took away their ricotta pancakes, which is just bizarre.

If they expanded the menu slightly, and served those delicious RICOTTA PANCAKES again (what breakfast joint doesn't have pancakes for gods sakes?  They don't have ANY pancakes- I mean REALLY?)
author: Bianca G.

description: If you go early, you can minimize the time waiting in line.  Food's quite good, especially their killer salmon omlette and chocolate pancake, which is just sweet enough without being overwhelmingly so.  Conscientious, attentive service.   Our family of three went for the first time today.  We'll be back.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
A lovely run in the Presidio? Sure! What could go wrong? Well, if you are me and my charming but directionally challenged ex, it will be cold and foggy and you will end up at the Golden Gate Bridge instead of the Richmond, and what started out as a lovely 4-mile run will end up a death march.

Luckily, when we stumbled out of the Arguello gates and turned the corner, there was Eats. We were seated right away (although it seemed some larger parties had to wait outside for a bit) and given some coffee and juice. The food took awhile to arrive, but like others have mentioned, they've only got two waitresses working, and both were hustling as fast a they could. (There was also a creepy, staring kid sitting next to us, but you can't really blame that on the restaurant. Still, cool it with the Manson lamps, Damian.)

My scrambled eggs were both scrambled and eggy, but it was really the potatoes that made the meal. Crispy outside, creamy inside, and totally, totally bad for me. Awesome. The charming ex had corn beef hash, which I tasted and was extremely good. He also had some blueberry pancakes, and he ate them all, so I guess those were OK, too.

Overall, a nice little joint. If I ever planned on running in the Presidio ever again, I would totally stop back.
author: Shannon K.

description: Decent place for a Sunday brunch in the Richmond. LOVE the ricotta pancakes and the good prices. Get there early as there was a wait after 10:30AM. Parking is also pretty good om Sunday mornings. The service is pretty good as well. Give it a try if you're in the neighborhood. There aren't that many American style breakfast places around here to pick from but it'll do the trick.
author: Josephine L.

description: Might be the best Huevos Rancheros I've ever had. Waffles are soft and fluffy. Staff is friendly and efficient. The only thing I don't like is that they've started charging 75 cents for extra syrup. I'm happy to spend 45 bucks on a lavish breakfast for 2 here, but at that price you can throw in an extra syrup.
author: K K.

description: I have been here a couple times and really enjoyed the savory items such as the eggs and fries for example but, i did not not like the deep fried french toast... it was extremely greasy and tasteless... i am puzzled? it seemed it didn't come out of the same kitchen... but, I still like Eats and will continue to patronize...
author: William W.

description: As good as it gets for a fresh local brunch or lunch! I keep going back and taking new friends with me.  There is usually a line because this place rocks! But it moves fast and is worth the wait.  Better for smaller groups.
author: Lauren O.

description:
This is the best place in the neighborhood for an American breakfast.  The menu is pretty much standard and they usually have a special board with some scrambles and omelets.  The portions are pretty big.  I usually use a doggy bag for the home fries, which I can usually not finish.  My favorites here are the bacon avocado and cheese omelet, the spicy italian sausage omelet, and the bacon avocado and cheese omelet.  They have a fairly limited drink menu and I have heard that their coffee is not all that good.
The staff is friendly and helpful.  Be prepared to wait about ten minutes on a Saturday or Sunday morning and write your name on the waiting list.
author: Pandy F.

description: Perfect for brunch.  Fresh squeezed orange juice in your mimosa, need I say more?  Great place to catch up with a friend and enjoy some really great picks on the menu, tomato omelette, my favorite.  The only thing could use an upgrade is the ambiance.  Other than that, a neat find.
author: Jess P.

description:
Yummy ricotta pancakes and avocado/mushroom/cheese omelettes.

Cheap prices.

What's not to like?
author: Al Y.

description: I had gone to this place a few times in the last few years but I was not very impressed with the food. Food and price were decent, it just wasn't a place I would want to go to, but I would go if someone suggested it. When I was asked to go to this place again 2 months ago I thought "sure, it's been a year, I would give it another try", and it turned out that it was closed for some remodeling. Last Sunday (Valentine's day and Chinese New Year) we decided to swing by the place to see if it's opened and it was. There was a short line for tables but we got seated at the counter within 10mins. Service was great, the place looked a lot bigger, and they can now seat a lot more people. The menu was very interesting and I had a hard time deciding what to order. At the end I decided to order something that didn't sound right together but they're delicious on their own - Bacon Waffle! It was DELICIOUS! I definitely like this place now, and I willl recommend the bacon waffle to everyone I take to this place in the future.
author: J L.

description:
Here are my top 5 reasons I love this place:
1) They serve coffee while you wait for your table
2) Make your own mimosas
3) The garlicly breakfest patatos
4) Wonderful and friendly service
5) Very reasonably priced
author: Lisa D.

description: The worse waffle I've ever had and super over priced- it was cold and had no flavor- not to mention they just make tons of waffles at a time and just march them out so its not even fresh- I witnessed it as I was sitting at the counter! Spent over 40 minutes waiting to eat here.. Don't understand the hype. Never again!!
author: Marie o.

description: The tri-tip sandwich and chicken and waffles are amaaaaazing! The grilled onions on the tri-tip are so well cooked. The meat is tender and well seasoned. The chicken is crispy and tasty on it's own, but in addition to the creamy mushroomy gravy and waffles, it is great. The orange juice here is also really good and fresh tasting.
author: Shizuka L.

description:
Tagline could be "Fillmore meets Clement". I was extremely sad to find out Rosie and her husband had left and new owners were taking over Eats (even if it was the folks who took rescued Burma Superstar). I was pleasantly surprised when I did go. They've redesigned the interior, styled it up. There are about 6 times the number of people working there, and it seems like less seating (definitely less floor space in the customer area, but used efficiently).

I got the Belgian Waffle, and a mocha. The little lady got the bacon waffle. The food was great. The mocha was great. Besides having to wait quite a bit longer before ordering, the service was great. Back at the old Eats, we knew all the wait-staff and the owners, so the service was a given. Last Saturday all three waitresses who helped us genuinely seemed interested in how our experience was. I asked about the ricotta cheese pancakes  (rumored, but not on the menu), which were my favorite at the old Eats, and I was told they were still working on the recipe. 

I could honestly go for more of the old Eats menu items, like pancakes, French toast, etc. Since I don't live there now and can't go back so frequently, I guess I can get by with the waffles (and, hint hint, ricotta pancakes). 

I also asked about Rosie and her husband, the previous owners. I was told they had been looking to retire for a couple of years, and were finally able to. That made me happy. They definetly worked hard. Of course, maybe the new owners have them tied up in the back room and are holding them against their will until they give up their ricotta pancake recipe....

The only real negative is the same issue with the old Eats - the door does not close fully on its own, and on a cold Inner Richmond day the gusts of wind are highly annoying and detract from the experience, especially by the window seats to the left of the door as you come in. My advice to the owners - tweak that door closer mechanism so it completes the last inch of door closure when the wind is blowing. 

I'll be going back when I'm in the area. You can bet I'll be trying the riccotta pancakes when they get that on the menu. But I won't be sitting next to the door.
author: Mark P.

description: I like this place. The steak, double eggs with potatoes :) Mmm, two of them, a coffee and O.J. for around 25$. Will be back!
author: Vivian L.

description: Standard brunch food plus really good mini scones. Efficient staff kept the Saturday brunch line moving.
author: Bill L.

description: Whenever I visit my friend that lives in the Richmond district, we end up at Eats the next morning. Love this place. Only downside is that you should expect a wait on the weekends to get in - the food is worth it though! They have no problem customizing your order which is always a plus. I have had the Spanish Scramble once and Huevos Rancheros twice. I will be trying the cream cheese french toast next time!
author: Sarah C.

description:
3/21/10     4 1/2 Stars

wow...this place had been changed from a hole in the wall to a beautiful breakfast place.

This place may give Ella's and Dottie's some stiff competition.

Service was excellent....I don't often say this for a breakfast place...especially when they are buzy. Big staff size
The Belgium Waffle was pretty good. Toasted on the outside and moist and flavorful inside. Didn't need any syrup.

more to come
author: S.K. Y.

description: FINALLY! My *old*er lady friend picked a worthy restaurant! She has a tendency to pick bland places, but what I have had from them so far has been full of flavor. I have been there twice on off peak hours (around 2:00pm) any earlier and you are likely to have a wait. The potatoes are Deeee-lish and their sourdough toast is good too. I like the bacon, avocado and cheese omlette. They don't skimp on anything here either: lot's of avocado, crispy bacon and stringy delicious cheese. The prices are great and the fresh squeezed orange juice is wonderful (though pricey for the size). I would reccomend this place for breakfast anytime, and especially after a night spent at the Richmond's finer drinking establishments. ;) The service is pretty decent too.
author: Lindsey G.

description: You can't beat the quality and portion-size for the price.  The corned beef hash and the ricotta pancakes were highlights of our meal, and the service was good once we finally got a table.
author: Amy D.

description:
$2.50 for a cup of  mediocre coffee.   No refills.  EATS has recently remodeled - and it is nice - but -you are paying for the silly bathroom
in its menu.  

How sad - they forgot who they were - So if you want to pay  $30.00 plus a breakfast for two -not including tip - here you go.
author: mary o.

description: We sat and contemplated our mortality as we waited. And waited. And waited. For our ultimately bad food. Bacon was petrified. One person cooking with the entire restaurant seated sipping water and coffee at 10:30 a.m. on a Monday.  We were doomed. And our mortality slipped on by.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
for reals?

we waited outside for 20 minutes for a table for 2...thats okay, its saturday and brunch time.

when we get inside, we were seated and brought coffee and water almost immediately. awesome!

then we wait.

and wait.

and wait.

and wait some more.

then i look around and try to recognize the patrons that were seated just before us. do they have food? you know you only really do this when youve been waiting a really friggin long time for your food.

finally, 45 minutes after being seated, our food arrived.

meh.

then, there was a fire in one of the pans in the kitchen and the whole place started smelling like burning plastic.

that was our queue to leave.
author: Ameigh F.

description:
I really enjoyed eating at Eats 2-3 times before it was renovated and completely changed, and am really disappointed.

Before, it was (I think) a family run, basic diner that was always busy and served a lot of tasty, no-frills breakfast fare. It wasnt the place to go if you wanted a fancy, over the top, goat-cheese veggie omelette, but if you wanted to get a nice, hot breakfast that tasted really good (scrambled eggs, pancakes, bacon, the basics), it was a great place to go. 

Even though the decor was really old and basic, it was always busy and you always had to wait. Personally, I never care about how good a restaurant looked, as long as the food tastes good. The homie, Cheers-style "Eats" logo seemed fitting because it seemed like a low-key, family-run restaurant with really good fun.

Now its TOTALLY different--the staff is different, the prices are more expensive, and, to my disappointment, the great combos--bacon/eggs/pancakes have been replaced by a bunch of complicated omelettes and other pretentious fare. I cant get pancakes anymore--but I can get a chicken that is wrapped in a waffle (or something like that), or a waffle that has bacon bits in its batter.

To its credit, the portion sizes are generous and the food still tastes pretty good. If you want a trendy breakfast place with fancy omelettes, then come here. But if you ate at Eats before it was renovated and are expecting the same restaurant, you will be disappointed.
author: Eric J.

description:
Awesome place.  Really small, but the food was good. 

I had the fried chicken sandwich.  I don't know what kind of sauce was in it, but it was freaken awesome!

One of the best chicken sandwiches I've ate!  Top five for best sandwich i've eaten.
author: Rusty W.

description: More like 3.5... this place is cheap, fast and decent. Standard breakfast fare in unassuming surroundings. I had eggs, sausage with home fries and toast. Everything was ok except for the sausage which I couldn't bring myself to finish. They just tasted really fatty and off. This place is only two blocks from my house though so I think I'll be here often.
author: Cathy T.

description: I Went here with my girlfriend on Wednesday morning. After a long 25 miles bike ride... the 4 stack of pancakes, eggs, and yummy jam, the place is clean and with that name very really inviting to just sit and relax, I will have to check it out during weekend brunch.
author: mossiwo m.

description: The new and improved EATS is where to go for breakfast and lunch. The food and service are great. I recommend EATS to my friends and everybody!!
author: Conrado A.

description: It can be a bit of a wait but it is so worth it. The ricotta pancakes are delicious and I have not yet been able to replicate them at home (though I've tried). I also love the sourdough french toast. Service is very prompt and they have a delicious drink called yummy juice. I know they have a larger menu but everytime I go there I end up having those two things so I can't speak much about other menu items. Also I have gone here many times and never had a problem with billing.
author: Kelly O.

description: I really like this place. I don't go for the ambience (although I kinda like the casual/cozy feel) and I certainly don't go for the comfort (the tables are way too small to accommodate plates for a group larger than 2). I go for the food. It's reliable. If you're like me and don't care for eggs and omelettes, don't panic - their pancakes are excellent. I suggest the California pancakes, which are the perfect size and made of cornmeal, pre-loaded with delicious fruit and cooked in syrup - yum. For beverages, try the Yum-Yum juice. It's kind of a smoothie, kind of a protein shake, kind of juice - who cares, it's good. The prices are right and the service, which can at times be painfully slow, definitely has a "we're a family and there are like 2 of us cooking back here" feel, which I appreciate. The owner is really nice and definitely cares that you are a happy diner.
author: Kiesha R.

description: I've tried Eats a few times and I keep wanting it to be better than it is. The basic breakfast is the way to go. I've tried the Eggs Benedict and the hollandaise was lackluster, and the chicken and waffles are an absolute travesty - a shanda. The classic  chicken and waffle combo is a soul food mainstay of the Harlem Renaissance - when musicians needed a filling meal at 5 or 6 in the morning after working all night long. With this version, the chicken, the waffles, and the gravy are all wrong and lack any soul whatsoever. If I go back I will stick with the basics: bacon and eggs.
author: Christopher S.

description: I ate here for the first time on Saturday - it was beautiful outside, and we were able to sit next to the window, thank goodness. It looks like we came after the big breakfast and lunch rush, as we didn't have to put our name on a waiting list. The food was solid, down home, honest cooking. The home fried potatoes were great, and my chicken salad sandwich was v. yummy. Good service. No blaring music, which was nice on this quiet lazy day.
author: Kristen O.

description: i am a man of few words. this place no longer deserves the name on it's door. compared to the old eat's, this new one no longer offers: bacon, home fries or pancakes. prices are much higher for less quality and simplicity. it's brunch, it's hard to mess up, but it's amazing how new management has done so.
author: Victor W.

description: OH MY GATOS!  The menu is incredible.  So many lovely little items to choose from.  I was tempted with the chorizo polenta and the waffle bacon, but my eyes immediately were drawn to the fried chicken sandwich.  The chicken was cooked perfectly and it tasted so wonderful with the citrusy slaw, aioli, tomatoes, and avocados.  I got it with mixed greens and even their house dressing is yummy and light.  I should also add that their ingredients are FRESH!  I never really noticed how much fresh tomatoes would make a difference, but it definitely gave me a mouthful of flavor after every bite.  My friend got the cheese, egg, and potato dish.  Basically, it was just a big pile of potato, bacon, mushroom, cheese, and two eggs.  Simple but done right!  The bacon wasn't too fatty and you could taste it in every bite.  Even the potatoes were loaded with flavor.  I usually get really tired of breakfast potatoes too, but I couldn't help myself.  Also, the OJ was sooo refreshing.  I downed a large glass before my food came and I RARELY do that.  I'm not usually a breakfast person, but this place might just turn me.  Just sayin...
author: Kimba V.

description: Come here on a Sunday for brunch if you don't mind a reallly long wait but enjoy a better breakfast than Mel's. I wouldnt rely on street parking, we walked there.
author: Jen C.

description: Great name for a restaurant. I don't go to a resty to show off my lady friend or my new suede jacket - I go to eat, damn it. Eats serves food and it is pretty tasty. I'm pretty sure they are just lunch and breakfast. I've had the breaky a few times and really enjoyed it. The french toast is so very French if you know what I mean.
author: Colin S.

description: Definitely a brunch place catered to the locals. The place was modestly ran by a bunch of really nice people. Basic breakfast fare, nothing extraordinary. I had the Bacon, Spinach, and Cheese omelette. Exactly what you would expect which isn't necessarily a bad thing. Their cornmeal pancakes topped with fruit were also not bad. Again, you get what you expect. However, their dishes can easily be recreated at home for a cheaper option.
author: Mary H.

description: A quaint little place great for weekend brunches. The food is typical diner stuff, with occasional flourishes. And, to reiterate what other posters have said, it is indeed greasy. But isn't that what Sunday brunch is for?
author: Lara L.

description: From the lettering of their sign to the smell of greasy frying in the air to the down home, reliable menu, this has all the makings of the Cozy Neighborhood Breakfast Joint which seems to be lacking around here.  The smell of frying can actually be a little powerful at times but the food is solid.
author: Deb T.

description:
So my friend and I decided to eat here at EIGHT AM.  There were a few people inside and the bathroom had a huge plant in it.  I ordered the three egg scramble with mushrooms, onions, and ham and a coffee.  It came with a lot of potatoes also.  I was incredibly full after the huge plate load of food.  I couldn't even finish the 2 pieces of toast with mixed fruit jelly.

Ok now let's talk about the magical quarter that got me 36 minutes on the meter.  It was incredible, I mean, I haven't gotten that much time for my money since that lady did me sexual favors.

Overall, really good food, not that expensive.
author: Matthew G.

description: No wait on a Saturday morning! That amazed me. The food is good but verrry greasy. Be prepared to do crunches out of guilt afterwards. And either the servers were on some speed-enhancing drug when I went, or service is just damn fast. Because damn! They were fast. Try the ricotta pancakes.
author: Anika K.

description: A good breakfast/brunch place. I like the Mexican scramble, which is what I almost always get. The food's tasty but greasy. In fact, the whole place smells of grease, which I don't mind that much, except that my clothes usually reek afterwards. That's never good. Service can also be a bit slow, especially on busy Sunday mornings.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description: Great place for a relaxing weekend day.  Sandwiches have the perfect meat to vegetable ratio (this is very important!).  Pancakes and omelettes are good too.  Foods are basic but good.
author: Lindsey W.

description: WE LOVE THIS PLACE! A co-worker suggested EATS one early Sunday morning when  we were in search of a breakfast spot. I then discovered their sourdough french toast and my friend discovered the ricottta pancakes. The "special" comes with eggs and bacon or sausage and house potato fries too. Mmm good! I would refer to it as a mom & pops type joint, kind of hole-in-the-wall. And yes, weekends are craziness here. The people are really nice but just decided to give it 4 stars because we noticed after a few times, they kinda began to skimp us on those potatoes. =[ Other than that, STILL LOVE IT! Def a good breakfast spot.
author: Dijonne M.

description:
Nothing is more sad than going back to your favorite breakfast joint only to learn that it has changed owners. No...wait...there IS something more sad: the new owner is a snob and has taken the best thing off the menu because it doesn't fit the restaurant's new 'philosophy.' 
Excuse me...but aren't restaurants supposed to aim to please their customers? I don't give a rip if the ricotta pancakes made by the previous owners were made from a mix ! They were freakin' awesome!!! If you want a fresh start, don't buy an establishment that was made famous by something you refuse to make!
 Furthermore, were that TRULY the reason you removed them from the menu (it couldn't possibly be your smug attitude, your overwhelmingly huge ego, or your inability to duplicate such deliciousness)  Mr. or Ms. NEW Eats owner, you would have been able to make EVEN MORE delicious ricotta pancakes from scratch...and KEEP THE ONE THING THAT MADE THIS RESTAURANT MEMORABLE ON THE MENU!!!
I would have given you a much better rating had our waitress not acted smug and nasty when we asked about the pancakes; ...but she did. Now, there is nothing left to distinguish Eats from every other snotty, overpriced yuppy brunch spot in SF where you have to wait an hour to get something I could have easily duplicated at home.
Shame on you for taking a cool little joint (institution, really...), slapping some makeup on it and changing the entire menu to suit your ego....and next time, at least give me the whole waffle instead of 1/4 of a waffle. 
I was hungry again 5 minutes later, AND you left a bad taste in my mouth to boot.
author: Kathryn E.

description: Food is Awesome!!! Nothing very fancy...but fresh and tasty.  Gets super busy so be prepared to wait on the weekend.  Service could be a little better but food comes out on time.
author: F B.

description:
Here goes my 1st yelp review.

I live on the same block as Eat's and have been a regular for years. The old Eat's wasn't the most glamorous place, but it was good, consistent, simple food served quickly and cheaply.

So, I watched as the new remodel went into place, quickly figured out it was the Burma/ B-star folks behind it, as they are familiar faces in the neighborhood. Was sad to see the old Eats go, but willing to give the new place a fair shake, as I like the owner's other restaurants (though actually I didn't really care for B-Star when it first opened either - it seemed to take them several months to hit their stride in that place, I'm hoping the same will happen at Eat's.)

So I made my first visit about a week ago. Ordered a tea and the chicken and waffles.

The woman who appeared  to be the manager took my drink order. The entire time I was in the place she seemed to be hovering at every single table. While I was eating she kept approaching me and asking how everything was - intrusive and unprofessional. After I ordered my tea from her, I watched her walk over to another table and engage them in about a ten minute long conversation, my drink order completely forgotten until I flagged down another server. The rest of the service staff did seem more professional. 

The tea comes in a teeny tiny little cup. The servers come  to the table about every two minutes to offer more hot water, which is fine, but that's not really the best way to brew tea, to keep pouring hot water over the same leaves.

The chicken and waffles - I don't really get this dish at all. I know chicken and waffles is a southern thing, but I've never had it before so I don't really know what to compare it to. In theory I like the "comfort foods with a twist" concept, so long as the "comfort" isn't lost. 

The chicken itself was very moist, and had good flavor, but the panko crust on the outside was dark, dark brown, nearly burnt. It looked rather unappealing. It probably would have done better to fry it at a lower temperature. The waffles arrived at the table stone cold. I suspect the cook timed it so that she started the waffles at the same time as the chicken, the chicken took longer to cook while the waffles sat. The mushroom sauce went well with the chicken but didn't go well with the waffles at all. And for being the most expensive entree on the menu, $12, portions seemed rather dainty.

I sorely miss my hang-over curing fried egg sandwich, and the hot pastrami with swiss cheese I used to order at the old Eat's. 

There is only one sandwich on the menu now, and it appears to feature the same fried chicken as goes with the chicken and waffles. The old Eat's filled a niche, in that it was the only place in the neighborhood to get a decent hot sandwich for lunch. It seems very odd to me that a place that's only open till 3 in the afternoon wouldn't put together a better lunch menu. 

Anyway, just my first impressions. I'm sure I'll give it another go at some point, like I said I didn't like B-star much my first two times there, but have since come to appreciate it more. But really, there isn't much about the menu at present to bring me back in. I can make eggs at home.
author: Jonathan V.

description: Yelped for a breakfast place in inner Richmond and Halfway Cafe came up.  Walked over to the Halfway Cafe to find that it had closed down for business.  Then suddenly I remembered Eats as I was walking on Clement.  The place is usually packed but it was early so we got seats on the counter.  I ordered the Spanish Scramblewith salad and thought it was pretty good.
author: Mary L.

description: This is right around the corner and I go here often.  I think some of these reviews are funny because I wonder what the people thought they were coming for?  I love the riccotta pancakes...i have to share them each time because I think I would have overload.  Yes for the most part this is diner type food.  The place is named eats now?  seriously.  The prices are very cheap and you receive way too much food.  The service is friendly and the wait is never long.  just....please don't try the yum yum juice......long sstory...short ending.
author: Nikki W.

description: Great Ricotta pancakes... Hard to get in... Friendly staff... Tables are close... reasonable prices. Also hard to park in neighborhood...
author: Debbie C.

description: We went for breakfast during the week recently and had a great meal. There was no wait.  The pancakes were fabulous.  I had the eggs, sausages and waffle combo and it was all awesome.  We will definitely return.
author: Randy D.

description: I just returned to EATS for the first time since it's change of ownership.  I already liked it, but the new people have really kicked things up a notch.  I had the vegetable breakfast sandwich with a side salad.  The sandwich was full of ripe avocado and was oozing with gooey egg yolk (ask for it over hard if you don't like a mess).  The ciabatta was easy to chew but still had a little toasty crispness on the outside.  The cheese was real sharp cheddar...I'm always impressed when a breakfast spot has quality cheese.  The side salad was pretty standard, but the veggies were all ripe.  Even the melon wedge on the side that I pass over at most places was perfectly ripe.  We also had some fries on the table--shoe string style, not too greasy, soft on the inside, crisp on the out.  The space is cramped so I would recommend avoiding peak hours.  I would definitely return!
author: Allegra W.

description:
i can't believe this place exists. but in a HORRIBLE way. i know the burma superstar people bought the place and re-did everything, but i don't like it one bit. (first of all, i don't understand why they even bother with breakfast food, when they should really focus of making authentic burmese food.)

the food is pricey per person. i can't seem to justify $18 for food, drink and tip. its breakfast. its waffles and eggs. the food was a bit cold and it took a while to come; which the place wasn't that busy when i visited a few days ago.

the service wasn't very good. i felt bad for asking for more water and some extra napkins. but i couldn't help it, the waitress was too busy talking to one another and not paying attention to the customers. as someone who has worked as a waitress, i expected a lot more.

i think the owner; the woman (older asian lady), was around  and she wasn't very nice. i heard her reprimanding the wait staff and the kitchen, which made for a very unpleasant afternoon.

i had visited another time earlier in the year and i thought it was okay (the service was better, the food was better, still expensive). so i gave it another chance when some friends wanted to eat here, but there's no way i'm coming back. i'm going to stick with my joe's coffee shop.
author: starla l.

description:
mmm, ricotta pancakes. either my fork was broken or the pancakes were so soft (and melt in your mouth) that i couldn't even pick them up. 

cozy vibe, really affordable and good breakfast/brunch selections. no waffles, though. but who needs waffles when ricotta pancakes are on the menu?
author: kristin e.

description: This place is conveniently located and pretty cheap, however, the food is not so good.  The staff was extremely attentive, but the number 1 criteria for getting me to come back is food.  It is definitely diner food, but not good diner food.  I had 2 eggs over medium with home-fries.  The home-fries looked as if they would be tasty bc they were nice and crisp, but they tasted like old burnt crust on a grill.  The flavor was gross.  I don't see any reason to go back.
author: Jaime C.

description: Greasy spoon for a Saturday or Sunday morning.  Usually a good crowd, and little wait if you get there before 11.  Service is so-so, but who cares on a weekend morning.
author: Andrew R.

description: Great place to have brunch when you're hung-over. I've never been during the weekdays but its usually packed during the weekends. I would say the wait is 15 mins if you're coming for brunch (and shorter if you like late lunch!). It has a lot of windows so the place is great on a nice day. I usually sit near the window and pile ketchup onto my potatoes as the sun shines through. The staff provides great customer service and I think they really pull of a good job for the amount of people that roll in. The menu consists of all your breakfast favorites (omelettes, bacon, sausages, eggs, french toast, orange juice...um, you get the idea). It is a lot cheaper than some of the other places I've been so make sure to stop by if you're ever in the Richmond around 10pm on a Sat!
author: Emily F.

description: Came here on a Thursday mid-morning for brunch and we were seated right away.  The staff was very nice.  The food was good.  I had the fried chicken sandwich but with grilled chicken.  The chicken was moist and flavorful and all the ingredients on the sandwich went well together.  I got to taste my friend's spanish omelette which was also delicious.  Although it took a while for the food to come out, it was worth the wait.
author: le n.

description: Eats is a landmark in my opinion. I've been frequenting this breakfast spot for many years now and its always consistent. Sometimes you will find yourself waiting in line on the weekends, but its always worth it. The ricotta cheese pancakes are their specialty and its hard not to order them every time. On days I'm feeling healthy I get the black bean omelet which is huge and tasty! The omelets come with potatoes and toast, which is allot of food for the price. Check it out if you're in the Richmond district!
author: Garrett B.

description: There aren't too many breakfast places in the area so we stopped in to check it out.  It's your average breakfast spot, nothing super impressive.  Food and service was average.  Can get crowded.  I'd rather cook my own breakfast at home.  I will most likely not be frequenting this place.
author: Meredith K.

description: I've been coming here at least once a month for the past few years.  Hash, eggs, home fries, and toast.  I can never, ever finish the amount of food I get here.  And, as previous posters have noted, when you get coffee, it's ne'er empty.  I mean, when I leave this joint, I'm freakin wired like no joke.
author: Al K.

description:
This place rocks the proverbial casbah. 
Although it is literally a hop, skip and jump away from my apartment, the outrageous Sunday morning lines left me hesitant to brave them, and I could do no better than lust after that corner table whenever I passed by. Finally I thought I'd just split the difference and go there on a Monday when it was sure to be line free. Don't let the clashing decor and posters that come with the frames hanging on the wall fool you. The food is excellent, the waitress knows me on a first name basis, and i've made a ritual out of their mouth watering ice tea which i make sure to order everytime i'm there.
The only problem is deciding whether i should order the french toast or the turkey sandwhich.
Literally "Eat's" you alive.
author: Bethany D.

description: Love the breakfast potatoes, love the Omelettes, love how cozy it is, love the prices.
author: Oscar M.

description: This is the place to go for a plenty good breakfast. I ordered the veggie scramble and home fries which was very tasty indeed. The pancakes are pretty good too, just border line burned and soaked in syrup...hmm hmm good. I ordered a coffee, but here came a cafe mocha, but I drank it anyways because I didn't care I was so famished from no food anyways. One waitress and she was jugglin like 9-10 tables. Impressive indeed. The bill wasn't so bad for two, and I would frequent this place again when I get the chance sooner than soon...!!! Catsup Please
author: Sven S.
